uksc-2015-0177: Littlewoods overpaid VAT to HMRC between 1973 and 2004.
HMRC repaid the principal sum of 205 million to Littlewoods between 2005 and 2008.
HMRC also paid simple interest of 268 million to Littlewoods between 2005 and 2008.
Littlewoods seeks additional compound interest of 1.25 billion on the overpaid VAT.
Littlewoods claims the compound interest is due under the common law of restitution.
Littlewoods argues the compound interest is due as restitution for a mistake of law.
Littlewoods also argues the compound interest is due as restitution of tax unlawfully demanded.
The Supreme Court is asked to determine if Littlewoods' common law claims are excluded by sections 78 and 80 of the Value Added Tax Act 1994.
The Supreme Court is also asked to determine if the exclusion of compound interest is contrary to EU law.
The lower courts found that Littlewoods' common law claims were barred by the 1994 Act.
The lower courts also found that denying compound interest was contrary to EU law.
Littlewoods appeals the lower court's decision on the first issue.
HMRC appeals the lower court's decision on the second issue.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Littlewoods' cross appeal on the first issue.
The Supreme Court allowed HMRC's appeal on the second issue.
Lord Reed and Lord Hodge provided a joint judgment, which the rest of the Court agreed with.
Section 78 of the 1994 Act is said to exclude common law claims for interest.
Section 78(1) limits HMRC's liability to cases of error by HMRC.
Section 78(3) and its referenced provisions determine that interest is calculated on a simple basis.
Section 78(11) sets a shorter limitation period than that applicable to a common law claim.
The limitations in section 78 would be defeated if common law claims for interest were allowed.
Section 78(1) is interpreted to refer only to statutory liabilities, not common law liabilities.
The CJEU judgment does not require reimbursement of losses from the unavailability of money.
The CJEU gives member states discretion to provide reasonable redress in the form of interest.
The lower courts misinterpreted the phrase "adequate indemnity" in the CJEU judgment.
The CJEU judgment supports the use of simple interest by member states.
The CJEU case law supports the principle that interest rates and methods are matters for member states.
The CJEU case C 271/91 is distinguishable from the present case.
The other issues raised in the appeal do not need to be decided.
The other issues would only arise if Littlewoods succeeded on the first two issues.
uksc-2009-0105: E challenged JFS's refusal to admit his son, M, to the school.
JFS is designated as a Jewish faith school.
JFS has an oversubscription policy that gives precedence to children recognized as Jewish by the OCR.
The OCR recognizes a person as Jewish if they are descended in the matrilineal line from a Jewish woman or have undergone Orthodox conversion.
E and M are practising Masorti Jews.
E is recognized as Jewish by the OCR, but M's mother is of Italian and Catholic origin.
M's mother converted to Judaism under the auspices of a non-Orthodox synagogue.
M's mother's conversion is not recognized by the OCR.
M's application was rejected because he did not meet the OCR's matrilineal descent requirement.
E claimed JFS's admissions policy directly discriminated against M on grounds of ethnic origins.
E also claimed the policy was indirectly discriminatory.
The High Court rejected both claims.
The Court of Appeal unanimously held that JFS directly discriminated against M on the basis of ethnic origins.
JFS appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The United Synagogue also appealed a costs order made by the Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court dismissed JFS's appeal.
The Supreme Court allowed in part the United Synagogue's appeal on costs.
The majority of the Supreme Court held that JFS directly discriminated against M on grounds of ethnic origins.
Lords Hope and Walker would have dismissed the appeal on the basis of indirect discrimination.
Lords Rodger and Brown would have allowed JFS's appeal in its entirety.
The Supreme Court's judgments did not criticize JFS's admissions policy on moral grounds.
The legal question was whether M was disadvantaged on grounds of his ethnic origins.
Direct discrimination does not require the discriminator to have a discriminatory motive.
The factual criterion for M's rejection was his lack of matrilineal descent from an OCR-recognized Jewish woman.
The subjective state of mind of JFS, the OCR, and the Chief Rabbi is irrelevant.
The test applied by JFS and the OCR focuses on the ethnicity of the women from whom M is descended.
The requirement of undergoing Orthodox conversion is a significant burden not applicable to those born with the requisite ethnic origins.
The test of matrilineal descent is one of ethnic origins.
Discriminating on the basis of ethnic origins is contrary to the 1976 Act.
JFS and the OCR were indifferent to M's religious beliefs and focused solely on his ethnic origins.
uksc-2017-0040: The Appellant and Respondent are former husband and wife.
They divorced in 2002 after a marriage of approximately fifteen years.
The financial issues in the divorce were resolved by a consent order.
Under the consent order, the wife received 230,000 in settlement of her capital claims against the husband.
The husband agreed to make periodical payments to the wife at an annual rate of 13,200.
The husband anticipated the wife would use the 230,000 to purchase a home without a mortgage.
The wife took out a mortgage and purchased a more expensive home for 345,000.
Between 2002 and 2009, the wife sold and purchased a series of different properties.
With each property purchase, the amount borrowed by the wife increased.
The wife did not reinvest all sale proceeds into the next property.
The wife spent the balance of the sale proceeds, reducing her capital over time.
By 2009, the wife sold her final property and began renting accommodation.
By April 2015, the wife had no capital and debts of around 42,000.
The case involved two cross applications under s.31(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973.
The husband applied for the discharge or downwards variation of the periodical payments.
The wife applied for the periodical payments to be varied upwards.
The judge noted a shortfall of 4,092 per annum between the wife's needs and the existing payments.
The judge held the wife had not managed her finances wisely, increasing her rental needs.
The judge concluded it would be unfair to expect the husband to fully cover the wife's rental costs.
The judge declined to vary the periodical payments either upwards or downwards.
The wife appealed the decision and was successful in the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal increased the periodical payments to 17,292 to cover the wife's shortfall.
The husband now appeals the decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the husband's appeal.
The Supreme Court concluded the judge was entitled to decline to vary the periodical payments.
The husband was granted permission to appeal on the ground of whether the Court of Appeal was entitled to interfere with the judge's decision.
The Court of Appeal erred in saying the judge gave no reason for declining to increase the payments.
The judge gave a clear reason for declining to increase the payments: the wife's unwise decisions increased her rental needs.
The Court of Appeal should have considered the impact of the original capital payment on the wife's rental needs.
The Court of Appeal's decision was based on three earlier cases: Pearce v Pearce, North v North, and Yates v Yates.
uksc-2011-0046: The issue in the appeal is whether the appellants meet the threshold conditions in section 1(6) of the Equal Pay Act 1970 to bring claims of less favourable terms.
The appellants are 251 classroom assistants, support for learning assistants, and nursery nurses employed under the Blue Book agreement.
The appellants wish to compare their terms with those of male comparators, such as groundsmen and refuse collectors, under the Green Book agreement.
The comparators are entitled to a substantial supplement on top of their basic pay, which the appellants are not.
The Employment Tribunal initially ruled that the appellants and comparators are in the same employment.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal overturned this ruling, stating the appellants could not show a real possibility that comparators could be employed in schools.
The Court of Session held that the test used by the Employment Appeal Tribunal was wrong but found the appellants still failed to show comparators would be on Green Book terms if based in schools.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the Employment Tribunal's decision.
The Supreme Court ruled that the same employment test does not require claimants and comparators to be employed by the same employer.
The same employment test requires that common terms and conditions are observed at establishments in Great Britain for relevant classes of employees.
The Supreme Court stated that it is not necessary to show that comparators could be co-located with claimants to satisfy the same employment test.
The Employment Tribunal adopted the correct test and found it satisfied based on the evidence provided.
The Supreme Court emphasized that the same employment test does not establish job comparability, but rather weeds out cases where geography affects terms and conditions.
The Supreme Court stated that the interpretation of section 1(6) is consistent with European Union law.
The European Court of Justice has established that differences in treatment must be attributable to a single source to give effect to the principle of equal pay.
The Supreme Court concluded that section 1(6) does not operate as a barrier to the comparison required by EU law.
The evidence from the respondent's Group Manager confirmed that comparators would retain Green Book conditions if based in schools.
The Supreme Court held that the same employment test should not be interpreted in a way that defeats the purpose of the legislation.
The Supreme Court noted that the requirement for work to be carried out in different places does not prevent equalizing terms and conditions.
The Supreme Court emphasized that the same employment test is a low threshold and does not prevent the proposed comparison.
The appellants' claims will now proceed to determine whether their work is of equal value to that of the comparators.
The Supreme Court stated that the same employment test is not meant to establish job comparability but to eliminate cases where geography influences terms and conditions.
The Supreme Court ruled that the interpretation of section 1(6) aligns with the requirements of European Union law.
The Employment Tribunal was entitled to find that the same employment test was satisfied based on the evidence provided.
The Supreme Court held that the test for same employment should not be interpreted in a way that makes it too easy for employers to segregate workers by gender.
The Supreme Court emphasized that the purpose of the same employment test is to ensure that terms and conditions are not determined solely by geography.
The Supreme Court noted that the correct hypothesis to consider is the transfer of comparators to a different location to perform the same job.
The Supreme Court ruled that the same employment test does not require a feasible co-location of workers.
The Supreme Court stated that the same employment test should not be interpreted in a way that would defeat the purpose of the Equal Pay Act.
The Supreme Court concluded that the same employment test does not prevent the comparison required by EU law to enforce the principle of equal treatment.
uksc-2011-0115: Section 6(1) of the Prosecution of Offences Act 1985 allows a private person to institute and conduct a private prosecution.
Section 6(2) of the 1985 Act gives the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) the power to take over a private prosecution at any stage.
The DPP's policy includes assessing the strength of the evidence in support of the prosecution.
Before 23 June 2009, the DPP used the "no case to answer" criterion to decide whether to take over a private prosecution.
On 23 June 2009, the DPP changed its policy to use the "reasonable prospect test" for deciding whether to take over a private prosecution.
In August 2010, the Appellant instituted two private prosecutions.
On 16 November 2010, the DPP, acting through the Crown Prosecution Service, took over and discontinued the two private prosecutions.
The Appellant applied for judicial review of the DPP's decision to take over and discontinue the prosecutions.
The Appellant argued that the reasonable prospect test adopted by the DPP on 23 June 2009 was unlawful.
The Divisional Court of the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court dismissed the Appellant's application for judicial review.
The Appellant appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court, by a majority of 3:2, dismissed the Appellant's appeal.
Lord Wilson gave the lead judgment for the majority in the Supreme Court.
Lord Wilson acknowledged the constitutional importance of the right to private prosecutions.
Lord Wilson focused on whether the DPP's application of the reasonable prospect test frustrated the policy and objects behind Section 6 of the 1985 Act.
The Supreme Court reaffirmed the right to maintain a private prosecution in Section 6 of the 1985 Act, in qualified terms.
The new reasonable prospect test focuses on the likelihood of conviction rather than the previous "no case to answer" test.
The Royal Commission report of 1981 supported the reasonable prospect standard for all prosecutions.
Prosecutions lacking a reasonable prospect of success may inappropriately use court resources.
A defendant may have a legitimate grievance if subjected to a private prosecution that would not result in a public prosecution.
The 2009 Code for Crown Prosecutors acknowledges that the DPP may act unlawfully by adopting too rigid an approach in applying his policy towards interventions.
Lord Neuberger noted that factors like fairness to the defendant, costs, use of court time, and confidence in the justice system apply to private prosecutions.
The right to initiate a private prosecution remains virtually unlimited, provided it meets evidential and public interest tests.
The right to conduct a private prosecution can be curtailed by the Attorney General through issuing a nolle prosequi.
Lord Kerr emphasized that the right to private prosecutions has been modified by successive enactments, including the establishment of the DPP.
The policy prior to 2009 was not immutable or inviolable.
The new policy may restrict private prosecutions but is not unlawful.
Lord Mance emphasized the strong historical and constitutional basis for private prosecutions.
Lord Mance argued that the reasonable prospect test would emasculate the right afforded by Section 6(1) of the 1985 Act.
Lady Hale expressed doubts about the reasonable prospect test due to potential inconsistencies in determining whether a court would convict.
uksc-2010-0127: The Buyers entered into six shipbuilding contracts with Jinse Shipbuilding Co Ltd in May 2007.
Each vessel was priced at US$33.3 million, to be paid in five equal instalments.
Payment of the first instalment was conditional upon the Builder providing a refund guarantee from a first-class Korean bank.
The Buyers had the right to a full refund if they rejected the vessel or terminated the contract.
The Buyers were entitled to repayment of instalments if the Builder defaulted.
Article XII.3 of the Contracts allowed Buyers to demand refund upon the Builder's insolvency.
The Respondent bank issued identical Advanced Payment Bonds to each Buyer in August 2007.
Paragraph 2 of the Bonds stated the Buyer was entitled to a refund if they rejected the vessel or terminated the contract.
The Respondent promised to pay all sums due to the Buyer under the Contract as per paragraph 3 of the Bonds.
The Respondent's guarantee was conditional on the Buyer making pre-delivery instalments.
Payment under the Bonds would occur upon receipt of a written demand from the Buyer.
The Respondent's liability was unaffected by the Builder's insolvency, reorganisation, or dissolution.
Each Buyer paid the first instalment of US$6.66 million under the Contracts.
One Buyer also paid a second instalment of US$6.66 million.
The Builder experienced financial difficulties in 2008 and entered a debt workout procedure in January 2009.
In April 2009, the Buyers demanded repayment under the Bonds.
The Respondent rejected the Buyers' demands, arguing the Bonds did not cover refunds under Article XII.3.
The High Court ruled in favor of the Buyers' construction of the Bonds.
The Court of Appeal overturned the High Court's ruling in favor of the Respondent.
Sir Simon Tuckey provided a dissenting judgment favoring the High Court's interpretation.
The Supreme Court granted the Appellants leave to appeal.
The Supreme Court unanimously restored the High Court's order.
Lord Clarke delivered the sole judgment, with which other justices agreed.
The core issue was whether the Buyers were entitled to payment from the Respondent for refunds under Article XII.3.
The interpretation of the Bonds depended on their true construction, with Contract terms only relevant if they informed that construction.
The Buyers argued that "such sums" in paragraph 3 referred to all pre-delivery instalments.
The Respondent argued "such sums" were limited to those mentioned in paragraph 2 of the Bonds.
The court must determine the meaning of the language used by the parties in the Bonds.
The court should consider what a reasonable person would have understood the parties to mean.
The court should prefer the interpretation most consistent with commercial common sense when there are two possible constructions.
uksc-2010-0039: The appeal concerns the scope of exceptions to the without prejudice rule.
The issue is whether statements from without prejudice negotiations can be used to interpret a resulting agreement.
TMT Asia Limited and others entered into forward freight agreements with Oceanbulk Shipping & Trading SA.
The appellants failed to pay a sum due under the forward freight agreements.
The parties entered into settlement negotiations expressed to be without prejudice.
The negotiations resulted in a written settlement agreement regarding the sum due.
The respondent brought a claim for damages against the appellants for breach of a settlement agreement clause.
The appellants sought to rely on without prejudice negotiations to support their interpretation of the clause.
The respondent argued that reliance on the statements was precluded by the without prejudice rule.
The High Court held that the evidence was admissible for interpreting the settlement agreement.
The majority of the Court of Appeal allowed Oceanbulk's appeal, holding the evidence inadmissible.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
Lord Clarke delivered the substantive judgment, with whom the other justices agreed.
The without prejudice rule is now broader, including admissions made with a genuine intention to settle.
The without prejudice rule is based on public policy encouraging settlements and parties' agreements.
The boundaries of the without prejudice rule should not be lightly eroded.
Authorities established that exceptions to the rule may be applied when justice requires.
The central issue was whether an interpretation exception to the without prejudice rule should be recognized.
Lord Clarke concluded that justice demanded recognizing the interpretation exception.
Without the without prejudice material, the agreement could not be properly construed.
The principles of contractual interpretation include admissibility of objective facts from negotiations.
The interpretation of a settlement agreement should be the same whether negotiations are without prejudice or not.
Permitting recourse to without prejudice material respects modern principles of contractual interpretation.
An alternative approach would create an unprincipled distinction between exceptions to the without prejudice rule.
One exception allows use of without prejudice material to determine if negotiations resulted in a compromise agreement.
Another exception allows reliance on without prejudice material to show a settlement agreement should be rectified.
There is no sensible basis to distinguish between admitting without prejudice communications for rectification and for construction.
Lord Clarke emphasized the importance of the without prejudice rule and cautioned against admitting evidence beyond what is necessary.
The judgment does not intend to downplay the importance of the without prejudice rule.
The judgment does not encourage admitting evidence of pre-contractual negotiations beyond what is necessary.
uksc-2010-0231: The Appellants are employed to work on offshore oil and gas installations.
The Respondents are the employers of the Appellants.
All Appellants, except one, were contracted to work in a pattern of two weeks offshore followed by two weeks onshore.
While offshore, the Appellants generally worked 12-hour shifts each day.
During their offshore shifts, the Appellants took rest breaks.
The Appellants did not have any days off while they were offshore.
The Appellants were mostly free from work-related obligations during their field breaks.
The Working Time Regulations 1998 incorporate the Working Time Directive 2003.
The Working Time Directive 2003 sets minimum health and safety requirements for working time organization.
The Working Time Directive 2003 includes provisions for daily rest, weekly rest, and annual leave.
Article 7 of the Working Time Directive 2003 provides for a minimum of four weeks of paid annual leave.
Regulation 15 of the Working Time Regulations 1998 allows workers to take leave on chosen days, with employer requirements for specific days.
The case centers on whether onshore time counts toward the Appellants' annual leave entitlement.
The Appellants argued that annual leave means release from work obligations, so onshore time should count.
The Respondents argued that onshore time is a rest period, not working time, so it does not count toward annual leave.
The Employment Tribunal ruled that leave involves release from work obligations.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal held that field break time, after compensatory rest, was sufficient for annual leave.
The Court of Session refused the Appellants' appeal, affirming that four weeks of rest from work is required.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and refused a reference to the European Court of Justice.
The Supreme Court judgment was given by Lord Hope.
The Working Time Directive requires rest breaks, daily rest, and weekly rest periods.
Rest periods under the WTD must be measured separately and cannot overlap.
Workers must be provided equivalent compensatory rest if their working patterns require it.
The Appellants' field break included two days of compensatory rest for their offshore work.
Article 7 of the WTD does not require annual leave to be taken consecutively or uninterrupted.
Annual leave is considered a rest period under the WTD, not working time.
The WTD does not impose qualitative requirements on rest periods, only quantitative.
The Appellants' contract required them to work 26 weeks a year.
The purpose of annual leave is to allow workers rest and leisure.
The European Court of Justice has not ruled that pre-ordained rest periods cannot be annual leave.
uksc-2016-0052: The appellant was convicted of drug trafficking offences on 21 May 1999 and sentenced to 25 years imprisonment.
On 29 March 2000, the appellant was ordered to pay a little over 5.4 million by way of a confiscation order.
The order required the appellant to pay the amount within 12 months or serve six years imprisonment in default of payment.
On 4 May 2007, a receiver appointed to realise the appellant's assets paid 12,500.
The magistrates deducted seven days from the six-year term in default to account for that part payment.
At that time, interest had increased the net sum outstanding, allowing for the part payment, to 8.1 million.
Later in 2007 and 2011, the appellant's receiver made further payments of 12,500 and 65,370.
The prison authorities calculated the reduction in the six-year default term based on the proportion these payments bore to the 8.1 million at the time of his committal.
That produced a total reduction of 24 days.
Had the arithmetic been applied instead to an outstanding figure confined to the original 5.4 million, an extra 11 days reduction would have been made.

The issue in the appeal is whether interest is included in the starting point under s.79(2) Magistrates Courts Act 1980 for the giving of proportionate credit for part payment of a confiscation order.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal.
Lord Reed and Lord Hughes give a joint judgment with which the other Justices agree.

The key provisions of the Drug Trafficking Act 1994 (DTA), as in force at the relevant time, were s.10(1), which treats interest for the purposes of enforcement as part of the amount to be recovered under the confiscation order.

S.10(2) of the DTA enables a Crown Court judge to refix and increase the default term if the addition of accrued interest takes the sum outstanding into a higher bracket in the relevant schedule of default terms.

At the relevant time, s.9 DTA stated that where the Crown Court orders a defendant to pay any amount under s.2 DTA, ss.139(1)(4) and 140(1)(3) of the 2000 Sentencing Act shall have the effect as if that amount were a fine imposed on the defendant by the Crown Court.
S.140(1) of the 2000 Sentencing Act treats for enforcement purposes a fine imposed by the Crown Court as if it had been imposed by the magistrates, and thus a confiscation order is treated the same.

S.76 Magistrates Courts Act 1980 contains the magistrates' power to commit an individual to prison for failure to pay a fine and an alternative power to issue a warrant of distress (now named a warrant of control).
S.79 Magistrates Courts Act 1980 is the only provision dealing with part payments.
The difficulties in this case arise from the fact that the enforcement of confiscation orders is achieved by applying statutory provisions to confiscation orders which were not designed for them.
A confiscation order is thus treated as if it was a fine imposed by the magistrates.
The difference between a magistrates-imposed fine and a Crown Court-imposed fine is that magistrates do not fix a default term when imposing the fine.
Imprisonment in default is only considered in the event of a default and, at that time, the magistrates will know whether the default is total or partial.
Thus, credit can be given for part payments made before the commitment process is undertaken.
S.139(2) of the 2000 Sentencing Act mandates the fixing of an anticipatory default term at the time the fine or order is imposed.

The difference in practices led the lower courts to analyse s.79(2) Magistrates Courts Act 1980 as assuming the standard magistrates practice and thus to conclude that the references in that subsection to a period of imprisonment having been imposed in default of payment were references to the act of the magistrates in issuing the warrant of commitment.

This caused the consequential difficulty that s.79(2) would say nothing about how to deal with part payments made in Crown Court cases between the Crown Court making a confiscation order and the later magistrates proceedings.
Hence, the Court of Appeal understandably read additional words into s.79(2).

The period of imprisonment in default of payment is imposed for the purposes of s.79 when the Crown Court discharges its statutory duty under s.139(2) of the 2000 Sentencing Act and fixes the (anticipatory) term in default.
This construction follows from s.150 Magistrates Courts Act 1980 and is necessary to make sense of s.140(3) of the 2000 Sentencing Act.
uksc-2012-0124: The issue in the appeal is whether the definition of terrorism in the Terrorism Act 2000 includes military attacks by non-state armed groups against national or international armed forces in a non-international armed conflict.
Mr Gul was convicted of five counts of disseminating terrorist publications and was sentenced to five years imprisonment.
The offence of disseminating terrorist publications was created by section 2 of the Terrorism Act 2006.
Section 2 of the Terrorism Act 2006 defines terrorist publications as including publications likely to be understood as encouragement of acts of terrorism.
Section 1 of the Terrorism Act 2000 defines terrorism as the use or threat of action involving serious violence, damage, or disruption, and designed to influence governments or intimidate the public.
The publications in question included videos showing attacks by al Qaeda, the Taliban, and other proscribed groups on military targets in Chechnya, Iraq, and Afghanistan.
The videos also included the use of improvised explosive devices against Coalition forces.
The videos featured excerpts from martyrdom videos.
The videos included clips of attacks on civilians, including the 11 September 2001 attack on the United States.
The videos were accompanied by commentaries praising the bravery and martyrdom of those carrying out the attacks.
The videos encouraged others to emulate the actions depicted.
The Court of Appeal refused Mr Gul's appeal against conviction and sentence.
Mr Gul's appeal to the Supreme Court challenged the conclusion that the definition of terrorism included attacks by non-state armed groups on armed forces.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr Gul's appeal.
Mr Gul argued that domestic and international law required a narrow interpretation of the statutory definition of terrorism.
The Court considered domestic law principles in interpreting the statutory definition of terrorism.
The Court held that the natural and wide meaning of section 1 of the 2000 Act could not be read restrictively.
Section 117 of the 2000 Act was found to be of no assistance in interpreting the definition of terrorism.
The Court observed that prosecutorial discretion should not be used to mitigate the broad reach of the offence.
The Court noted that there is no accepted definition of terrorism in international law.
The U.N. General Assembly's working group reported disagreements on the distinction between terrorism and legitimate self-determination struggles.
Some U.N. resolutions have labeled the activities of al Qaeda and the Taliban as terrorism.
The international law of armed conflict does not grant immunity to combatants in non-international armed conflicts.
Some provisions of the 2000 and 2006 Acts implement treaties that do not cover insurgent attacks on military forces.
The United Kingdom could still define terrorism more broadly than treaties required.
The Court noted that the material in the case was disseminated in the United Kingdom.
The Court concluded there is no valid basis for narrowing the definition of terrorism beyond its plain meaning.
The Court acknowledged concerns about the wide definition of terrorism and the powers granted under the 2000 and 2006 Acts.
The Independent Reviewer of Terrorism Legislation in the UK has highlighted concerns about the broad definition of terrorism.
The 2000 and 2006 Acts grant substantial intrusive powers to the police and immigration officers.
uksc-2009-0127: The Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 (RTOA) originally set the maximum sentence for driving while disqualified to six months imprisonment or the statutory maximum fine or both when tried summarily.
The maximum sentence for driving while disqualified, when prosecuted on indictment, was 12 months imprisonment or a fine or both.
A committee recommended increasing the sentencing powers of sheriffs sitting summarily to a maximum of 12 months.
The Criminal Proceedings etc (Reform)(Scotland) Act 2007 (the 2007 Act) was enacted by the Scottish Parliament to implement the committee's recommendation.
Section 45 of the 2007 Act increased the maximum sentence that sheriffs could impose for driving while disqualified to 12 months imprisonment.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller were each sentenced to more than six months imprisonment for driving while disqualified in summary proceedings.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller challenged their sentences, arguing that the 2007 Act's amendment was outside the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The High Court of Justiciary dismissed the appeals, stating that the amendment was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Appellants were granted permission to appeal to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by a majority of three to two.
The Supreme Court held that the provision in question was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
Lord Hope delivered the leading judgment on behalf of the majority.
The majority judgment applied the rules in sections 29 and Part 1 of Schedule 4 of the Scotland Act 1998.
Three questions were raised regarding the legislative competence of the 2007 Act's amendment.
The first question was whether the purpose of s.45 was to modify Scots criminal law as defined in section 126(5) of the Scotland Act.
The majority concluded that the purpose of s.45 was to reform summary justice by reducing pressure on higher courts.
The jurisdiction of a sheriff is defined by the penalties they can impose, which is a matter of Scots criminal law.
Section 45 of the 2007 Act was directed to a rule of Scots criminal law, not a reserved matter.
The majority held that s.45 was not related to a reserved matter under section 29(2)(b) of the Scotland Act 1998.
The second question was whether s.45 ensured consistency in the application of law between reserved and non-reserved matters.
The majority concluded that s.45 aimed to ensure consistency in the law relating to the sentencing powers of sheriffs.
The majority held that s.45 was not related to a reserved matter under section 29(4) of the Scotland Act 1998.
The third question was whether the sentencing jurisdiction of a sheriff in relation to road traffic offences was special to the RTOA and RTA.
The majority identified the rule being modified as a rule of Scots criminal procedure, not a rule special to the RTOA or RTA.
The change in law by s.45 did not alter the maximum period of imprisonment for driving while disqualified.
The rule modified by s.45 concerned the procedure for imposing the maximum sentence.
The majority held that s.45 was an important modification to a rule of Scots criminal procedure, not an incidental or consequential effect.
The court concluded that s.45 was within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.
The appeals were dismissed and remitted to the High Court of Justiciary for any further orders.
Lord Rodger and Lord Kerr dissented, with Lord Rodger arguing that the RTOA's provision on maximum imprisonment was special to a reserved matter.
uksc-2013-0266: The appellants challenged the validity of a 2010 amendment to the Immigration Rules requiring foreign spouses or partners to pass an English language test.
The amendment was introduced to assist integration, improve employment chances, raise language awareness, save translation costs, benefit children, and reduce vulnerability.
The Rule requires spouses and partners to demonstrate basic English language skills by passing an approved test unless exceptional circumstances apply.
Guidance accompanying the Rule states that exceptional circumstances are rare and do not include financial reasons or lack of literacy.
The appellants are UK citizens married to foreigners since 2009 and 2010 respectively.
In Saiqa Bibi's case, the husband could not meet the requirement due to the unaffordability of relocating to Pakistan.
In Mrs. Ali's case, the husband could not meet the requirement due to the absence of a test center in Yemen.
The High Court ruled that the Rule itself was not unlawful.
The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision by a majority.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal regarding the Rule's infringement on article 8 of the ECHR.
The Supreme Court invited further submissions on whether the Guidance is incompatible with article 8 rights in certain cases.
Three justices provided substantive judgments: Lady Hale, Lord Hodge, and Lord Neuberger.
The right to respect for family life includes the right of married couples to live together.
Article 8 does not require the state to accept non-national spouses for settlement in a country of choice.
Interference with article 8 rights must be proportionate and strike a fair balance between individual and community interests.
The six objectives of the Rule aim to protect the economic well-being of the country and the rights of others.
Assisting integration through English language skills is a legitimate and important aim.
The test may not be as effective as opportunities for learning after arrival, but the aim is legitimate.
There is a rational connection between the Rule and its intended objectives.
The Rule contributes to the overall aim of promoting integration.
The Rule is no more than necessary to achieve its intended contribution.
The impact of the pre-entry language requirement has not been systematically studied.
Access to appropriate tuition and test centers may create obstacles, leading to unjustified interference with article 8 rights.
The problem lies in the restrictive interpretation of exceptional circumstances in the Guidance.
The Guidance may result in a significant number of cases where article 8 rights are breached.
The discrimination claim does not add to the article 8 claim, as exemptions for Anglophone countries are justified.
The Rule itself is not disproportionate.
Lady Hale suggested recasting the Guidance to grant exemptions where compliance is impracticable.
The Court invited further submissions before deciding on a declaration regarding the Guidance.
Lord Hodge agreed that the Guidance may lead to breaches of article 8 rights but was not persuaded to declare it incompatible.
uksc-2013-0023: The vessel Alexandros T sank on 3 May 2006 and became a total loss 300 miles south of Port Elizabeth.
The sinking of the Alexandros T resulted in considerable loss of life.
The owners of the Alexandros T were Starlight Shipping Company.
Starlight Shipping Company made a claim against their insurers.
The insurers denied liability, citing the vessel was unseaworthy with the privity of Starlight.
Starlight made serious allegations against their insurers, including misconduct involving tampering with and bribing witnesses.
On 15 August 2006, Starlight issued proceedings in the Commercial Court against various insurers.
The insurers were divided into two groups: the Company Market Insurers (CMI) and the Lloyds Market Insurers (LMI).
The 2006 proceedings were settled between Starlight and the insurers before the hearing.
The proceedings were stayed by way of a Tomlin Order.
In April 2011, nine sets of Greek proceedings were issued by Starlight.
The Greek proceedings were expressed as torts actionable in Greece.
The insurers sought to enforce the earlier settlement agreements.
Starlight applied for a stay of the Greek proceedings under Article 28 of Regulation (EC) No 44/2001.
The judge refused to grant a stay under Article 28 and gave summary judgment to the insurers.
The Court of Appeal held that the Greek proceedings should be stayed under Article 27.
The Court of Appeal concluded that Article 27 provides for a mandatory stay.
The Supreme Court was asked to review the correctness of the Court of Appeal's conclusion under Article 27.
The insurers challenged the correctness of the Court of Appeal's conclusion under Article 27.
Starlight cross-appealed on the Article 28 point.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeals of the CMIs and LMIs.
Lord Clarke gave the lead judgment, with which Lord Sumption and Lord Hughes agreed.
Lord Neuberger agreed with the result, adding a short judgment of his own.
Lord Mance agreed with the result.
Article 27 must be construed in its context.
The purpose of Article 27 is to prevent inconsistent judgments between Member States.
The essential question is whether the claims in England and Greece are mirror images of each other.
The claims in England are contractual, while the Greek claims are in tort.
The factual bases for the two claims are entirely different.
The object of the two claims is different.
uksc-2012-0247: The appeals concern extradition requests under European arrest warrants (EAWs).
The Lithuanian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Mindaugas Bucnys based on a conviction for housebreaking and fraud.
The Lithuanian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Marius Sakalis based on a conviction for sexual assaults.
The Estonian Ministry of Justice issued an EAW for Dimitri Lavrov based on a conviction for murder.
EAWs are intended to meet the requirements of Council Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA on surrender procedures between EU member states.
Part 1 of the United Kingdom Extradition Act 2003 was enacted to give effect to the same requirements as the Framework Decision.
Section 2(7) of the 2003 Act requires EAW requests to be certified by the Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA).
The National Crime Agency (NCA) is the designated authority under section 2(8) of the 2003 Act.
The appeals raise questions about whether the EAW requests were the product of a judicial decision by a judicial authority.
The appeals also question whether the ministries issuing the EAWs had the function of issuing domestic arrest warrants.
The appeals ask whether the ministries were incorrectly certified by SOCA under section 2(7) of the 2003 Act.
The Divisional Court answered the first question affirmatively and the second negatively.
The Divisional Court concluded that a ministry of justice could be considered a judicial authority if it was sufficiently independent of the executive.
The Divisional Court held that the antecedent process, such as a request from the court responsible for the conviction, was relevant.
The Divisional Court found that the EAWs issued by the Lithuanian Ministry for Mr. Bucnys and Mr. Sakalis were valid.
The Divisional Court found that the EAW issued by the Estonian Ministry for Mr. Lavrov was invalid.
Mr. Bucnys and Mr. Sakalis appealed the Divisional Court's decision.
The Estonian Ministry appealed the Divisional Court's decision in Mr. Lavrov's case.
Further evidence was adduced during the appeal about the legal position and procedures in Lithuania and Estonia.
Mr. Bucnys has died since the hearing.
The Supreme Court unanimously held that the arrest warrants issued for Mr. Bucnys and Mr. Lavrov were valid.
The Supreme Court held that the arrest warrant issued for Mr. Sakalis was not valid.
Mr. Bucnys' appeal is dismissed.
Mr. Sakalis' appeal and the Estonian Ministry's appeal in Mr. Lavrov's case are allowed.
The Supreme Court held that member states were not intended to define judicial authority arbitrarily.
The concept of judicial authority is embedded in European Union law.
The Framework Decision is based on Article 31(1)(a) of the former Treaty of European Union.
The Framework Decision distinguishes between ministries and judicial authorities.
The Framework Decision aims to ensure objectivity and reduce political or executive influence in decision-making.
An EAW issued by a ministry can be regarded as issued by a judicial authority if it is issued at the request of a court responsible for the sentence.
uksc-2012-0249: The proceedings involve three sets of claims related to the deaths of three British servicemen and serious injuries of two others in Iraq.
The Challenger claims involve a friendly fire incident that caused the death of Cpl Stephen Allbutt and serious injuries to Lance Cpl Daniel Twiddy and Tpr Andrew Julien.
The Challenger claims allege failures by the Ministry of Defence to properly equip the tanks and provide adequate recognition training.
The Snatch Land Rover claims involve the deaths of Pte Phillip Hewett and Pte Lee Ellis due to improvised explosive devices detonating at their level.
The claimants in the Snatch Land Rover claims argue that the MoD breached the implied positive obligation under Article 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
The Ellis negligence claim is brought by Courtney Ellis and alleges various failures by the MoD.
The MoD argued that the Snatch Land Rover claims should be struck out because the deceased were not within the UK's jurisdiction under the Convention.
The MoD also argued that the Challenger and Ellis claims should be struck out due to combat immunity and fairness considerations.
The High Court and Court of Appeal ruled that the Snatch Land Rover claims should be struck out due to lack of jurisdiction and no duty under Article 2.
The High Court and Court of Appeal allowed the Challenger and Ellis claims to proceed to trial.
The Supreme Court considered whether the deceased in the Snatch Land Rover claims were within the UK's jurisdiction under the Convention.
The Supreme Court held that Pte Hewett and Pte Ellis were within the UK's jurisdiction for the purposes of the Convention at the time of their deaths.
The Supreme Court ruled that the Snatch Land Rover claims should not be struck out under Article 2 of the Convention.
The Supreme Court also ruled that the Challenger and Ellis claims should not be struck out on the grounds of combat immunity or fairness.
The effect of the Supreme Court's decision is that all three sets of claims may proceed to trial.
The Al Skeini case established that extra territorial jurisdiction can exist when a state exercises authority and control over an individual.
The European Court of Human Rights indicated that Convention rights can be tailored to the circumstances of extra territorial acts.
The Court acknowledged that the UK exercises authority and control over its armed forces, thereby extending jurisdiction to local inhabitants.
The Court emphasized that the margin of appreciation should be given to the state in determining the scope of Article 2 obligations.
The Court noted that policy decisions at a high level and battlefield actions fall outside the scope of Article 2.
The Court stated that whether claims fall under Article 2 requires judgment based on the facts of each case.
The Court acknowledged that the claims provide only brief outlines and predate relevant case law on Article 2.
The Court emphasized that the circumstances of decisions must be inquired into to determine if there was a breach of Article 2.
The Court noted that it is unclear whether the claimants can demonstrate a breach of Article 2.
The Court held that the doctrine of combat immunity should be narrowly construed and not extended beyond its established scope.
The Challenger claims are not within the scope of combat immunity as they relate to decisions not directly connected to active operations.
The Ellis negligence claim is less clearly outside the scope of combat immunity and may be within it.
The Court stated that it would be premature to strike out the claims without further evidence.
The Court acknowledged that the circumstances of active operations vary and cannot be grouped under a single risk.
The Court considered whether it would be fair, just, and reasonable to impose a duty of care on the MoD in the context of the claims.
uksc-2015-0214: B is a British national who is now aged 7.
The Respondent is B's biological mother and is a British national of Pakistani ethnicity.
The Appellant is a British national of Indian ethnicity and was previously in a same-sex relationship with the Respondent.
The Appellant has strong claims to be described as a mother of B.
The couple lived in England and set up home together but never became civil partners.
The couple received IUI treatment as a couple.
The Respondent gave birth to B in April 2008.
The Respondent undertook most of B's care.
The Appellant also helped care for B.
The couple took B out on weekends, including visits to family members.
The relationship between the Appellant and the Respondent broke down acrimoniously in December 2011.
The Appellant left the family home in December 2011.
The Respondent progressively reduced the Appellant's contact with B over the next two years.
The Appellant objected to the reduction in contact and suggested mediation.
The Respondent decided to move with B to Pakistan.
The Respondent moved to Pakistan with B on 3 February 2014.
The Appellant did not consent to B's removal to Pakistan.
The removal of B to Pakistan was lawful.
The Appellant applied for orders under the Children Act 1989 on 13 February 2014.
The Appellant's application depended on showing that B was habitually resident in England on 13 February 2014.
The Appellant also applied for orders under the court's inherent jurisdiction to have B made a ward of court and returned to England.
Hogg J held that the English court had no jurisdiction to determine the Appellant's 1989 Act application because B had lost her habitual residence on 3 February 2014.
Hogg J also held that the inherent jurisdiction should only be exercised in dire and exceptional circumstances, which were not present in this case.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the Appellant's appeal in July 2014.
The Appellant appeals to the Supreme Court regarding both applications.
The Supreme Court allows the appeal on the Appellant's 1989 Act application by a majority of 3:2.
Lord Clarke and Lord Sumption dissented in the Supreme Court decision.
Lord Wilson gives the lead judgment in the Supreme Court decision.
The Supreme Court concluded that B remained habitually resident in England on 13 February 2014.
The Supreme Court states that the English concept of habitual residence should be governed by the CJEU's criterion of some degree of integration by the child in a social and family environment.
uksc-2009-0180: The appeal concerns whether UK courts must consider the proportionality of evicting an occupier from their home under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
Most residential occupiers of local authority properties are secure tenants under Part IV of the Housing Act 1985.
Secure tenants under the Housing Act 1985 can only be evicted pursuant to the grounds in section 84 of the Act.
The Anti Social Behaviour Act 2003 allows courts to remove the security of tenure by making a demotion order.
A demoted tenancy lasts for a year and reverts to a secure tenancy unless possession proceedings are brought under section 143D of the Housing Act 1996.
Section 143D(2) of the Housing Act 1996 requires the court to make an order for possession unless it determines that the procedure under sections 143E and 143F has not been followed.
Before issuing possession proceedings against a demoted tenant, the landlord must serve a notice informing the tenant of its decision to seek possession and the reasons for it.
The Appellant, Cleveland Pinnock, is a demoted tenant who contests a possession order made under section 143D.
Mr. Pinnock has lived in the property owned by Manchester City Council for over 30 years with his partner and some of their children.
The demotion order was based on incidents of anti-social behaviour by Mr. Pinnock's family members.
The Council served a notice under section 143E citing further anti-social behaviour by Mr. Pinnock's sons after the demotion order.
A review under section 143F upheld the Council's possession notice.
The Council issued a claim for possession in the Manchester County Court.
The County Court granted an order for possession of the property.
Mr. Pinnock appealed to the Court of Appeal, which dismissed his appeal.
Mr. Pinnock then appealed to the Supreme Court.
Mr. Pinnock's main contention is that the possession order violates his right to respect for his home under Article 8.
The previous line of House of Lords authorities rejected Mr. Pinnock's Article 8 arguments, stating that courts could not review the Council's decision for proportionality.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr. Pinnock's appeal but for different reasons than the County Court and Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court concluded that courts must have the power to assess the proportionality of evicting a person from their home under Article 8.
The Court emphasized that this conclusion applies only to possession claims by local authorities, not private landlords.
The Court identified four issues to be considered in the appeal, including the compatibility of the demoted tenancy regime with the Convention.
The Court noted that Article 8 only applies when a person's home is involved.
The Court stated that proportionality of seeking possession is only considered if raised by the occupier.
The Court emphasized that an article 8 defence should be considered summarily.
The Court noted that article 8 may justify granting an extended period for possession, suspending an order, or refusing an order altogether.
The Court concluded that section 143D(2) can be interpreted to allow courts to review the proportionality of a landlord's decision to seek possession.
The Court stated that County Court judges have the jurisdiction to carry out an article 8 proportionality review under section 7(1) of the Human Rights Act.
The Court concluded that the demoted tenancy regime is compatible with the Convention.
The Court found that the possession order against Mr. Pinnock was proportionate and should be upheld.
uksc-2010-0106: Mr Tariq was employed as an immigration officer with the Home Office until 2006.
Mr Tariq was suspended and his security clearance withdrawn in 2006.
The arrest of Mr Tariq's brother and cousin was related to an investigation into a suspected terrorist plot.
Mr Tariq's cousin was convicted in 2008 of offences related to the suspected terrorist plot.
No information suggested that Mr Tariq was involved in any terrorism plot.
Mr Tariq claimed direct and indirect discrimination on grounds of race and religion in employment tribunal proceedings.
The Home Office denied the allegations and stated its decisions were based on Mr Tariq's association with suspected terrorists.
Section 10(6) of the Employment Tribunals Act 1996 allows the Secretary of State to make regulations for closed material procedures.
Rule 54(2) of Schedule 1 to the Employment Tribunals (Constitution and Rules of Procedure) Regulations 2004 provides for closed material procedures.
Schedule 2 of the Regulations provides for the use of special advocates in closed material procedures.
The Employment Tribunal ordered a closed material procedure, excluding Mr Tariq and his representatives from certain proceedings.
Mr Tariq appealed the order to the Employment Appeal Tribunal, which dismissed the appeal.
The Court of Appeal declared that Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights required the provision of a gist to Mr Tariq.
The Home Office appealed to the Supreme Court against the Court of Appeal's declaration.
Mr Tariq cross-appealed against the conclusion that a closed material procedure was permissible.
The Supreme Court allowed the Home Office's appeal and set aside the Court of Appeal's declaration requiring a gist.
Lord Kerr dissented in the Supreme Court's decision.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr Tariq's cross appeal, finding the closed material procedure compatible with Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights and EU law.
The cross appeal concerned whether the closed material procedure provisions were contrary to EU law or the European Convention on Human Rights.
EU law requires national law to provide effective legal protection of EU law rights, including the right not to be discriminated against on grounds of race or religion.
The European Court of Justice looks to the European Court of Human Rights for guidance on national security-related procedures.
The European Court of Human Rights established in Kennedy v UK that national security may justify a system where a claimant cannot know the secret material against them.
The Supreme Court held that the closed material procedure was necessary to protect the integrity of security vetting.
The closed material procedure contained sufficient safeguards through the use of special advocates.
The Supreme Court held that the closed material procedure was lawful and the cross appeal must be dismissed.
The Home Office's appeal concerned whether a claimant must be able to see allegations against them in sufficient detail to challenge them effectively.
The Supreme Court held that there is no absolute requirement for a claimant to see allegations in sufficient detail under Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
The European Court of Human Rights requires a gist in cases involving the liberty of the subject.
In cases not involving liberty, the Supreme Court found that the closed material procedure did not impair the essence of the right to a fair trial.
Lord Kerr dissented, arguing that withholding information from a claimant constitutes a breach of their fundamental common law right to a fair trial.
uksc-2012-0143: Mr OBrien was investigated in 2009 for involvement in a large scale boiler room fraud scheme.
A restraint order under section 41 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 was issued against Mr OBrien on 24 September 2009.
The restraint order required Mr OBrien to disclose his assets and return to England and Wales within 21 days.
The restraint order included a penal notice warning Mr OBrien of potential contempt of court if he disobeyed the order.
Mr OBrien disobeyed the restraint order and fled to the United States.
On 18 December 2009, the Common Serjeant found Mr OBrien in contempt and issued a bench warrant for his arrest.
Mr OBrien was traced to Chicago and the Serious Fraud Office sought his extradition to face fraud charges.
Mr OBrien consented to his extradition on 8 October 2010.
The SFO applied to the Common Serjeant to set aside the bench warrant, which was granted on 18 November 2010.
Mr OBrien was returned to the UK on 2 December 2010 and was arrested.
Mr OBrien was charged with various fraud offences and remanded in custody.
The SFO re-applied to the Common Serjeant for Mr OBrien's committal for contempt after reviewing its concerns.
Mr OBrien challenged the court's jurisdiction to hear the contempt application.
The Common Serjeant and the Court of Appeal rejected Mr OBrien's challenge to the court's jurisdiction.
Mr OBrien appealed to the Supreme Court on two grounds regarding the specialty principle and contempt of court.
Mr OBrien argued that his contempt satisfied the definition of an extradition offence under section 148 of the Extradition Act 2003.
Mr OBrien also argued that his contempt constituted a criminal contempt, which would fall under the specialty principle.
The Supreme Court dismissed Mr OBrien's appeal.
Lord Toulson delivered the judgment of the Supreme Court.
The Court held that section 151A of the Extradition Act 2003 does not directly apply to this case.
The Court emphasized that sections 148 and 151A should be read in the context of the entire Extradition Act 2003.
The Court stated that an extradition offence must be a criminal offence under the law of the requesting state.
The Court distinguished between civil and criminal contempt, noting that civil contempt is not a criminal offence.
The Court held that Mr OBrien's contempt of court was civil in nature and did not constitute an extradition offence.
The Court noted that the specialty principle does not bar the court from dealing with Mr OBrien for civil contempt.
The Extradition Act 2003 replaced the 1989 Act to implement an EU Framework Decision on extradition.
The Framework Decision requires that an arrest warrant be based on conduct that constitutes a criminal offence under the requesting state's law.
The definition of an extradition offence under Part 1 of the Extradition Act 2003 includes conduct punishable under UK law.
Section 148 of the Extradition Act 2003 does not apply to this case as the UK judiciary was not involved in the extradition process.
The Court emphasized that the nature and purpose of the restraint order, not the court that issued it, determine whether contempt is civil or criminal.
uksc-2009-0022: Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi is a Zimbabwean national.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi entered the UK lawfully but remained after his leave to remain expired.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was convicted of assault and sexual assault in 2005.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was sentenced to one year of imprisonment and ordered to be registered as a sex offender for five years.
A deportation order was made against Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi on 24 August 2007.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained under paragraph 2(2) of Schedule 3 to the Immigration Act 1971 on 7 March 2006.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained under paragraph 2(3) of Schedule 3 to the Immigration Act 1971 after the deportation order was made.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was detained for a total of 27 months until 13 June 2008.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi was granted bail on 13 June 2008.
Shepherd Masimba Kambadzi has not yet been returned to Zimbabwe due to conditions in that country.
The common law recognizes limits on the power to detain under paragraphs 2(2) and (3) of Schedule 3 to the Immigration Act 1971.
The Respondent had a policy detailing how the power to detain foreign nationals was to be exercised.
The policy required that all reasonable alternatives to detention must be considered before detention was authorized.
The policy required that detention be subject to regular reviews.
The policy specified the frequency of reviews and the grade of official required to conduct them.
The policy required the Appellant's detention to be reviewed five times in the first month and then monthly thereafter.
The Appellant's detention was not reviewed in accordance with the policy.
By the date of the first instance hearing, the Appellant was entitled to 22 monthly reviews of his detention.
The Appellant's detention was reviewed only ten times by the date of the first instance hearing.
Only six of the ten reviews were conducted by officials of the required seniority.
Two of the six reviews conducted by officials of the required seniority were flawed by material errors of fact.
The substantive requirements for detaining the Appellant were met throughout his detention.
The Appellant raised a judicial review seeking a declaration that he was unlawfully detained and damages.
Munby J granted a declaration that the Appellant was unlawfully detained for about 19 months.
The Court of Appeal allowed the Secretary of State's appeal and held that the Appellant's detention was lawful throughout.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal and held that the Appellant's detention was unlawful for periods without proper reviews.
The Supreme Court held that the Appellant has a claim in tort for false imprisonment for the unlawful periods.
The Supreme Court rejected the argument that procedural breaches do not affect the legality of detention.
The policy was sufficiently related to the authority to detain to qualify the Secretary of State's discretion.
The Court held that the failure to conduct required reviews resulted in the Appellant's detention being unlawful.
uksc-2013-0161: Ms Mirga is an EU national born in Poland.
Ms Mirga lived in the UK with her parents for four years before moving back in 2004.
The benefit rights of Polish nationals in the UK were governed by the A8 Regulations.
The A8 Regulations were enacted to give effect to the Treaty on Accession 2003.
Ms Mirga worked for seven months under the A8 Regulations after finishing her education in 2005.
Ms Mirga did three months of unregistered work after becoming pregnant.
Ms Mirga claimed income support in August 2006.
The Income Support Regulations governed her claim for income support.
The Secretary of State refused Ms Mirga's application for income support.
The First tier Tribunal upheld the Secretary of State's decision.
The Upper Tribunal affirmed the Secretary of State's decision.
The Court of Appeal affirmed the Secretary of State's decision.
The Court of Appeal's decision was based on Ms Mirga not having a right of residence under the A8 Regulations.
Mr Samin is an EU national born in Iraq.
Mr Samin was granted asylum in Austria in 1992.
Mr Samin was granted Austrian citizenship in 1993.
Mr Samin came to the UK in December 2005 and has lived there alone since then.
The benefit rights of EU nationals not covered by the A8 Regulations are governed by the EEA Regulations.
Mr Samin applied for housing assistance under the Housing Act 1996 in 2010.
The Council decided Mr Samin was not eligible for housing assistance because he did not have the right of residence under the EEA Regulations.
The Central London County Court upheld the Council's decision.
The Court of Appeal upheld the Council's decision.
The Supreme Court dismissed both Ms Mirga's and Mr Samin's appeals.
The Secretary of State argued Ms Mirga was ineligible for income support due to not meeting the 12-month employment requirement.
The Council argued Mr Samin was not a worker under the EEA Regulations due to not working for 12 months.
Ms Mirga argued her right to family and private life under the ECHR and her right of residence under TFEU were infringed.
Mr Samin argued his refusal of housing assistance was unlawful discrimination under TFEU.
Ms Mirga also argued that the Income Support Regulations could only apply if providing support was not disproportionate.
Mr Samin also argued that the refusal of housing assistance could only be justified if it was not disproportionate.
The Supreme Court concluded that the domestic Regulations did not infringe the appellants' TFEU rights.
uksc-2013-0057: The appeal is from Guernsey, where there is no equivalent of the 2006 Act.
The common laws of England and Guernsey are agreed to be identical in this area.
The principal issue is whether the reasoning in Barker still applies in Guernsey.

The reasoning in Barker may mean that an employers liability insurer covering an employer for only part of the period during which the employer exposed a victim is liable for only a pro rata part of the employer's liability to the victim.
A second principal issue is whether, if Barker does not apply, an insurer is liable in the first instance for the whole of the employer's liability to the victim.

A third principal issue is whether the insurer has pro rata rights to contribution from any other insurer of that employer and/or from the employer in respect of any periods not covered by the insurer.
There are parallel issues regarding such an insurer's responsibility for defence costs incurred in meeting the victim's claim.
Mr Carr was negligently and consistently exposed to asbestos dust by his employer from 1961 to 1988.
Mr Carr later contracted mesothelioma, from which he died.
Before his death, Mr Carr sued the Respondent, as successor in title of GGLCL, and recovered compensation of £250,000 damages and interest.
Mr Carr also recovered £15,300 towards his costs.
The Respondent also incurred defence costs of £13,151.60.
During the 27 years of exposure, GGLCL had two identifiable liability insurances.
One of the insurances was with Excess Insurance Co Ltd for two years from 1978 to 1980.
The other insurance was with Midland Assurance Ltd for six years from 1982 to 1988.
The Appellant, Zurich, as successor to Midlands liabilities, claims it is only liable to meet 22.08% of IEG's loss and defence costs.
Zurich's claim is based on the fact that Midland only insured GGLCL for 6/27ths of the 27-year period of exposure.
The trial judge ordered Zurich to meet 22.08% of the compensation but 100% of defence costs.
The Court of Appeal ordered Zurich to pay 100% of both the compensation and defence costs.
Zurich appeals in relation to both compensation and defence costs.
The Supreme Court unanimously holds that the common law rule of proportionate recovery established in Barker continues to apply in Guernsey.
The Supreme Court allows Zurich's appeal in respect of compensation.
The Supreme Court dismisses the appeal in relation to defence costs.
The judges' order is therefore restored.
The other issues do not arise in these circumstances, but the Supreme Court states its opinion on them.

By a majority of 4 to 3, the Court concludes that, had Guernsey had an equivalent to the 2006 Act, Zurich would have been liable in the first instance to meet IEG's claim in respect of the compensation paid by IEG in full.
The majority holds that Zurich has equitable rights to contribution pro rata from any other insurer able to contribute and, in respect of any period where there is no such insurer, from IEG itself.
The minority considers that Zurich is only liable to IEG in the first instance for 22.08% of the full loss.
Lord Mance's judgment discusses the position under the Third Party (Rights against Insurers) Act 1930 had IEG been insolvent.
Lord Mance concludes that it is probable that Mr Carr would have been able to look to Zurich for his full 100% loss in such a case.
uksc-2014-0087: The Claimant entered the Respondent's premises in Small Heath, Birmingham on 15 March 2008.
The premises included a petrol station and a kiosk where customers pay for their purchases.
The Claimant parked his car and entered the kiosk to ask if he could print documents from a USB stick.
Mr Amjid Khan was behind the kiosk desk, employed by the Respondent.
Mr Khan's job was to ensure the petrol pumps and kiosk were in good order and to serve customers.
Mr Khan refused the Claimant's request in a rude manner.
The Claimant protested Mr Khan's refusal.
Mr Khan responded in foul, racist, and threatening language.
Mr Khan ordered the Claimant to leave the premises.
The Claimant returned to his car, followed by Mr Khan.
Before the Claimant could drive off, Mr Khan opened the passenger door.
Mr Khan told the Claimant in threatening words never to return.
Mr Khan punched the Claimant on the left temple.
The Claimant got out of his car and walked around to close the passenger door.
Mr Khan subjected the Claimant to a serious attack.
The Claimant had not done anything aggressive or abusive.
The Claimant brought proceedings against the Respondent for vicarious liability for Mr Khan's actions.
The trial judge dismissed the claim, finding insufficient connection between Mr Khan's job and his conduct.
The Court of Appeal upheld the trial judge's decision.
The Claimant appealed, challenging the close connection test and arguing his claim should have succeeded.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the Claimant's appeal.
The Supreme Court held the Respondent vicariously liable for Mr Khan's actions.
Lord Toulson gave the lead judgment.
The close connection test has been followed at the highest level.
The close connection test is not flawed in itself.
The court must consider the nature of Mr Khan's job and the connection between his employment and his wrongful conduct.
Mr Khan's job included interacting with customers and responding to their inquiries.
Mr Khan's conduct in responding to the Claimant with abuse was inexcusable but within his field of activities.
The sequence of events after Mr Khan left the counter was continuous.
Mr Khan's actions were part of his employment duties as he was acting on behalf of his employer.
uksc-2012-0025: Lord Reed questions whether the approach taken by the courts below and the parties' printed cases is correct.
Lord Reed concludes that the case concerns a continuing representation capable of remaining in effect until the contract is concluded.
The representation in the critical email was of a continuing nature as long as Mr. Erskine remained the prospective contracting party.
A representation may continue to be asserted and have a causative effect even if the contracting parties are not the original representor and representee.
The parties' conduct indicates they proceeded with negotiations on the basis that the representation continued to be asserted after the identity of the prospective contracting party changed.
The representation could continue to have a causative effect, inducing the conclusion of the contract.
If a representation continues to be made until the contract is concluded, the risk of harm from reliance on it remains foreseeable.
The representor may be taken to have assumed responsibility for the accuracy of the representation towards the contracting party who relied on it.
A representation made by a company's agent prior to the commencement of his agency may have the same effect if the person to whom it is addressed becomes the agent of the contracting party.
The negotiations continued after it became apparent that an LLP would be used as the vehicle for Mr. Erskine's investment.
Neither party drew a line under previous discussions, disclaimed what had been said, or sought assurance that the statements could be relied upon as between the contracting parties.
The respondents implicitly asserted the accuracy of the representation to Cramaso by continuing and concluding negotiations with Cramaso through Mr. Erskine.
It continued to be foreseeable that the representation would induce the other party to enter into a contract.
The respondents assumed a responsibility towards Cramaso for the accuracy of the representation and owed it a duty of care.
The respondents failed to fulfill their duty of care towards Cramaso.
Cramaso is entitled to recover damages for any loss suffered as a result of the representation.
Cramaso is entitled to recover damages under section 10 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Scotland) Act 1985.
In a concurring judgment, Lord Toulson rejects the respondents' argument that Cramaso must show Mr. Lewis knew or ought to have known Mr. Erskine would rely on the email.
The situation where a statement is made by one party to another, who relies on it in entering a contract with a third party, is different from the present situation.
Lord Toulson agrees with Lord Reed that the representation being negligent rather than fraudulent does not affect its continuing nature.
What matters is the continuing potency of the representation as an inducing factor.
The case will return to the Court of Session for further procedure in relation to remedies.
The case involves a situation where a statement was made during contractual negotiations by one prospective party to another in relation to the transaction they were negotiating.
The representation was made by one prospective party to another during the negotiations.
The representation was relied upon by the other party in the negotiations.
The representation was made in the context of the transaction being negotiated.
The representation was made by one party to another during the negotiations.
The representation was made by a prospective party to another.
uksc-2014-0094: A patient who was clinically asymptomatic requested a heart screen from his GP on 30 May 2008.
The GP referred the patient for an electrocardiogram (ECG) test in July 2008.
The ECG test reported negative for ischaemic heart disease, and no further action was taken.
The patient complained of chest pain to a locum doctor on 10 December 2008.
The GP referred the patient to a chest pain clinic 5 days after the chest pain complaint.
The chest pain clinic declined to see the patient due to his earlier negative test.
The clinic sent a report to the practice on 20 December 2008, which was not marked urgent or reviewed.
The patient attended the practice again on 6 January 2009 to inquire about an appointment.
The GP referred the patient for another ECG, but the patient died of a myocardial infarction later that day.
The patient's widow complained to the Northern Ireland Commissioner for Complaints.
The Commissioner held that the practice had failed to provide a reasonable level of care and treatment.
The Commissioner found the practice guilty of maladministration.
The Commissioner recommended that the GP make a payment of £10,000 to the widow.
The GP refused to make the payment.
The Commissioner indicated he would lay a special report before the Northern Ireland Assembly.
The Commissioner's recommendation was upheld at first instance but quashed by the Court of Appeal.
The Commissioner appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The Supreme Court held that the Commissioner had no power to recommend a monetary payment against a non-public authority.
The Commissioner's power to investigate was derived from Article 8 of the 1996 Order.
The Commissioner could not recommend monetary redress unless it was not reasonable to expect the complainant to resort to court.
The widow had a legal remedy but the Commissioner proceeded with the investigation because she wanted to find out what had gone wrong.
The Commissioner could not recommend a payment after proceeding with the investigation on that basis.
The Commissioner does not have the power to make a special report in default of payment.
The Commissioner's relationship with the legislature is different from that of other statutory ombudsmen.
The Commissioner is not an officer of the legislature and has no powers of compulsion.
Article 19 of the 1996 Order is concerned with annual reports, not individual case reports.
Lord Sumption commented that the monetary recommendation lacked rational explanation.
The figure of £10,000 was not supported by a coherent explanation or calculation.
The Commissioner's recommendation did not identify the precise failings in the case.
uksc-2012-0181: AA was born in Somalia on 21 August 1994.
AA's father was killed in the mid 1990s.
AA became separated from her mother and other siblings during the fighting in Somalia.
AA went to live with her brother-in-law, Mohamed, around the end of 2002.
Mohamed had a daughter named Fadima and a step-daughter named Amaani.
Mohamed took AA into his family home under the Islamic legal procedure known as Kafala.
Kafala is described as a process of legal guardianship akin to adoption.
Mohamed left Somalia and arrived in the UK in November 2007.
Mohamed was granted asylum on 21 July 2008.
The three girls, AA, Fadima, and Amaani, were left with a maternal aunt in Mogadishu.
An application for entry into the UK was made for all three girls.
Entry clearance was granted to Fadima and Amaani who came to the UK in January 2010.
Entry clearance was refused for AA, who remained in Addis Ababa pending her appeal.
AA's appeal was heard in the First tier Tribunal (FTT) on 3 September 2010.
The FTT allowed the appeal under paragraph 352D and article 8 ECHR.
The Secretary of State appealed the FTT's decision.
The Upper Tribunal (UT) allowed the Secretary of State's appeal in respect of paragraph 352D.
The UT confirmed the FTT's decision under article 8 ECHR.
The Court of Appeal confirmed the UT's decision on 2 May 2012.
AA was given entry clearance on 14 May 2012 and arrived in the UK on 4 June 2012.
AA appeals to the Supreme Court in respect of paragraph 352D of the Immigration Rules.
The Supreme Court dismissed AA's appeal.
Lord Carnwath gave the lead judgment, with which Lady Hale, Lord Wilson, Lord Reed, and Lord Hughes agreed.
The correct approach to construction of the rules was explained by Lord Brown in Mahed v Entry Clearance Officer [2010] 1 WLR 48.
Paragraph 352D does not cover AA's case and cannot be rewritten to do so.
The definition of adoptive parent in paragraph 6 is more restricted and extends only to de facto adoption within the limitations of paragraph 309A.
