Paragraph 309A does not cover AA's case.
International instruments call for a broad approach to the protection of children's interests.
The best interests principle is recognised by both domestic and international law.
There is no specific international obligation covering AA's position.
uksc-2012-0162: The case involves an appeal concerning the interpretation of "earnings" in section 6(1) of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992.
The case focuses on whether payments made by FML to a Funded Unapproved Retirement Benefits Scheme count as earnings for NICs purposes.
The Funded Unapproved Retirement Benefits Scheme was established by FML on 11 April 2002 to provide benefits to its employees and directors.
Mr McHugh became a member of the scheme and requested that his wife be the beneficiary in the event of his death.
FML made an initial cash contribution of £1,000 and transferred Treasury Stock with a nominal value of £162,000 to the scheme for Mr McHugh's benefit.
Mr McHugh has not received any relevant benefits from the scheme as defined in section 612 of the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988.
Mr McHugh was 54 years old when the transfers were made, and FML specified his retirement age as his 60th birthday.
Mr McHugh controlled FML, allowing him to bring forward his retirement age for the purposes of the scheme.
The question was whether the transfers constituted payments of earnings to or for the benefit of Mr McHugh under section 6 of the 1992 Act.
HMRC initially decided that the transfers were payments of earnings and that FML was liable to pay Class 1 NICs on the value of the transfer.
FML's appeal to the Upper Tribunal was successful, but the Court of Appeal reinstated HMRC's decision.
FML appealed to the Supreme Court, and during the appeal, it accepted that earnings had a wider meaning than emoluments in income tax legislation.
FML argued that the payment of earnings under section 6 did not extend to the employer's transfer of funds or assets to a trust where the earner had only a contingent interest.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed FML's appeal.
Lord Hodge examined the legislative history of the UK's national insurance system, noting that NICs are levied on a basis different from emoluments in income tax.
Parliament chose the word "earnings" in the National Insurance Act 1946 instead of "emoluments," which courts have interpreted as referring to actual money payments or benefits in kind.
Lord Hodge referenced primary and subordinate legislation from 1911 and 1946 to show that earnings in NICs legislation include non-convertible benefits in kind, unless disregarded.
HMRC argued that earnings are paid to an earner both when assets are transferred to a pension scheme and when payments are made from the trust fund.
HMRC focused on the payment made, not on what the earner received, and considered the sum paid into the trust as part of Mr McHugh's remuneration.
Payments from the trust to Mr McHugh were also considered earnings, as they were payments in respect of his employment.
Lord Hodge found HMRC's interpretation counterintuitive, as it would imply that a person earns remuneration both when an employer pays into a trust and when the trust pays out.
Lord Hodge argued that HMRC's interpretation denudes the word "earnings" of any meaning, reducing the phrase to "payments are made."
Lord Hodge noted that HMRC's approach fails to consider the contingency of Mr McHugh's entitlement to the trust fund.
The hypothetical value of Mr McHugh's entitlement would be based on the value of his contingent right to the trust fund at his retirement age, not at the time of the transfer.
Lord Hodge concluded that the transfer to the trust was not the payment of earnings for the purposes of section 6(1).
The Supreme Court allowed FML's appeal and reinstated the judgment of the Upper Tribunal.
uksc-2009-0152: The Respondent was vaccinated on 3 November 1992 with a vaccine manufactured in France by Aventis Pasteur SA.
On 18 September 1992, Aventis Pasteur SA sent a consignment of the vaccine to its subsidiary, Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd.
Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd acted as a United Kingdom distributor for Aventis Pasteur SA's products.
Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd received the consignment on 22 September 1992.
Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd sold part of the consignment, including the Product, on an unknown date.
The Product was eventually used to vaccinate the Respondent.
On 1 August 2001, the Respondent began proceedings under section 2 of the Consumer Protection Act 1987 against Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd.
On 16 October 2002, the Respondent issued separate proceedings against Aventis Pasteur SA under section 2 of the Consumer Protection Act 1987.
Aventis Pasteur SA defended the action by relying on section 11(3) of the Limitation Act 1980 and Article 11 of Council Directive 85/374/EEC.
Article 11 provides a ten-year time limit for initiating proceedings against the producer of a product.
Aventis Pasteur SA argued that the action was brought more than ten years after the Product was put into circulation.
The Respondent sought an order to substitute Aventis Pasteur SA as a defendant in place of Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd.
The Respondent relied on section 35(5)(b) and (6)(a) of the Limitation Act 1980 to seek substitution.
Aventis Pasteur SA contended that English law's substitution after the expiry of the time limit was inconsistent with Article 11.
The High Court made a preliminary reference to the European Court of Justice.
The House of Lords could not reach a unanimous view on the effect of the European Court of Justice's judgment.
The House of Lords referred the question back to the European Court of Justice.
The European Court of Justice clarified that a producer cannot be sued after ten years if proceedings were not taken within that period.
The Respondent now accepts that section 35 of the Limitation Act cannot be used to substitute Aventis Pasteur SA for Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd.
The Respondent submits that the European Court of Justice indicated a different basis for substitution.
The European Court of Justice suggested that a producer can be substituted if the domestic court finds that the product's circulation was determined by the producer.
The dispute turns on the interpretation of the European Court of Justice's judgment.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and set aside the order substituting Aventis Pasteur SA for Aventis Pasteur MSD Ltd.
Lord Rodger gave the judgment of the Court.
The European Court of Justice did not intend to depart from its earlier principled approach in its judgment.
The European Court of Justice followed the lead of the Advocate General in its additional guidance.
The Advocate General referred back to the European Court of Justice's earlier judgment on the definition of "put into circulation."
The European Court of Justice rejected an approach based on the formal legal relationship between the parent and subsidiary.
The national court must consider all links between the entities to determine if they are closely connected for the purposes of Article 11.
The European Court of Justice indicated that the domestic court should assess whether the manufacturer was controlling the subsidiary and determining when the product was put into circulation.
uksc-2012-0179: The United Kingdom failed to secure compliance with nitrogen dioxide levels in certain zones since 2010.
The Supreme Court referred questions to the Court of Justice of the European Union regarding the interpretation of Directive 2008/50/EC.
Article 13 of the Directive sets limit values for nitrogen dioxide that could not be exceeded from 1 January 2010.
Article 22 allows a member state to apply for a postponement of the compliance date for up to five years under certain conditions.
Article 23 requires member states to prepare air quality plans for areas where nitrogen dioxide limits are exceeded.
If the attainment deadline has expired, air quality plans must include measures to minimize the period of exceedance.
Air quality plans under Article 23 must include information on air pollution abatement measures, including those to limit transport emissions.
ClientEarth argued the UK was required to apply for postponement under Article 22 for all non-compliant zones.
The Secretary of State did not apply for postponement for some non-compliant zones and instead produced air quality plans predicting compliance by 2025.
The Secretary of State claimed it was not required to apply for postponement under Article 22.
The Supreme Court declared the UK in breach of Article 13 of the Directive.
The Supreme Court referred four questions to the CJEU regarding the interpretation of the Directive.
The CJEU answered the referred questions in a judgment dated 14 November 2014.
The Supreme Court ordered the UK government to submit new air quality plans to the European Commission by 31 December 2015.
The CJEU reformulated the first two questions referred by the Supreme Court.
The reformulation of the questions introduced ambiguity regarding whether the Secretary of State breached Article 22.
The CJEU stated that a compliant air quality plan under Article 23 does not automatically satisfy Article 13 obligations.
The CJEU ruled that national courts must ensure the required plan is established if a member state fails to comply with Article 13.
The CJEU judgment left no doubt about the seriousness of the UK's breach of Article 13.
The breach of Article 13 has been continuing for more than five years.
The prospects of early compliance with nitrogen dioxide limits have worsened over the five years.
The Secretary of State accepted that a new air quality plan must be prepared.
The Supreme Court emphasized the need for immediate action to address the breach of Article 13.
The new government must prepare air quality plans by 31 December 2015 to ensure compliance.
The requirements of Article 23(1) are no less onerous than those under Article 22.
The checklist of measures under paragraph 3 of Annex XV, section B, must be considered for compliance with either Article 22 or 23.
The court can impose requirements to ensure effective compliance with the Directive.
The CJEU judgment reinforces the national court's responsibility to secure compliance with the Directive.
The critical breach is of Article 13, not of Articles 22 or 23.
The CJEU judgment highlights the responsibility of the national court to address the ongoing breach of Article 13.
uksc-2017-0096: Mr Holden accidentally set fire to his car while repairing it at Phoenix Engineering's premises.
The fire caused £2 million in damage to Phoenix and its neighboring premises.
Phoenix's insurer, Axa, paid out the claim and agreed not to pursue Mr Holden personally.
Axa claims Mr Holden is covered by his car insurance policy's third party liability cover.
Churchill, Mr Holden's car insurance provider, disputes that he is covered under the policy.
Clause 1a of the policy states coverage applies if there is an accident involving the insured's vehicle and they injure someone or damage property.
The policy includes a certificate that satisfies the requirements of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (RTA).
Under the RTA, car insurance policies must cover liability for damage to property caused by or arising out of the use of a vehicle on a road or public place.
The High Court ruled that the policy did not cover Mr Holden's accident because it arose from the negligent repair, not from the use of the car.
The Court of Appeal allowed Mr Holden's appeal, finding the policy's wording inadequate and requiring it to be read with the certificate.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
Lord Hodge provided the only judgment in the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court held that the policy must be interpreted to meet the requirements of the RTA.
The certificate does not provide additional cover beyond the policy itself.
The Court of Appeal extended coverage to any accident involving Mr Holden's vehicle, which the Supreme Court found excessive.
The statutory term "use" in the RTA is interpreted broadly to include situations where the owner has control or operation of the vehicle on a road or public place.
Even a parked car may be considered a hazard on a road or public place under English case law.
The phrase "caused by, or arising out of, the use of the vehicle" extends coverage but must have a reasonable causal link.
In EU law, the concept of "use" extends to any use of a vehicle as a means of transport.
The RTA may need to be revised to comply with EU law, but it cannot be read down to remove the phrase "on a road or other public place."
The Supreme Court emphasized that the cover required by the RTA must be read into the policy.
The Court of Appeal's correction of the policy's wording extended coverage beyond the RTA's requirements.
The Supreme Court concluded that the necessary correction is to align the policy with the RTA's requirements without exceeding them.
The Supreme Court found that the CA's interpretation expanded coverage beyond the express terms of the policy and the RTA.
The Supreme Court determined that the accident did not fall under the policy's coverage as interpreted.
A vehicle being repaired on private property is not considered to be in use.
The property damage was caused by Mr Holden's alleged negligence in carrying out the repairs, not by the prior use of the car.
The damage did not arise out of the use of the car as a means of transport.
The Supreme Court rejected the argument that the statutory rule favoring consumers applies in this case.
The appropriate corrective construction is to read the clause to align with the RTA's requirements without extending coverage beyond them.
uksc-2018-0132: The compensation scheme was set up in 1999 by the Department for Trade and Industry.
The scheme provided compensation for miners with vibration white finger (VWF).
The scheme included payments for general damages and special damages.
Special damages could include a services award for domestic tasks.
The scheme used a presumption based on the severity of VWF for services awards.
Mr Arthur Watkins was employed by British Coal from 1964 to 1985.
Mr Watkins developed VWF by the early 1980s.
Mr Watkins instructed the appellant to act for him in 1999.
A medical examination and interview found Mr Watkins qualified for a services award.
Mr Watkins sought a services award under the scheme.
In 2003, Mr Watkins was offered a full and final settlement for general damages.
The appellant informed Mr Watkins of the offer on 18 February 2003.
Mr Watkins accepted the offer after a telephone conversation.
In 2008, Mr Watkins instructed new solicitors to claim professional negligence.
Mr Watkins died in 2014, and his daughter continued the claim.
The first instance court found the appellant's advice was negligent.
The court concluded Mr Watkins would have rejected the offer with proper advice.
A medical expert was instructed not to apply the scheme's presumption.
The expert concluded Mr Watkins' symptoms were insufficient for a services claim.
The court dismissed the claim, stating no loss was suffered.
The Court of Appeal overturned the dismissal, finding the trial judge erred.
The appellant seeks to appeal the Court of Appeal's decision.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal and remitted the case.
The court must assess the value of the lost opportunity to pursue the services claim.
The expert report was used to assess causation, not loss.
The expert was instructed not to apply the scheme's presumption.
The services claim would have proceeded under the scheme's procedures.
The scheme would not have commissioned a further medical report.
The court found the services claim had a real chance of success.
The first instance judge should have assessed the value of the lost claim.
uksc-2018-0131: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc filed patents for a new type of genetically modified mouse in 2001.
The hybrid mice combine a section of mouse genetic material with a section of human genetic material.
The resulting hybrid mice can produce antibodies suitable for medical treatment in humans.
The hybrid mice do not cause immunological sickness in the mouse.
Combining a human variable region with a mouse constant region was a major scientific contribution.
Hybrid mice developed by Regeneron had medical uses, including in the development of antibody therapies against coronavirus.
In 2013, Regeneron sued Kymab Ltd for patent infringement.
Kymab was producing genetically modified mice with a similar genetic structure to Regeneron's mice.
Kymab argued that Regeneron's 2001 patents were invalid due to insufficient detail.
The sufficiency requirement in patent law requires documents to be detailed enough for skilled readers to replicate the invention.
The Court of Appeal found that Regeneron's patents provided enough information to create one type of hybrid mouse.
The patents did not explain how to create a hybrid structure with the full human variable region genes.
A reliable method for incorporating the full human variable region into the mouse genome was not invented until 2011.
An expert in 2001 would have been unable to make many types of hybrid mice claimed by Regeneron.
The Court of Appeal upheld the patents, stating they reflected a principle of general application.
Kymab appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court allowed Kymab's appeal by a majority of four to one, holding the patents invalid.
Lord Briggs delivered the majority judgment in the Supreme Court case.
Lady Black provided a dissenting judgment in the Supreme Court case.
A patent is a bargain between the inventor and the public, granting a time-limited monopoly in exchange for public access to the invention.
Patent holders must publish enough information to enable a skilled person to make the invention.
The Court of Appeal believed Regeneron's invention had broader applications beyond the mice that could be made in 2001.
The Court of Appeal thought it unfair to limit Regeneron's monopoly to mice that could be made at the time of the patent filing.
Patentees must not make overly broad claims.
If a patent claims a range of products, it must disclose enough information to enable a skilled person to make the full range.
The amount of human genetic material affects the diversity of useful antibodies produced by the mice.
Mice with more human genetic material could not be made using Regeneron's patents.
Regeneron claimed a monopoly that was wider than its contribution to the field.
The Court of Appeal's analysis weakened the sufficiency requirement in patent law.
Lady Black agreed with the Court of Appeal's reasoning in her dissenting judgment.
uksc-2020-0042: The Airports National Policy Statement (ANPS) is the national policy framework governing the construction of a third runway at Heathrow Airport.
Any future application for development consent to build the third runway at Heathrow Airport will be considered against the ANPS.
The ANPS does not grant development consent in its own right.
Successive governments have considered whether there is a need for increased airport capacity in the South East of England.
The Secretary of State for Transport declared that the Government accepted the case for airport expansion in 2015.
The Secretary of State announced that the North West Runway (NWR) scheme was the preferred scheme in October 2016.
The UK signed the Paris Agreement under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change on 22 April 2016.
The UK ratified the Paris Agreement on 17 November 2016.
The Paris Agreement sets out targets for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, particularly carbon dioxide, and the reduction of temperature increases resulting from global warming.
Two Government ministers made statements about the Government's approach to the Paris Agreement in March 2016.
The Secretary of State designated the ANPS as national policy on 26 June 2018.
Objectors to the NWR scheme challenged the lawfulness of the Secretary of State's designation of the ANPS.
The Divisional Court dismissed all of the objectors' claims in two separate judgments.
The Court of Appeal upheld the main parts of the judgments but allowed some of the objectors' grounds.
The Court of Appeal held that the Secretary of State had acted unlawfully in failing to take the Paris Agreement into account when designating the ANPS.
The ANPS was declared of no legal effect due to the Court of Appeal's decision.
The Secretary of State does not appeal the Court of Appeal's decision.
Heathrow Airport Ltd (HAL) is a party to the proceedings and has been granted permission to appeal to the Supreme Court.
HAL has invested a large sum of money in promoting the NWR scheme and wishes to apply for development consent.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
The Court explained that Government policy in the context of section 5(8) of the Planning Act 2008 refers to carefully formulated written statements of policy.
The Court held that the March 2016 statements of Andrea Leadsom MP and Amber Rudd MP did not meet the minimum standard of Government policy.
International treaties such as the Paris Agreement do not constitute Government policy for the purposes of domestic law.
Section 1 of the Climate Change Act 2008 sets a national carbon target.
Section 4 of the Climate Change Act 2008 obliges the Government to establish carbon budgets for the UK.
The Court held that there was no established Government policy on climate change beyond that already reflected in the Climate Change Act 2008 at the time the ANPS was designated.
The Secretary of State must take into account the environmental, economic, and social objectives that make up sustainable development when designating national policy frameworks.
The Court dismissed FoEs argument that the Secretary of State failed to have proper regard to the Paris Agreement when designating the ANPS.
The Secretary of State took the Paris Agreement into account and ensured that its obligations were incorporated into the ANPS framework.
Future applications for development consent regarding the NWR scheme will be assessed against the emissions targets and environmental policies in force at that later date.
uksc-2011-0089: The appeals raise important issues in equity and trust law.
The appeals involve the rule in Hastings Bass concerning trustees' decision-making.
The appeal in Pitt involves the court's jurisdiction to set aside a voluntary disposition on the ground of mistake.
In 1985, Mr. Mark Futter made two settlements.
Initially, both settlements had non-resident trustees.
In 2004, Mr. Futter and Mr. Cutbill were appointed as resident trustees.
In 2008, Mr. Futter and Mr. Cutbill distributed the capital of the first settlement to Mr. Futter.
In 2008, Mr. Futter and Mr. Cutbill distributed 36,000 from the second settlement to Mr. Futter's three children.
The trustees overlooked the effect of section 2(4) of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992.
The distribution resulted in a large capital gains tax liability for Mr. Futter.
The distribution resulted in a modest capital gains tax liability for Mr. Futter's children.
Mr. Futter and Mr. Cutbill applied to have the deeds declared void.
Norris J held the deeds to be void based on the rule in Hastings Bass.
In 1990, Mr. Derek Pitt suffered serious head injuries resulting in mental incapacity.
Mr. Pitt's claim for damages was compromised by a court-approved settlement of 1.2 million.
Mr. Pitt's solicitors sought advice from Frankel Topping.
Frankel Topping advised that the damages should be settled in a discretionary settlement.
The Derek Pitt Special Needs Trust was established in 1994.
The SNT could have been established without inheritance tax liability.
The SNT was not established without inheritance tax liability.
The report from Frankel Topping made no reference to inheritance tax.
Mr. Pitt died in 2007.
His personal representatives commenced proceedings to have the SNT set aside.
The deputy judge ordered the SNT set aside based on the rule in Hastings Bass.
The deputy judge indicated that a mistake as to consequences was not sufficient for rescission.
The Revenues appealed against the decisions in the Court of Appeal.
Lloyd LJ allowed the appeals, stating the rule in Hastings Bass was not applicable.
Lloyd LJ dismissed Mrs. Pitt's appeal based on mistake.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal in Futter and the Pitt appeal related to Hastings Bass.
The Supreme Court allowed the Pitt appeal on the ground of mistake and set aside the SNT.
uksc-2011-0011: The HJ (Iran) principle was established in a previous court decision regarding a gay man's right to live openly.
The country guidance for Zimbabwe indicates a campaign of persecution by militias following the 2008 election.
The persecution in Zimbabwe targets individuals who cannot demonstrate support for Zanu PF or alignment with the regime.
The regime in Zimbabwe uses methods such as requiring a Zanu PF card or singing campaign songs to establish loyalty.
Inability to demonstrate loyalty through these methods is considered evidence of disloyalty and support for the opposition.
The regime in Zimbabwe has unleashed a campaign of violence, murder, destruction, rape, and displacement against its citizens.
RT, SM, and AM are individuals who claimed asylum in the UK from Zimbabwe between 2001 and 2008.
Each of RT, SM, and AM's asylum claims was initially refused.
RT was credible but had never been politically active.
SM was not a credible witness and had given inconsistent accounts of her involvement with the MDC.
SM had lied in several respects and was later found to have no connections with the MDC.
AM was not a credible witness and had no political profile prior to leaving Zimbabwe.
The Court of Appeal allowed the appeals of RT, SM, and AM based on the HJ (Iran) principle.
The HJ (Iran) principle covers cases where individuals are forced to lie about their absence of political beliefs to avoid persecution.
The second appeal concerns KM, who claimed asylum in the UK in 2008.
KM claimed to have arrived in the UK on a false South African passport.
KM's asylum claim was refused by the Tribunal.
KM's son had been granted asylum in the UK due to fears of persecution as an MDC sympathizer.
The Tribunal found KM had not established a sufficient factual basis for his asylum claim.
The Court of Appeal allowed KM's appeal, sending the case back for further decision.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the Home Secretary's appeals in the cases of RT, SM, and AM.
The Supreme Court allowed KM's appeal.
The HJ (Iran) principle applies to individuals who claim asylum due to a well-founded fear of persecution for lack of political belief.
The Refugee Convention provides equal protection for all reasons of persecution, including political beliefs.
The Convention affords no less protection to the right to express political opinion than to other fundamental rights.
The HJ (Iran) principle applies to any person who is obliged to conceal political beliefs to avoid persecution.
The right to freedom of thought, opinion, and expression protects both believers and non-believers.
There is no basis for treating political beliefs differently from religious beliefs under the Refugee Convention.
A politically neutral individual may still be at risk of persecution if imputed as a supporter of the regime.
An asylum claim based on imputed political opinion may succeed if there is a real risk of persecution for perceived disloyalty.
uksc-2011-0244: On 20 December 2010, the Financial Services Authority (FSA) applied for a freezing injunction against Sinaloa Gold and PH Capital Invest without notice.
The FSA alleged that both companies were involved in promoting the sale of shares in Sinaloa without proper authorisation and an approved prospectus.
The FSA also alleged that PH Capital Invest had breached FSMA in various other respects.
Schedule B to the injunction stated that the FSA gave no cross undertaking in damages.
Under Schedule B, the FSA undertook to cover both costs and losses incurred by third parties as a result of the injunction.
The undertaking in respect of third party losses was inadvertent.
The FSA applied to have the undertaking in respect of third party losses removed.
Barclays, with whom Sinaloa Gold plc had six bank accounts, intervened to oppose the application to remove the undertaking.
The application to have the undertaking removed was refused in the High Court.
The decision to refuse the application was reversed in the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal's decision preserved the undertaking in respect of third party costs but eliminated the undertaking in respect of third party losses.
Barclays appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
There is no general rule requiring an authority like the FSA to give a cross undertaking in respect of losses incurred by third parties.
The FSA is not required to give a cross undertaking in respect of losses on the facts of this case.
The judgment was given by Lord Mance.
A general distinction exists between private claims and law enforcement actions.
In private claims, a claimant is expected to give a cross undertaking in damages to the defendant(s) and third parties.
A cross undertaking in damages can be justified as a way to protect against unjustified injunctions causing harm.
In law enforcement actions, public authorities are not expected to back their legal actions with public funds.
Public authorities may be inhibited from fulfilling their duties if required to provide cross undertakings.
The position regarding cross undertakings does not differ based on whether it protects a defendant or a third party.
A cross undertaking covers loss caused by the grant of an injunction where the person incurring the loss is innocent.
A pragmatic distinction can be made between undertakings in respect of costs and damages.
Public authorities should be able to enforce the law without fear of cross claims or exposure of resources.
This applies more strongly to open-ended undertakings in respect of third party loss than to limited undertakings in respect of costs.
There are no special circumstances requiring the FSA to give a cross undertaking in respect of third party losses in this case.
The FSA does not assume responsibility or liability for breach of duty towards third parties in this case.
The FSA has a power under Part IV of the FSMA to freeze the assets of a permitted person without court application.
The FSA is excluded from liability in the exercise of its powers under Part IV of the FSMA by virtue of paragraph 19 of Schedule 1 to FSMA.
uksc-2014-0159: In June 2006, Hastings Borough Council restricted public access to Hastings Pier due to its dangerous condition caused by serious structural defects.
Manolete Partners PLC pursued a compensation claim against Hastings Borough Council for business losses resulting from the emergency closure of the pier.
Manolete brought the claim as an assignee of Stylus Sports Ltd, which went into liquidation in late 2011.
Stylus Sports Ltd leased two units from Ravenclaw Investments Incorporated on the Hastings Pier.
Stylus operated a bingo hall and amusement arcade within the leased units on the pier.
Two years before the pier's closure, Stylus commissioned a structural engineering survey that warned of urgent and future repairs needed to prevent public risk.
Ravenclaw, the freeholder and landlord of the pier, did not take action to fix the structural defects identified in the survey.
The Council also did not take action to address the structural defects, and the pier remained open to the public.
In April 2006, a section of tension cord fell from the pier, prompting the Council to attempt to compel Ravenclaw to act.
The Council commissioned its own structural integrity report in June 2006, which recommended immediate restrictions on public access to the pier.
The Council exercised its emergency powers under section 78 of the 1984 Act to restrict public access to the pier.
In September 2006, the Council obtained a court order under section 77 to prohibit public access to the pier until necessary repairs were completed.
Section 106 of the Building Act 1984 provides a right to compensation for business losses caused by the exercise of an authority's powers, provided the claimant is not in default.
The Council alleged that Stylus had breached the Occupiers Liability Act 1957 and the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974.
The Council sought to use these alleged breaches to establish that Stylus was in default, thereby barring compensation under the 1984 Act.
The Technology and Construction Court and the Court of Appeal rejected the Council's defence, stating that the reference to default was limited to obligations under the 1984 Act itself.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the Council's appeal.
Lord Carnwath delivered the judgment, with which the other justices agreed.
Section 106 of the 1984 Act requires identifying the matter related to the authority's exercise of powers and determining whether the claimant was in default.

The relevant power exercised by the Council was under section 78 of the 1984 Act, and the compensation claim was limited to the period from the emergency closure until the court order in September 2006.
The trigger for the Council's emergency action was the state of the pier combined with fears of possible collapse from crowd loading during planned events.
The trigger was not the general state of the pier or the specific repairs identified in the Stylus-commissioned report.
Stylus was not in default regarding the matter that led to the Council's exercise of its section 78 powers.
Manolete is entitled to succeed in its claim for compensation based on the lack of default by Stylus.
Lord Carnwath addressed whether default in section 106 is limited to default under the 1984 Act itself, noting that it may impact future cases.
Lord Carnwath concluded that default in section 106 is not limited to the provisions of the 1984 Act but extends to other forms of legal default.

The Court of Appeal's conclusion that the Council had no defence to the compensation claim was correct, not because there was no default under the 1984 Act, but because it was not Stylus's default that led to the emergency action.
Lord Carnwath emphasized that this does not limit the arbitrator's ability to consider other factors in assessing compensation.
The arbitrator may consider Stylus's statutory and common law responsibilities, the pier's structural condition, and its impact on business continuity.
The arbitrator may also consider the effects of the emergency action on Stylus's business operations.
uksc-2016-0080: PJS is married to YMA.
PJS and YMA are both well known individuals in the entertainment business.
PJS and YMA have two young children.
Between 2009 and 2011, PJS had a sexual relationship with AB.
Between 2009 and 2011, PJS had a sexual relationship with AB and CD on one occasion.
In January 2016, the editor of the Sun on Sunday newspaper notified PJS that he proposed to publish AB's account of the relationship.
PJS claimed that the publication would breach his rights to privacy and confidentiality under article 8 of the ECHR.
PJS applied for an interim injunction to restrain the publication pending the trial of his claim.
The court had to balance PJS's article 8 rights with NGN's freedom of expression under article 10 ECHR.
The court's decision was subject to section 12 of the Human Rights Act 1998.
Section 12(3) of the HRA requires that an interim injunction can only be granted if the claimant is likely to establish at trial that publication should not be allowed.
Section 12(4) of the HRA requires the court to have particular regard to the importance of freedom of expression.
The High Court refused PJS's application for an interim injunction.
The Court of Appeal allowed PJS's appeal and granted an interim injunction.
The interim injunction restrained the publication of information that would disclose PJS's identity and details of the sexual relationship.
AB's account was published in print in the United States on 6 April 2016.
AB's account was later published in Canada and in Scotland.
Publication was restricted to hardcopy editions and online publication was geo-blocked for users in England and Wales.
Details of the relationship were published on other websites and social media.
Appellants' solicitors worked to remove offending URLs and web pages.
NGN applied to the Court of Appeal to set aside the interim injunction on 12 April 2016.
NGN argued that the information was in the public domain and PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction.
The Court of Appeal held that the injunction should be discharged on 18 April 2016.
The Supreme Court restored the interim injunction pending determination of PJS's application for permission to appeal.
The Supreme Court granted permission to appeal and allowed PJS's appeal by a majority of 4 to 1.
Lord Mance gave the leading judgment, with which Lord Neuberger, Lady Hale, and Lord Reed agreed.
Lord Toulson gave a dissenting judgment.
The Court of Appeal erred in law by giving more weight to article 10 rights in the balancing exercise.
The Supreme Court concluded that there is no public interest in the disclosure of private sexual encounters.
The Supreme Court determined that PJS is likely to establish at trial that the proposed publication constitutes a serious breach of his and his family's privacy rights.
uksc-2010-0201: Mr Seldon joined the law firm in 1971 and became an equity partner in 1972.
In 2005, the partners adopted a partnership deed that required partners to retire by the end of the following December if they reached the age of 65.
Mr Seldon reached the age of 65 on 15 January 2006.
Mr Seldon requested an extension of his tenure after reaching the age of 65.
The other partners rejected Mr Seldon's request, citing no sufficient business need.
The partners offered Mr Seldon an ex gratia payment of £30,000.
The Employment Equality (Age) Regulations 2006 came into force in October 2006.
Mr Seldon informed the partners of his intention to consider his rights under the Age Regulations.
The partners withdrew their offer of an ex gratia payment after Mr Seldon mentioned his legal rights.
Mr Seldon ceased to be a partner in the firm on 31 December 2006.
Mr Seldon issued proceedings in March 2007, alleging direct age discrimination and victimisation.
Regulation 17 of the Age Regulations prohibits discrimination against partners by expelling them from their position.
Regulation 3 of the Age Regulations defines discrimination as treating someone less favourably on the grounds of age.
The mandatory retirement age treated Mr Seldon less favourably than other partners, based on his age.
The key issue was whether the treatment of Mr Seldon could be justified.
The Age Regulations transposed Council Directive 2000/78/EC into UK law.
Article 2(1)(a) of the Directive defines direct discrimination as treating someone less favourably in a comparable situation.
Article 2(1)(b) of the Directive defines indirect discrimination as a neutral provision that puts a particular age group at a disadvantage.
Article 6(1) of the Directive allows member states to justify age-based differences if they are objectively and reasonably justified by a legitimate aim.
Regulation 3 of the Age Regulations does not distinguish between direct and indirect discrimination for the purpose of justification.

The Employment Tribunal found that the retirement policy pursued three legitimate aims: giving associates an opportunity for partnership, facilitating workforce planning, and limiting the need to expel underperforming partners.
The Tribunal concluded that the mandatory retirement age of 65 was a proportionate means of achieving the three legitimate aims.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal remitted the case to the Employment Tribunal, noting that the aims could have been met by a retirement age other than 65.
The Court of Appeal dismissed Mr Seldon's appeal.
Mr Seldon appealed to the Supreme Court, asserting that the tests for justification in direct and indirect discrimination should be distinguished.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr Seldon's appeal and remitted the case to the Employment Tribunal.
Lady Hale's lead judgment emphasized the need to distinguish the tests for justification in direct and indirect discrimination.
The aims of the Directive are of a public interest nature, distinguishing them from purely individual employer reasons.
The Age Regulations allowed employers to choose legitimate aims consistent with the Directive's social policy objectives.
The case was remitted to the Employment Tribunal to determine whether the choice of a mandatory retirement age of 65 was proportionate to the legitimate aims of the partnership.
uksc-2016-0048: DD was born in 2006 in Romania to Romanian parents who met while working in England.
The family returned to England after the birth of DD.
The parents of DD separated in 2007.
DD has lived in England since 2007 in the care of his mother.
The father returned to Romania in 2009 but has maintained a significant relationship with his son.
The father commenced divorce and custody proceedings in Romania in 2007.
The Romanian Court of Appeal issued a decision in November 2013 stating that DD should live with his father.
The father applied for the recognition and enforcement of the custody order in the English court in February 2014.
These proceedings are governed by the Brussels II (Revised) Regulation (BIIR).
DD was made a party to the proceedings.
A High Court judge refused the father's application in July 2014, citing Article 23(b) BIIR.
Article 23(b) BIIR states that a judgment should not be recognized if the child was not given an opportunity to be heard.
The Romanian court did not make direct or indirect enquiry of DD regarding his wishes and feelings.
The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision.
The father sought to pursue a further appeal to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court considered whether it had jurisdiction to hear an appeal against an order for the enforcement of a custody order under BIIR.
The Supreme Court unanimously ruled that it does not have jurisdiction to hear the father's appeal.
Lady Hale gave the only substantive judgment in the case.
Under Section 40 of the Constitutional Reform Act 2005, appeals to the Supreme Court are subject to provisions under other enactments.
The question was whether the provisions of BIIR constitute such an enactment or override the Supreme Court's jurisdiction.
The application to register a judgment governed by BIIR is intended to be a speedy and administrative process.
Either party may appeal the decision under Article 33 of BIIR.
Article 34 of BIIR allows the judgment on an appeal to be contested only by proceedings notified by each member state to the Commission.
The UK notified that appeals under Article 34 in England and Wales may be brought only by a single further appeal on a point of law to the Court of Appeal.
The UK has historically provided for only one tier of further appeal in similar European instruments.
The purpose of the restriction on appeals is to ensure member states recognize and enforce each other's judgments without excessive challenge.
The provisions of BIIR and the notification under Article 68 are directly applicable in the UK.
Article 34 of BIIR does not depend on the member state's choice of appellate route and the UK made a notification.
The notification under Article 68 does not need to reflect all appellate rights under UK law.
The Supreme Court has no jurisdiction to entertain an appeal in this case, and the appeal is struck out.
uksc-2016-0004: The appellant was in the care of the respondent local authority from the ages of seven to eighteen.
The local authority placed her into foster care with Mr and Mrs A between March 1985 and March 1986.
The local authority placed her into foster care with Mr and Mrs B between October 1987 and February 1988.
The appellant was physically and emotionally abused by Mrs A.
The appellant was sexually abused by Mr B.
The case proceeded on the basis that the local authority were not negligent in the selection or supervision of the foster parents.
The case proceeded on the basis that the local authority were liable for the abuse perpetrated by her foster carers.
The appellant claimed that the local authority were liable for the abuse either on the basis of a non delegable duty or vicarious liability.
The appellant's claim was dismissed by the High Court.
The appellant's claim was dismissed by the Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal by a majority of 4 to 1.
The Supreme Court found the local authority vicariously liable for the abuse committed by the foster parents.
The Supreme Court rejected the argument that the local authority were liable on the basis of a non delegable duty.
Lord Reed gave the lead judgment, with which Lady Hale, Lord Kerr, and Lord Clarke agreed.
Lord Hughes gave a dissenting judgment.
A local authority is not under a non delegable duty to ensure that reasonable care is taken for the safety of children in care while they are in the care and control of foster parents.
The Child Care Act 1980 permits a local authority to arrange for children in care to spend time staying with their parents or grandparents.

Imposing strict liability on local authorities for the lack of care of relatives or friends would risk creating a conflict between their duty to safeguard children and their interests in avoiding liability.
The Child Care Act 1980 requires the local authority to discharge the duty to provide accommodation and maintenance for a child, including by placing the child with foster parents.
The local authority's duty is not to provide the child with day to day care, but rather to arrange for and monitor the performance of that function by the foster parents.
The Secretary of State makes regulations under section 22 of the 1980 Act imposing duties on local authorities in relation to the boarding out of children.
The local authority's continuing responsibility for the child is discharged by boarding out the child in accordance with those regulations.
The statutory regime does not impose any responsibility for the day to day care of the child.
The local authority are vicariously liable for the acts of the foster parents in the present case.
The local authority carried out the recruitment, selection, and training of foster parents.
The local authority paid the expenses of the foster parents.
The local authority supervised the fostering process.
The foster parents were not carrying on an independent business of their own.
The abuse committed by the foster parents was in the course of an activity carried on for the benefit of the local authority.
The placement of children with foster parents creates a relationship of authority and trust where close control cannot be exercised by the local authority.
uksc-2011-0117: Section 175 of the Housing Act 1996 defines a person as homeless if they have no accommodation available for occupation in the United Kingdom or elsewhere.

Section 176 of the Housing Act 1996 states that accommodation is available for occupation only if it is available for the person and any other person who normally resides with them as a family member.
The phrase "available for his occupation" is relevant to determining both homelessness and the duties of local housing authorities under the 1996 Act.
In 2004, Camden London Borough Council accepted a duty under the 1996 Act to provide accommodation to Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister.
Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister were initially accommodated in a hostel by the Council and later moved to a three-bedroom house owned by a private sector landlord.
In 2009, the Council offered Ms Sharif, her father, and her sister two separate units on the same floor of a block of flats in North London.
Each unit offered to Ms Sharif's family comprised a single bed sitting room with cooking facilities and a bathroom.
The two units were separated by only a few yards.
The Council intended for Ms Sharif and her sister to share one unit, while her father would live in the other unit.
Ms Sharif refused the accommodation offer, stating that her father's medical condition required them to live in the same unit.
Ms Sharif requested a review of the Council's decision, but the reviewing officer concluded that the offered accommodation was suitable.
Ms Sharif appealed to the London Central County Court, arguing that the accommodation was not suitable and that section 176 of the 1996 Act precluded offering separate units.
The County Court dismissed Ms Sharif's appeal.
The Court of Appeal reversed the County Court's decision, stating that the phrase "together with" in section 176 requires a homeless family to be housed in the same unit.
The Council appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court allowed the Council's appeal.
The Supreme Court held that section 176 of the 1996 Act does not prevent local authorities from offering a homeless family two separate units of accommodation.
The lead judgment for the majority was given by Lord Carnwath.
Lord Kerr gave a dissenting judgment.

The majority concluded that while the 1996 Act aims to prevent splitting up homeless families, it does not prohibit offering separate units if they allow the family to live together in practical terms.
The 1996 Act requires that accommodation provided by a local housing authority be suitable.
Ms Sharif no longer denies that the two flats offered by the Council meet the suitability requirement.
Neither the word "accommodation" nor the phrase "together with" in section 176 imply that a homeless family must be in the same unit.
Had the reviewing officer been asked whether section 176 prohibits housing a homeless family in two separate units, he would have answered in the negative.
The main obstacle to family living raised before the reviewing officer was the problem of caring for Ms Sharif's father in a separate unit.
The reviewing officer discounted the problem of caring for Ms Sharif's father by comparing it to communication issues in a two-floor house.
The arguments made on behalf of Ms Sharif would produce surprising results, such as preventing local authorities from improving overcrowded housing by offering additional units.
Ms Sharif accepted that two separate rooms in a hostel or hotel would satisfy the requirements of section 176 of the 1996 Act.
The majority found it hard to see why two adjacent flats should be treated differently from two separate rooms in a hostel or hotel.
Lady Hale emphasized that there is no requirement under the 1996 Act for local housing authorities to provide a communal living space to homeless individuals.
The majority emphasized that their interpretation of section 176 does not give local housing authorities a free hand.
A fundamental objective of the 1996 Act is to ensure that families can live together in a true sense.
Accommodation provided by a local housing authority must enable families to live together in a true sense.
Lord Hope stated that the test for accommodation is not to be exploited by local housing authorities; it must be applied reasonably and proportionately.
Lord Kerr, dissenting, argued that section 176 requires a local housing authority to accommodate a homeless family in the same unit of accommodation.
Lord Kerr concluded that the phrase "together with" in section 176 implies joint occupation of the same unit of accommodation.
Lord Kerr took the view that sufficient proximity is very different from living together.
uksc-2010-0154: The Appellant is a UK company based near Aberdeen and is one of about 70 subsidiary or associated companies of Halliburton Inc., a US corporation.
Mr Ravat is a British citizen who lived in Preston, Lancashire.
Mr Ravat was employed by the Appellant from April 1990 until May 2006.
Mr Ravat was made redundant in May 2006.
At the time of his dismissal, Mr Ravat was working in Libya.
Mr Ravat complained that he was unfairly dismissed.
An employment tribunal in Aberdeen initially held that it had jurisdiction to consider Mr Ravat's complaint.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal set aside the decision of the employment tribunal.
Mr Ravat appealed, and the Inner House of the Court of Session allowed the appeal.
The Appellant now appeals to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The Supreme Court remitted the case to the employment tribunal to deal with the merits of the claim that Mr Ravat was unfairly dismissed.
The judgment was given by Lord Hope.
Section 94(1) of the Employment Rights Act 1996 sets out the right of the employee not to be unfairly dismissed.
Section 230(1) of the Employment Rights Act 1996 sets out the definition of employee.
Sections 94(1) and 230(1) do not contain any geographical limitation.
Some limitation must be implied for section 94(1) to apply.
In Lawson v Serco Ltd, Lord Hoffmann identified three categories of employees within the jurisdiction of the employment tribunal.
Mr Ravat's case does not fit into any of Lord Hoffmann's categories.
The problem must be resolved by applying relevant guiding principles to the facts.
The question is whether section 94(1) applies to the particular case, despite foreign elements.
The employment relationship must have a stronger connection with Great Britain than with the foreign country where the employee works.
The general rule is that the place of employment is decisive, but this is not an absolute rule.
An exception can be made if the connection between Great Britain and the employment relationship is sufficiently strong.
The case of truly expatriate employees requires an especially strong connection with Great Britain.
The connection for non-expatriate employees does not need to meet the same high standard.
Mr Ravat was treated as a commuter with his home in Great Britain.
The burden on Mr Ravat to show a sufficient connection is less onerous.
The question is whether the connection between the employment and Great Britain is strong enough for section 94(1) to apply.
Mr Ravat was working in Libya for a German-based Halliburton associated company.
The decision to dismiss Mr Ravat was made by an individual based in Cairo.
The Appellant's business was based in Great Britain.
Mr Ravat was treated as a commuter, preserving benefits he would have received if working in Great Britain.
Mr Ravat was assured that UK employment law would apply to his contract.
The documentation Mr Ravat received reflected the assurance that UK employment law would apply.
Matters relating to the termination of Mr Ravat's employment were handled by the Appellant's human resources department in Aberdeen.
The question is ultimately one of degree.
The employment tribunal's decision should be given considerable respect.
Section 94(1) must be interpreted as applying to Mr Ravat's employment.
The employment tribunal therefore has jurisdiction to hear Mr Ravat's claim.
uksc-2015-0216: The Children and Young People (Scotland) Act 2014 establishes a named person service for children and young people in Scotland.
The named person service aims to promote early intervention to support the wellbeing of children and young people.
The named person service requires collaboration and information sharing among statutory bodies.
The named person service includes advising, informing, or supporting children, young people, or their parents.
The named person service includes helping children, young people, or their parents access services or support.
The named person service includes discussing or raising matters about children or young people with service providers or relevant authorities.
The authority responsible for the named person service depends on the age and circumstances of the child or young person.
Part 4 of the 2014 Act sets out powers and duties relating to information sharing.
Section 23 of Part 4 outlines conditions for sharing information following a change in named person service provider.
Section 26 of Part 4 outlines conditions for sharing information between service providers or relevant authorities.
Section 26(8) of Part 4 allows the named person service provider to disclose information if necessary or expedient for the exercise of named person functions.
The powers and duties of disclosure under sections 23 and 26 of Part 4 cannot be exercised in breach of an enactment's prohibition or restriction.
The appellants challenged Part 4 of the 2014 Act on grounds of legislative competence, human rights, and EU law.
The appellants included four registered charities and three individual parents.
The appellants' challenges were dismissed by the Outer House and the Inner House of the Court of Session.
The appellants appealed to the Supreme Court, which allowed the appeal on the basis of the ECHR and EU law challenges.
The Supreme Court invited written submissions on the terms of its order under section 102 of the Scotland Act.
The Reserved Matters Challenge argued that the data sharing provisions relate to the Data Protection Act 1998 and Council Directive 95/46/EC.
The subject matter of the Data Protection Act and Directive is the standards of protection for data and methods to secure them.
The Data Protection Act imposes obligations on data controllers and creates rights for data subjects.
Section 35 of the Data Protection Act allows for derogation from its requirements by legislation, including devolved legislation.
Service providers and relevant authorities under Part 4 are subject to legal duties under the Data Protection Act.
Information about children and young people can be disclosed without consent if necessary to protect their vital interests or for statutory functions.
Part 4's disclosure thresholds are lower than those under the Data Protection Act.
The ECHR Challenge argued that the named person service breaches Article 8 ECHR rights by compelling appointment without parental consent.
The ECHR Challenge also argued that information sharing provisions breach Article 8 rights of children and young people.
The Community Law Advice Network challenged the information sharing provisions for infringing Article 8 rights.
The information sharing provisions of Part 4 may interfere with the interests protected by Article 8, including family life and privacy.
The interference with Article 8 rights must be in accordance with the law, accessible, and foreseeable.
The information sharing provisions of Part 4 and the Guidance do not satisfy the requirement of being in accordance with the law.
uksc-2012-0109: Mr and Mrs Stott decided to take a holiday in Zante, Greece, in September 2008.
Mr Stott is paralysed from the shoulders down and a permanent wheelchair user.
Mr Stott has double incontinence and uses a catheter.
When travelling by air, Mr Stott depends on his wife to manage his incontinence, help him to eat, and change his sitting position.
Mr Stott booked return flights with Thomas Cook Tour Operators Ltd, a tour operator and air carrier.
Mr Stott telephoned Thomas Cook's helpline twice, informing them that he had paid to be seated with his wife, and was assured that this would happen.
On arrival at check in for the return journey, Mr and Mrs Stott were told that they would not be seated together.
Mr and Mrs Stott protested, but were eventually told that the seat allocations could not be changed.
Mr Stott had difficulties in boarding the aircraft, and was not sufficiently assisted by Thomas Cook staff.
Mr Stott felt extremely embarrassed, humiliated, and angry.
Mr Stott was eventually helped into his seat, with his wife sitting behind him.
The arrangement was problematic, since Mrs Stott could not properly assist her husband during the three hour and twenty minute flight.
Mrs Stott had to kneel or crouch in the aisle to attend to his personal needs, obstructing the cabin crew and other passengers.
The cabin crew made no attempt to ease their difficulties.

Mr Stott, assisted by the Equality and Human Rights Commission, brought a claim under the Civil Aviation (Access to Air Travel for Disabled Persons and Persons with Reduced Mobility) Regulations 2007.
The UK Regulations enable civil proceedings in UK courts for breaches of the EC disability rights regulations.
The EC Regulations require Community air carriers to make reasonable efforts to provide accompanying persons with a seat next to a disabled person.
Mr Stott claimed that Thomas Cook had breached this duty, and sought a declaration and damages for injury to his feelings.
Thomas Cook argued that it had made reasonable efforts and that the Montreal Convention precluded a damages award for injury to feelings.
Under Articles 17 and 29 of the Montreal Convention, damages can only be awarded for harm to passengers in cases of death or bodily injury.
The judge at trial found that Thomas Cook had breached the UK Regulations and made a declaration to that effect.
The judge held that the Convention prevented him from making any damages award to Mr Stott.
The Court of Appeal agreed with the judge's decision.
Mr Stott appealed, arguing that his claim was outside the substantive scope of the Convention.
Mr Stott also argued that his claim was outside the temporal scope of the Convention.
The Secretary of State for Transport intervened to support Mr Stott's claim on the second (temporal) ground.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The judgment of the Court was given by Lord Toulson, with a concurring judgment by Lady Hale.
Mr Stott was treated in a humiliating and disgraceful manner by Thomas Cook.
The Supreme Court held that Mr Stott's claim falls within the substantive and temporal scope of the Montreal Convention.
uksc-2017-0073: Nottingham City Council is the licensing authority for houses in multiple occupation (HMOs) in its area under Part 2 of the Housing Act 2004.
The appeal concerns two HMOs, 44, Rothesay Avenue and 50, Bute Avenue, owned by Trevor Parr Associates Ltd.
Dominic Parr is the managing director of Trevor Parr Associates Ltd and the manager of the two HMOs.
The Housing Act 2004 requires HMOs to be licensed by the local housing authority.
The local housing authority can grant an HMO licence under section 64 of the 2004 Act if it is satisfied the house is reasonably suitable for occupation.
The local housing authority can impose conditions under section 67 of the 2004 Act to make the house suitable for occupation.
Nottingham City Council issued guidance stating the minimum space provision for bedrooms in single occupation in HMOs is eight square metres.
A degree of flexibility is sometimes allowed in the minimum space provision for bedrooms in HMOs if other features are present.
44, Rothesay Avenue and 50, Bute Avenue are both used for letting to students.
Both HMOs have an attic bedroom with an area of useable living space below eight square metres.
Nottingham City Council granted an HMO licence for 44, Rothesay Avenue with a condition prohibiting the use of the attic bedroom for sleeping.
Nottingham City Council granted an HMO licence for 50, Bute Avenue with a condition prohibiting the use of the attic bedroom for sleeping.
The respondents appealed to the First tier Tribunal against the imposition of the conditions.
The First tier Tribunal deleted the conditions imposed by the appellant in both cases.
The First tier Tribunal substituted a condition for 44, Rothesay Avenue allowing the attic bedroom to be used for sleeping by a full-time student for a maximum of ten months per year.
The appellant appealed both decisions to the Upper Tribunal.
The Upper Tribunal dismissed the appeals and directed that the substituted condition be included in the HMO licence for 50, Bute Avenue.
The appellant then appealed to the Court of Appeal.
The Court of Appeal upheld the decision of the Upper Tribunal and added further conditions to both HMO licences.
The Court of Appeal added conditions requiring communal space to be available for communal living only and that no bedrooms be let to persons other than full-time students.
The appellant appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that conditions under sections 64 and 67 of the 2004 Act cannot be used to limit the class of persons for whom the HMO is suitable.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal, subject to varying the conditions to delete the ten-month occupation requirement.
Lord Lloyd Jones gave the sole judgment with which the other Justices agreed.
Section 64(3)(a) of the 2004 Act allows conditions to be imposed to make the house reasonably suitable for occupation.
Section 67(1)(a) allows the local housing authority to impose conditions for regulating the use and occupation of the house.
Section 67(2) provides a non-exhaustive list of permitted conditions, including restrictions on the use or occupation of particular parts of the house.
The words in sections 64 and 67 of the 2004 Act are sufficiently wide to include the conditions imposed by the Tribunals and the Court of Appeal.
The conditions imposed are consistent with the object and purpose of the 2004 Act.
The guidance on the 2004 Act supports the view that the manner of occupation and type of occupant may affect the suitability of a room for a particular use.
The Supreme Court considers that the conditions in issue do not introduce an exception for a category of persons or defined circumstances.
uksc-2013-0006: On 6 December 2010, the Crown Prosecution Service applied for restraint and receivership orders against Eastenders Group.
Eastenders Group was a holding company for several trading cash and carry retail outlets.
The CPS sought to investigate a suspected fraud on HMRC through Eastenders Group companies.
A POCA restraint order prevents named persons from dealing with their assets until the order is discharged.
A receivership order appoints a receiver to manage the assets of the company subject to the restraint order.
Mr Barnes was appointed as the receiver of Eastenders Group under an agreement with the CPS.
Mr Barnes was remunerated from Eastenders Group property under the letter of agreement.
The Crown Court judge made the restraint and receivership orders after a short hearing.
Eastenders Group attempted to have the orders discharged on 23 December 2010, but the judge refused.
Eastenders Group appealed the orders to the Court of Appeal, which heard the case on 25 January 2011.
The Court of Appeal quashed the orders over the Group, stating there was no good arguable case that the Group's assets were the individuals' assets.
The Court of Appeal also found that 95% of the Group's business was demonstrably legitimate.
During the receivership, the receiver incurred costs and expenses totaling £772,547.
The receiver applied to the Crown Court for permission to draw his remuneration and expenses from Eastenders Group assets.
The Crown Court refused the application, citing a breach of the Group's right to peaceful enjoyment of its possessions under Article 1 of Protocol 1 to the European Convention on Human Rights.
The Crown Court held that requiring the companies to pay would be unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998.
The CPS appealed the decision to the Court of Appeal.

The majority of the Court of Appeal upheld the Crown Court's decision that the Group's rights under A1P1 would be infringed by an order entitling the receiver to draw his remuneration from its assets.
Laws LJ dissented and would have allowed the receiver to draw his remuneration from Eastenders Group assets.
The Court of Appeal was unanimous in holding that there was no basis under POCA or the HRA 1998 for the CPS to be required to pay the receivers remuneration and expenses.
The receiver appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the receiver's appeal against the Court of Appeal's refusal to have the CPS pay the receivers remuneration and expenses.
Lord Toulson gave the leading judgment in the Supreme Court.
It is a general principle of the law of receivership that a court-appointed receiver is entitled to remuneration from the assets of the administered company.
The Supreme Court held that it would be a disproportionate interference with the Group's A1P1 rights to require the receivers remuneration to be drawn from the Group's assets.
The Supreme Court concluded that the receiver has a valid right to restitution from the CPS.
The receiver has a lien over the assets placed by the court in his control for the purpose of remuneration.
The receiver has a claim in unjust enrichment against the CPS.
The restraint and receivership orders were made on an application at short notice.
Applications by the CPS for such orders should be made as early as possible with proper time estimates and reading lists.
uksc-2014-0073: In 2006, the United States of America closed a watercraft repair centre in Hampshire.
Mrs Nolan was employed at the Base by the appellant.
Mrs Nolan was dismissed for redundancy the day before the Base closed.
Mrs Nolan complained that the appellant failed to consult with any employee representative before her dismissal.
The appellant denies having a duty to consult with employee representatives.
Mrs Nolan brought Employment Tribunal proceedings under Part IV Chapter II of the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992.
The 1995 Regulations amended TULCRA to require employee representatives to be designated for consultation purposes.
TULCRA as originally enacted extended a right to be consulted prior to redundancies to employees of public administrative bodies.
TULCRA was confined to circumstances where employees had union representation recognised by the employer.
In 1994, the Court of Justice identified the failure of TULCRA to meet European law requirements.
The Secretary of State made the 1995 Regulations under section 2(2) of the European Communities Act 1972.
Mrs Nolan succeeded before the Employment Tribunal and was granted an order for remuneration for one month.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal upheld the order granted to Mrs Nolan.
The Court of Appeal referred the UK Coal Mining/Fujitsu issue to the Court of Justice.
The Court of Justice declined jurisdiction, stating that national defence and closure of a military base are outside the scope of Directive 98/59/EEC.
The Court of Justice also held that it was not appropriate to rule on a question relating to a public administrative establishment.
The Court of Appeal ordered a further hearing of the UK Coal Mining/Fujitsu issues.
The USA appeals to the Supreme Court on three grounds.
The USA argues that TULCRA should not apply to employment by a public administrative establishment for non-commercial activities.
The USA claims that the 1995 Regulations exceeded the powers conferred by section 2 of the 1972 Act.
The Supreme Court dismissed the USA's appeal by a majority of 4:1.
The case was remitted to the Court of Appeal for determination of the UK Coal Mining/Fujitsu issues.
Lord Mance gave the lead judgment, with which Lord Neuberger, Lady Hale, and Lord Reed agreed.
Lord Carnwath dissented in the Supreme Court decision.
The Supreme Court rejected the USA's first submission that TULCRA should not apply to non-commercial activities.
The Supreme Court held that jurisdiction is primarily territorial in both international and domestic law.
TULCRA regulates procedures for redundancy in England, Wales, and Scotland.
The UK is not legislating extra-territorially when covering domestic redundancies developed or taken abroad.
TULCRA contains no exception for cases involving foreign states.
The Supreme Court rejected the USA's second submission that EU law protects third country nationals from discrimination.
uksc-2009-0125: The Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 (RTOA) originally limited the maximum sentence for driving while disqualified to six months imprisonment or a fine when prosecuted summarily.
The maximum sentence for driving while disqualified, when prosecuted on indictment, was 12 months imprisonment or a fine or both.
The Criminal Proceedings etc (Reform)(Scotland) Act 2007 increased the maximum sentence for driving while disqualified to 12 months imprisonment when prosecuted summarily.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller were each sentenced to over six months imprisonment for driving while disqualified in summary proceedings.
Sean Martin and Ross Miller challenged their sentences, arguing that the 2007 Act's amendment was outside the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The High Court of Justiciary dismissed the appeals, stating that the 2007 Act's amendment was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Supreme Court granted permission for an appeal against the High Court's decision.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, affirming that the 2007 Act's amendment was within the Scottish Parliament's legislative competence.
The Supreme Court's majority judgment was delivered by Lord Hope.
The majority judgment applied the rules in s 29 and Part 1 of Schedule 4 of the Scotland Act 1998 to determine legislative competence.
The case raised three questions regarding the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.
The first question was whether s.45 of the 2007 Act modified Scots criminal law as defined in s.126(5) of the Scotland Act.
The second question was whether the purpose of s.45 was to ensure consistent application of the law between reserved and non-reserved matters.
The third question was whether the rule modified by s.45 was special to a reserved matter under para 2(3) of Schedule 4.
The purpose of s.45 was to reform summary justice by reducing pressure on higher courts.
The jurisdiction of a Sheriff is defined by the penalties they can impose, which is a matter of Scots criminal law.
The majority held that s.45 did not relate to a reserved matter under s.29(2)(b) of the Scotland Act 1998.
The 2007 Act included provisions increasing the summary sentencing powers of Sheriffs for various common law and statutory offences.
The purpose of s.45 was to ensure consistency in the law relating to Sheriff sentencing powers across reserved and non-reserved matters.
The majority concluded that s.45 was not related to a reserved matter under s.29(4) of the Scotland Act 1998.
The key to the decision was identifying the rule of law being modified by s.45.
The rule being modified by s.45 was the procedure determining whether a Sheriff could impose a sentence.
The change in law by s.45 did not alter the maximum period of imprisonment for driving while disqualified.
The rule of Scots law being modified was a criminal procedure rule, not special to the RTOA or RTA.
The dissenting opinion argued that the maximum term of imprisonment for driving while disqualified was special to a reserved matter.
Lord Rodger did not agree that the purpose of a modifying provision could determine whether a rule was special to a reserved matter.
Lord Kerr agreed with Lord Rodger's dissenting opinion.
The Supreme Court held that s.45 was within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.
The appeals were dismissed and remitted to the High Court of Justiciary for further orders.
The case centered on the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament regarding the modification of Scots criminal law.
uksc-2013-0273: Section 28 of the Housing Act 1988 provides a method for calculating damages for unlawful eviction.
Section 27 of the Housing Act 1988 allows for the right to claim damages for unlawful eviction.
The Housing Act 1988 includes safeguards to prevent unscrupulous landlords from evicting tenants with protected tenancies.
Section 28(1) of the Housing Act 1988 requires the court to make two valuations of the landlord's interest in the property.
Valuation (a) under Section 28(1) assumes the tenant continues to have the same right to occupy the premises as before the eviction.
Valuation (b) under Section 28(1) assumes the tenant has ceased to have the right to occupy the premises.
Section 28(3)(a) requires both valuations to be calculated on the assumption that the property is sold on the open market to a willing buyer.
Mr Loveridge lived in the downstairs flat at 19 Moresby Walk from November 2002.
Both the upstairs and downstairs flats at 19 Moresby Walk were owned by the London Borough of Lambeth.
Mr Loveridge made a trip to Ghana from July to December 2009.
While Mr Loveridge was away, Lambeth changed the locks on his flat and cleared his possessions, mistakenly believing he had died.
Two days after returning to the UK, Mr Loveridge's flat was rented to someone else.
Mr Loveridge sued Lambeth for damages due to unlawful eviction.
Mr Loveridge and Lambeth each instructed a surveyor to value Lambeth's interest in 19 Moresby Walk.
Mr Loveridge's surveyor calculated valuation (a) assuming both flats were subject to secure tenancies.
Mr Loveridge's surveyor calculated valuation (b) assuming the downstairs flat was vacant and the upstairs flat was subject to a secure tenancy.
The difference in value between valuations (a) and (b) was 90,500.
Lambeth's surveyor calculated valuation (a) assuming both flats were subject to assured tenancies.
Lambeth's surveyor concluded valuation (b) produced the same figure as valuation (a).
The judge at the Lambeth County Court found that Mr Loveridge had been unlawfully evicted.
The judge awarded Mr Loveridge 90,500 under Section 28 and 9,000 at common law for trespass to his goods.
Lambeth appealed against the quantum of damages awarded under Section 28.
The Court of Appeal set aside the section 28 award and ordered Lambeth to pay 7,400 in damages at common law.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and restored the original order for damages.
Lord Wilson's judgment stated that the words of Section 27 of the 1988 Act cover local authority landlords.
The assumption of a sale on the open market does not extend to making adjustments to the nature of the tenant's rights.
Adjustments to the nature of the tenant's rights are barred by subsection 28(1)(a).
The likely effect of a sale to a private landlord on a secure tenancy should not be taken into account.
uksc-2018-0140: DN is a Rwandan national who was granted refugee status in the UK under the 1951 Refugee Convention on 26 October 2000.
DN was convicted in the UK of assisting the unlawful entry of a non-EEA national contrary to section 25 of the Immigration Act 1971.
DN was sentenced to 12 months imprisonment for the Immigration Act offence and two months consecutively for each of three pecuniary advantage offences, totaling 18 months imprisonment.
The Secretary of State for the Home Department has powers under the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 to order the deportation of persons convicted of serious offences.

Section 72(4)(a) of the 2002 Act provides that a person is presumed to have been convicted of a particularly serious crime and to constitute a danger to the community if convicted of an offence specified by the Secretary of State.
The Secretary of State specified several offences as particularly serious crimes through the 2004 Order.
Assisting unlawful immigration contrary to section 25 of the 1971 Act was included in the 2004 Order as a particularly serious crime.
DN was deported by the Secretary of State on 2 July 2007 based on section 72(4)(a) of the 2002 Act.
DN was detained pending deportation on 31 January 2008 under Schedule 3, paragraph 2(3) of the 1971 Act.
DN brought a claim for judicial review of the deportation order.
The Court of Appeal in EN (Serbia) v Secretary of State for the Home Department ruled the 2004 Order unlawful.
