DN amended his judicial review proceedings to focus on the lawfulness of his detention.
The Court of Appeal in R (Draga) v Secretary of State for the Home Department ruled detention lawful even if based on an unlawful deportation order.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed DN's appeal, finding him unlawfully detained and entitled to damages for false imprisonment.
Lord Kerr gave the lead judgment in the Supreme Court's decision.
Lord Carnwath gave a concurring judgment in the Supreme Court's decision.
The Court noted that there is no difference between detention unlawful due to lack of statutory power and detention unlawful due to breach of public law.
The 2004 Order, which was unlawful, was the basis for DN's deportation decision.
DN's detention was uniquely linked to the deportation order.
The lawfulness of detention is always referable back to the legality of the deportation decision.
The Court rejected the argument that a judicial decision in statutory appeals removes the legal error in the deportation order.
The Court considered that the decision in Draga was wrongly decided.
Lord Carnwath suggested that issue estoppel could provide a complete answer in similar cases in the future.
DN's claim for damages depended on the lawfulness of the deportation decision at the time it was made.
The tribunal's decision in August 2007 and the High Court's rejection of the review application conclusively determined the legality of the deportation decision.
DN had the opportunity to challenge the legality of the original deportation decision but did not do so.
DN would be estopped from challenging the legality of the deportation decision at a later date.
The Secretary of State did not rely on res judicata in this case.
It would be unfair to DN for the court to introduce res judicata at this stage.
The Court of Appeal's decision in Draga was based on the second actor theory, which the Court found misplaced.
uksc-2017-0110: The case involves the classification of chicken and pork products manufactured by Newby Foods Ltd under EU food hygiene rules.
The appeal concerns whether these products should be classified as mechanically separated meat (MSM) under point 1.14 of Annex I to EU Regulation No 853/2004.
Newby Foods Ltd argues that their products should not be classified as MSM.
The Food Standards Agency (FSA) contends that the products should be classified as MSM.
The EU Regulation distinguishes between high pressure and low pressure MSM.
Both types of MSM are subject to specific hygiene requirements in the Regulation.
MSM cannot be counted towards food meat content and requires specific labelling.
MSM produced from lamb and beef bones is prohibited under EU law.
The commercial value of MSM is lower than that of other fresh meat products.
Newby developed a machine to remove residual meat from carcase bones.
The machine is used to process residual meat on beef, lamb, and pork bones after initial boning.
The machine is also used on chicken carcases after the breasts have been removed.
Newby's process has two stages: shearing meat from bones and producing a minced meat-like product.
Newby's product was previously known as desinewed meat (DSM) in the UK.
DSM was not a category recognized in EU law.
The FSA issued a moratorium on DSM production from beef and lamb bones in 2012.
The moratorium restricted DSM production to chicken and pork bones, provided it was classified as MSM.
Newby challenged the moratorium through judicial review proceedings.
The High Court made a preliminary reference to the CJEU on the definition of MSM.
The CJEU issued a preliminary ruling on the definition of MSM in point 1.14 of the Regulation.
Newby abandoned its challenge to the moratorium regarding lamb and beef carcases after the CJEU judgment.
The High Court found that Newby's pork and chicken products from stage (1) of the process are not MSM.
The Court of Appeal upheld the finding that DSM is not derived from bone scrapings.
Newby appeals to the Supreme Court on the interpretation of point 1.14 in light of the CJEU judgment.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The CJEU identified three cumulative criteria for defining MSM under point 1.14.
The three criteria include the use of bones with attached meat, mechanical separation, and loss or modification of muscle fibre structure.
The CJEU stated that any product meeting the three criteria must be classified as MSM.
The Supreme Court found that Newby's products meet the first two criteria for MSM classification.
The appeal hinges on whether Newby's products meet the third criterion, considering the cutting point qualification.
uksc-2012-0072: Section 2(6)(e) of the Extradition Act 2003 requires an EAW to include particulars of the sentence(s) imposed.

Section 65(3)(c) of the Extradition Act 2003 applies to offences in the requesting state that would constitute an offence in the UK if it occurred there, provided that a minimum sentence of four months was imposed.
Many EU states provide for the aggregation of successive sentences imposed on different occasions to produce a single sentence for all of the offences committed.

Earlier case law establishes that where each of the original sentences is for conduct that satisfies all the other requirements of an extradition offence, it is enough for an EAW to specify the cumulative sentence rather than all of the individual sentences.
The appeal concerns the situation where a EAW specifies only the original sentences, but after it has been issued they are aggregated and their totality reduced.
Lukasz Zakrzewski was convicted on four occasions in Poland of various offences of dishonesty or violence.
His sentences were initially suspended and then activated by further offences or breaches of probation terms.
On 24 February 2010, the Regional Court in Lodz issued a EAW against Mr Zakrzewski based on these four convictions specifying the sentences passed.
Mr Zakrzewski was arrested in England on 28 September 2010 and brought before the City of Westminster Magistrates Court the same day.
However, as he was facing further criminal charges in England, the extradition proceedings were adjourned.
During the adjournment, Mr Zakrzewski applied to the District Court of Grudziadz in Poland to have the four sentences aggregated.
The court duly aggregated them and on 19 April 2012 imposed a cumulative sentence of 22 months imprisonment.
When the extradition proceedings resumed, Mr Zakrzewski claimed that the aggregation order meant the EAW was no longer gave the particulars required by s.2(6)(e).
The warrant was therefore invalid, and no longer gave proper, fair or accurate particulars.
District Judge Rose rejected Mr Zakrzewski's arguments and granted an extradition order.

However, this was overturned by Lloyd Jones J in the High Court on the basis that the EAW must relate to the current operative sentence in force not to earlier individual ones subsumed in an aggregated order.
The Regional Court in Lodz appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal and restores the extradition order of District Judge Rose.
Lord Sumption gives the judgment of the Court.
The Court was informed that Mr. Zakrzewski had returned voluntarily to Poland after the argument on the appeal and been arrested there.
The warrant has been withdrawn by the court which issued it.
The purpose of the European Council Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA was to create a simplified and accelerated procedure based on mutual recognition.
The courts of states being asked to consider EAWs should generally take information contained in them at face value.
An EAW's validity depends on whether the prescribed particulars are found in it, not on whether they are correct.
A defendant cannot normally challenge its validity by reference to extraneous evidence.
A EAW is either valid or not valid. It cannot change over time.
Lord Sumption drew attention to two safeguards against unjustified extradition in this context.
The first safeguard was mutual trust between parties to the Framework Decision to ensure information in a EAW is true.
The requesting authority has the right to forward additional information at any time and the requested UK authority has the right to receive it and to request further information.
The second safeguard is the courts inherent right to ensure its process is not abused, for example, where an EAW has been obtained for improper purposes.
uksc-2015-0063: Ms Janah is a Moroccan national who was recruited in Libya to work as a domestic worker for the Libyan government at its London embassy.
Ms Benkharbouche is a Moroccan national who was recruited in Iraq to work for Sudan at its London embassy.
Both Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche were dismissed from their employment and issued claims in the Employment Tribunal against Libya and Sudan respectively.
Some of the claims by Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche were based on EU law.
Other claims by Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche were based on breach of contract or on purely domestic statutes of the United Kingdom.
The Employment Tribunal dismissed the claims on the basis that Libya and Sudan were entitled to state immunity under the State Immunity Act 1978.
The Employment Appeal Tribunal (EAT) heard the appeals of Ms Janah and Ms Benkharbouche together.
The EAT allowed the appeals and held that sections of the 1978 Act were incompatible with article 47 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.
The EAT disapplied sections 4(2)(b) and 16(1)(a) of the 1978 Act insofar as they barred claims based on EU law.
The Court of Appeal affirmed the judgment of the EAT and declared those sections of the 1978 Act incompatible with the right to access a court under article 6 of the ECHR.
The Secretary of State appeals in both cases.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
Lord Sumption gave the judgment, with which Lord Neuberger, Lady Hale, Lord Clarke, and Lord Wilson agreed.
Section 4(2)(b) of the 1978 Act confers immunity in cases where the claimant was neither a UK national nor UK resident at the time of the contract.
Section 16(1)(a) of the 1978 Act confers immunity in cases where the claimant works for the foreign state's diplomatic mission.
Article 6 of the ECHR confers a right of access to a court to determine disputes, although it is not absolute.
The claimants argued that the provisions of the 1978 Act were incompatible with EU law and Article 6 of the ECHR.
The Secretary of State argued that the provisions of the 1978 Act were consistent with international law.
The test was whether the provisions of the Act were consistent with international law, not whether there was a tenable view to that effect.
The provisions of the 1978 Act were not consistent with international law.
A court may identify a rule of customary international law only if enough states follow a consistent practice.
The Secretary of State argued that the immunity was still absolute unless there was sufficient international consensus.
The Court rejected the arguments that mischaracterize the historical development of the restrictive doctrine of immunity.
There has never been sufficient international consensus for an absolute rule of state immunity in customary international law.
The only consensus about the scope of state immunity is the recent consensus in favor of the restrictive doctrine.
The restrictive doctrine emerged after a re-examination of the true basis of the doctrine.
In customary international law, a foreign state is immune where a claim is based on sovereign acts.
The employment of purely domestic staff in a diplomatic mission is a private act, not an inherently sovereign act.
The approach to state immunity is supported by case law from the United States, France, and the European Court of Human Rights.
Section 4(2)(b) of the Act draws no distinction between acts of a private nature and acts of a sovereign nature.
uksc-2013-0243: Mrs Sylvie Beghal passed through East Midlands Airport on 4 January 2011 with her three children.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was stopped by police at East Midlands Airport.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was not formally detained, arrested, or suspected of being a terrorist.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was told by police that they needed to speak to her to establish if she was involved in terrorist acts.
The police used the power under Paragraph 2 of Schedule 7 of the Terrorism Act 2000 to question Mrs Sylvie Beghal.
The power under Paragraph 2 of Schedule 7 allows questioning individuals at ports or borders to determine if they appear to be involved in terrorism.
No reasonable suspicion of a past or future offence is needed to exercise the power under Paragraph 2 of Schedule 7.
Under Schedule 7, officers may require the production of documents carried by individuals.
Under Schedule 7, officers may copy and retain material carried by individuals.
Under Schedule 7, officers may search and detain individuals for a maximum of 6 hours.
Failure to comply with Schedule 7 requirements is a criminal offence under Paragraph 18 of Schedule 7.
A Code of Practice exists for officers exercising the powers under Schedule 7.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal asked for a lawyer and was granted an opportunity to pray.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was searched during the questioning process.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was asked questions about her relationship with her husband, her reasons for travel, and where she had stayed.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal refused to answer most of the questions during the questioning.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal was charged with wilful failure to comply with the requirement to answer questions.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal pleaded guilty to the charge of wilful failure to comply with Schedule 7 requirements.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal received a conditional discharge as her sentence.
Mrs Sylvie Beghal brought proceedings arguing that Schedule 7 powers breached her Article 5, Article 6, and Article 8 ECHR rights.
The Divisional Court dismissed Mrs Sylvie Beghal's claims.
The Supreme Court dismissed Mrs Sylvie Beghal's appeal by a majority of 4 to 1.
Lord Kerr dissented in the Supreme Court ruling.
Lord Hughes delivered the lead judgment in the Supreme Court.
Lord Neuberger and Lord Dyson gave a joint concurring opinion in the Supreme Court.
Questioning and search under Schedule 7 constitutes an interference with Article 8(1) ECHR.
The use of Schedule 7 powers is justified under Article 8(2) ECHR due to sufficient safeguards.
The power to detain under Schedule 7 falls within Article 5(1)(b) ECHR.
The power to detain for six hours is proportionate and justified if necessary for the questioning process.
The retention of electronic data under Schedule 7 is a considerable intrusion into an individual's private life.
uksc-2011-0024: Paragraph 277 of the Immigration Rules was amended in 2008 to raise the minimum age for a spouse or sponsor from 18 to 21.
The purpose of the amendment to Paragraph 277 was to deter forced marriages.
A forced marriage is defined as a marriage into which at least one party enters without free and full consent through force or duress.
Mr Quila, a Chilean national, entered into a fully consensual marriage with Ms Jeffery, a British citizen.
Mr Quila applied for a marriage visa before the amendment took effect but was refused because his wife was 17.
By the time Ms Jeffery turned 18, the amendment was in force, and the Home Office refused to waive it.
Mr Quila and his wife were forced to leave the UK to live in Chile and later in Ireland.
Bibi, a Pakistani national, applied to join her husband, Mohammed, a British citizen, in the UK.
Bibi and Mohammed had an arranged marriage in Pakistan to which they both freely consented.
Their application to join in the UK was refused because both parties were under 21.
The Respondents' claims for judicial review were rejected in the High Court.
The Respondents successfully appealed to the Court of Appeal, which declared the application of Paragraph 277 was a breach of Article 8 ECHR.
The Secretary of State appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court dismissed the Secretary of State's appeal on the grounds that the refusal to grant marriage visas infringed Article 8 ECHR.
Lord Wilson gave the leading judgment in the Supreme Court's decision.
Lady Hale gave a concurring judgment in the Supreme Court's decision.
Lord Phillips and Lord Clarke agreed with Lord Wilson and Lady Hale.
Lord Brown gave a dissenting judgment in the Supreme Court's decision.
Article 8 ECHR was engaged in the case.
The Court considered whether the refusal to grant marriage visas was an interference with the right to family life.
Lord Wilson considered the refusal to grant marriage visas a colossal interference with the right to family life.
The ECtHR in Abdulaziz v United Kingdom held that denying entry to foreign spouses did not lack respect for family life.
Lord Wilson held that Abdulaziz should not be followed in this respect.
The Secretary of State failed to establish that the interference with Article 8 ECHR was justified.
Paragraph 277 has a legitimate aim of protecting individuals from forced marriage.
The effectiveness of Paragraph 277 in deterring forced marriage is highly debatable.
The Secretary of State failed to provide robust evidence that the amendment had a substantial deterrent effect.
The number of forced marriages among those refused a marriage visa was not quantified.
The amendment to Paragraph 277 was compared to a blanket prohibition on marriages without permission, which was found unlawful.
The measure was deemed a sledgehammer approach to a problem, with the Secretary of State failing to justify its necessity and proportionality.
uksc-2010-0189: The Wolverhampton City Council granted planning permission for four blocks of student accommodation near an LPG storage site.
Three of the four blocks of student accommodation had been completed, but work on the fourth had not commenced.
The Health and Safety Executive applied for an order to revoke or modify the planning permission under section 97 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.
The Council refused the application without considering whether to revoke or modify the permission for the fourth block alone.
The HSE brought judicial review proceedings challenging the Council's decision.
The High Court initially refused the part of the HSE's claim.
The Court of Appeal allowed the HSE's appeal, finding the Council's decision irrational.
The Court of Appeal held that the Council's decision was unlawful and ordered it to reconsider the matter.
The Court of Appeal also held that the Council could consider compensation under section 107 of the Act when reconsidering the matter.
The HSE appealed to the Supreme Court regarding whether compensation under section 107 could be considered under section 97.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the HSE's appeal.
Lord Carnwath delivered the leading judgment of the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court considered whether a public authority can take into account the cost of its actions when exercising a discretionary power.
The Supreme Court held that a public authority must consider whether the cost is proportionate to the aim.
Section 97 of the Act requires the authority to satisfy itself that revocation is expedient.
The development plan in this case provided no guidance on the issue.
The word "expedient" implies that the action should be appropriate in all the circumstances.
A potential liability for compensation is a relevant consideration under section 97.
The Supreme Court held that financial consequences are relevant to the exercise of section 97.
The term "material considerations" includes considerations relevant to the exercise of the power under the statute.
The Supreme Court rejected the view that cost considerations should be excluded from the decision-making process.
The Supreme Court noted that the decision in Alnwick DC v Secretary of State was wrong.
The Supreme Court stated that uncertainty in assessing compensation is not a reason to exclude cost considerations.
The Supreme Court dismissed the HSE's appeal for reasons similar to those of the majority in the Court of Appeal.
uksc-2013-0083: Letham Grange Development Company Limited (LGDC) sold hotel and adjoining golf courses to NSL in February 2001.
The sale price recorded in the disposition was 248,100.
LGDC purchased the subjects in November 1994 for just over 2 million.
The value of the subjects at the time of the sale was estimated at about 1.8 million.
LGDC went into liquidation in December 2002.
In January 2003, NSL granted a standard security over the subjects in favour of Foxworth Investments Limited.
The liquidator of LGDC, Mr Henderson, began proceedings against NSL seeking the reduction of the 2001 disposition.
Mr Henderson obtained a decree by default in 2009 when NSL failed to be represented at the proof (trial).
The liquidator then brought proceedings seeking reduction of Foxworths standard security.
The liquidator argued that Foxworth could not bring itself within the section 242 proviso.
The appellants claimed that NSL had assumed debts of 1.85m owed by LGDC to Mr Liu and his family.
The appellants argued that this brought Foxworth within the scope of the proviso.
The Lord Ordinary, Lord Glennie, rejected the liquidators case that the sale was a gratuitous alienation.
The liquidator sought to establish that the documentation relating to the assumption of the LGDC debts had not been prepared on the dates it bore.
Lord Glennie accepted Mr Liu's evidence on the point.
The Extra Division of the Inner House of the Court of Session reversed Lord Glennie's decision.
The Extra Division found that Lord Glennie had erred in law.
The Extra Division concluded that the sale had been a gratuitous alienation.
The court unanimously allowed the appeal by Foxworth and NSL.
Lord Reed delivered the main judgment, with which the other Justices agree.
Lord Reed outlined the principles governing review of a trial court's findings of fact.
The Extra Division was correct to identify that an appellate court can interfere where satisfied that the trial judge has gone plainly wrong.
The Extra Division erred in concluding that this criterion was met in the present case.
Lord Glennie did not err in law; he clearly understood the critical issue under section 242(4)(b).

Lord Glennie was aware that an obligation on the part of NSL could only constitute part of the consideration for the sale if it was undertaken as the counterpart of the obligations undertaken by LGDC.
Lord Glennie's opinion focused on whether any obligation was taken to assume the LGDC debts.
Lord Glennie was entitled to accept Mr Liu's evidence on this point.
Lord Reed rejected the criticisms made of Lord Glennie's treatment of the evidence.
Lord Glennie's assessment of the evidence reflected a careful and nuanced understanding of the commercial realities.
The parties accepted that no prejudice would be occasioned by remitting the question of expenses in the Outer House to the Lord Ordinary.
uksc-2018-0154: The appeal concerns whether Visa and Mastercard payment card schemes restrict competition in breach of Article 101(1) of the TFEU.
Visa and Mastercard operate open four-party payment card schemes.
Issuers issue debit and/or credit cards to cardholders, and acquirers provide payment services to merchants.
Scheme operators set the rules of the schemes and allow institutions to join as issuers and/or acquirers.
Cardholders contract with issuers for terms including fees, interest rates, and rewards.
Merchants contract with acquirers for payment services, paying a merchant service charge (MSC).
The issuer pays the acquirer, who passes the payment to the merchant less the MSC.
The schemes include a default interchange fee known as the multilateral interchange fee (MIF).
Acquirers and issuers typically contract based on the MIF.
Visa and Mastercard do not receive any part of the MIF or the MSC.
Their remuneration comes from scheme fees paid by issuers and acquirers.
The MIF typically accounted for about 90% of the MSC during the claim period.
Acquirers pass on all of the MIF to merchants through the MSC.
Negotiation between acquirers and merchants regarding the MSC is limited to the acquirer's margin.
Visa and Mastercard schemes operate in a two-sided market with issuers and acquirers competing on different sides.
The proceedings concern the effect of MIFs on competition in the acquiring market.
Article 101(1) TFEU prohibits agreements that restrict competition between member states.
Article 101(3) provides an exemption for agreements that improve production or distribution and benefit consumers.
The Visa and Mastercard schemes have been previously scrutinized by competition authorities.
The European Commission found that Mastercard's MIFs breached Article 101(1) in 2007.
The General Court dismissed Mastercard's appeal to annul the Commission decision.
The Court of Justice of the European Union upheld the Commission's decision.
The Competition Appeal Tribunal found that Mastercard's UK MIFs restricted competition and awarded damages to Sainsburys.
The Commercial Court found that Mastercard's MIFs did not infringe Article 101(1) and were exempt under Article 101(3).
The Court of Appeal overturned previous judgments and found that MIFs restricted competition.
The Court of Appeal remitted the exemption issue under Article 101(3) to the Competition Appeal Tribunal.
Visa and Mastercard appeal on four grounds, including whether MIFs restricted competition.
The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's conclusion that MIFs infringed Article 101(1).
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal on the restriction issue.
The Court of Appeal ruled that the MIFs set a minimum price floor for the MSC, restricting competition.
uksc-2011-0260: The appeals involve significant questions about the interrelationship between statutory schemes for employee pensions and corporate insolvency.
The Pensions Act 2004 introduced a financial support direction (FSD) regime to protect employees from underfunded pension schemes.
The Pensions Regulator can impose an FSD on group companies to provide financial support to underfunded pension schemes.
Non-compliance with an FSD can result in a Contribution Notice (CN) imposing a monetary liability on the target company.
Many UK members of the Lehman and Nortel groups went into insolvent administration.
A Lehman group company had service contracts and ran a pension scheme for employees of other group members.
The Nortel group included a company with an insufficiently resourced pension scheme.
The pension schemes in both cases were final salary schemes in substantial deficit.
The Pensions Regulator initiated FSD machinery to require financial support for the pension schemes.
The FSD machinery was delayed due to uncertainty about how administrators should treat liabilities under the FSD regime.
The issue was whether FSD liabilities would rank as an expense, pari passu with other creditors, or neither.
Briggs J and the Court of Appeal concluded that the liability should rank as an expense of the administration.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeals and declared that FSD liabilities rank as provable debts.
Lord Neuberger delivered the main judgment of the Supreme Court.
Lord Sumption gave a short concurring judgment.
Potential liabilities under the FSD regime can constitute a provable debt under rule 13.12 of the Insolvency Rules 1986.
FSD liabilities issued after an insolvent event fall within rule 13.12(1)(b) of the Insolvency Rules.
If a CN had been issued before an insolvent event, it would result in a provable debt.
The courts below considered that a CN issued after an insolvent event could still be a provable debt if based on an FSD issued before the event.
The courts below felt constrained by previous authority and would have reached the Supreme Court's conclusion if allowed.
Earlier authorities are overruled due to inconsistency and outdated concerns about individual insolvencies.
The liability imposed by an FSD issued after an insolvent event is a liability under an enactment within rule 13.12(4) of the Insolvency Rules.
The issue is whether the liability arose from an obligation incurred before the insolvent event.
The word "obligation" in rule 13.12(1)(b) refers to steps that had legal effect and made the company vulnerable to liability.
All requirements for an obligation under rule 13.12(1)(b) are satisfied in these cases.
The potential FSD liability is a provable debt under rule 13.12 of the Insolvency Rules.
The Court concluded that if the liability was not a provable debt, it would not count as an expense of the administration.
The Court also concluded that it would not have had discretion to rank the liability higher than under the legislation.
Lord Sumption provided additional observations on the limitations of what constitutes an obligation under rule 13.12(1)(b).
The Supreme Court's decision clarifies the treatment of FSD liabilities in the context of corporate insolvency.
uksc-2018-0164: The Supreme Court is asked to decide whether Barclays Bank is vicariously liable for sexual assaults allegedly committed by Dr Gordon Bates between 1968 and about 1984.
Dr Gordon Bates was a self-employed medical practitioner with a portfolio practice.
Dr Bates conducted medical assessments and examinations of prospective Barclays employees.
Barclays required job applicants to pass a pre-employment medical examination as part of its recruitment and employment procedures.
Barclays arranged the appointments with Dr Bates and provided him with a pro forma report headed "Barclays Confidential Medical Report."
Dr Bates was paid a fee for each report; Barclays did not pay him a retainer.
If the report was satisfactory, the applicants' job offer would be confirmed, subject to satisfactory GCE examination results.
Dr Bates conducted the medical examinations in a consulting room at his home.
It is alleged that Dr Bates sexually assaulted 126 claimants during their medical examinations.
After Dr Bates died in 2009, the claimants sought damages from Barclays.
At first instance, the judge held that Barclays is vicariously liable for any assaults that Dr Bates is proved to have perpetrated.
The Court of Appeal agreed and dismissed Barclays' appeal.
Barclays now appeals to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows Barclays' appeal and holds that it is not vicariously liable for Dr Bates' alleged wrongdoing.
Lady Hale gives the judgment, with which all members of the Court agree.
To establish vicarious liability, there must be a relationship between the two persons that makes it proper for the law to make one pay for the fault of the other.
There must also be a sufficient connection between that relationship and the wrongdoing of the person who committed the tort.
The case concerns the first element of the vicarious liability test.
Historically, vicarious liability was limited to the relationship between an employee and an employer.
Barclays argues that Dr Bates was an independent contractor and not an employee, so it cannot be held liable for his wrongdoing.
Lord Bridge of Harwich stated that the employer of an independent contractor is generally not liable for the negligence or other torts committed by the contractor.
The claimants argue that recent Supreme Court decisions have broadened the approach to vicarious liability.
The claimants reference the cases of Various Claimants v Catholic Child Welfare Society, Cox v Ministry of Justice, and Armes v Nottinghamshire County Council.
These cases suggest that a relationship akin to employment can lead to vicarious liability, but not for independent contractors.
The Court of Appeal and Singapore Court of Appeal have reached similar conclusions in other cases.
The key factor is whether the person who committed the tort was carrying on business on their own account.
If the person is carrying on their own independent business, the five factors from Christian Brothers are not necessary to consider.
Dr Bates was not an employee or in a relationship close to employment with Barclays.
Dr Bates was in business on his own account as a medical practitioner with a portfolio of patients and clients.
The Supreme Court concludes that Barclays is not vicariously liable for any assaults Dr Bates is proved to have committed during the medical examinations.
uksc-2014-0138: The appeal challenges the compatibility of s 60 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 with article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
Section 60 allows a police officer to stop and search a person or vehicle for offensive weapons or dangerous instruments without reasonable suspicion.
The power under s 60 requires authorisation from a senior police officer, which must be limited in time and place.
On 9 September 2010, Superintendent Barclay authorised s 60 searches for 17 hours in parts of Haringey due to gang-related violence.
Police Constable Jacqui Reid used s 60 to search Mrs Roberts' bag during an incident involving a fare dispute on a bus.
Mrs Roberts denied having identification and kept a tight hold on her bag during the encounter.
The search under s 60 enabled the police to establish Mrs Roberts' name from a bank card.
Mrs Roberts brought judicial review proceedings alleging breaches of her ECHR rights.
Both the High Court and Court of Appeal rejected Mrs Roberts' claims.
The only claim pursued in the Supreme Court was the alleged breach of article 8 of the ECHR.
Mrs Roberts sought a declaration of incompatibility under s 4 of the Human Rights Act 1998.
Article 8 requires the law to be accessible and foreseeable for individuals to regulate their conduct.
Article 8 also requires safeguards against arbitrary or discriminatory use of the law.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mrs Roberts' appeal.
The Court held that safeguards under s 60, such as providing reasons for authorisation and searches, ensure lawful exercise of the power.
The power under s 60 was found to be in accordance with the law.
Lady Hale and Lord Reed provided the only substantive judgment agreed upon by the justices.
Section 60 is one of the few instances where Parliament allows stop and search without reasonable suspicion for public safety.
The power is justified under article 8(2) as it pursues a legitimate aim of preventing serious crime.
The issue was whether s 60 satisfied article 8(2) by being in accordance with the law.
Section 60 targets the risk of violence involving offensive weapons in a specific locality.
The authorisation for s 60 requires a senior officer to reasonably believe serious violence may occur.
The authorisation can last up to 24 hours and may be renewed once.
The exercise of s 60 is subject to safeguards under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984.
The Code of Practice and Standard Operating Procedures of the Metropolitan Police also apply to s 60.
Failure to comply with these safeguards makes the use of s 60 unlawful.
The authorisation on 9 September 2010 was based on police intelligence reports of gang-related violence.
PC Reid considered Mrs Roberts' bag-holding behavior suspicious and conducted a search under s 60.
PC Reid provided Mrs Roberts with a form explaining the reasons for the search.
The Supreme Court concluded that the law under s 60 is not incompatible with article 8 of the ECHR.
uksc-2011-0233: The appellant was 17 years old when he had sexual intercourse with a 13-year-old girl.
The girl initially informed her mother that the intercourse was not consensual.
The appellant was arrested following the girl's initial allegation.
The girl later withdrew the allegation and admitted the sex had been consensual.
The appellant was charged with unlawful carnal knowledge of a girl under the age of 14 under section 4 of the 1885 Act.
The offence under section 4 of the 1885 Act carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.
The appellant pleaded guilty to the charge at Belfast Crown Court in 2004.
The appellant was sentenced to 3 years detention in a Young Offenders Centre, suspended for 2 years.
The appellant pleaded guilty under the understanding that belief in the girl's age was not a defence.
The appellant later argued that the Crown was required to prove he did not believe the girl was over 13.
The appellant argued that section 4 of the 1885 Act was silent on the defence of belief in the girl's age.
The appellant relied on the general presumption that criminal offences require mens rea unless excluded by statute.
The Northern Ireland Court of Appeal rejected the appellant's arguments and held no defence of reasonable belief existed.
The Court of Appeal stated that the prosecution only needed to prove the accused had sex with a girl under 14.
The appellant appealed to the Supreme Court, which unanimously dismissed the appeal.
Lord Kerr delivered the judgment of the Supreme Court.
Section 4 of the 1885 Act originally referred to unlawful carnal knowledge of a girl under 13 years old.
The age of liability was increased to 14 years by the 1950 Act.
Section 5 of the 1885 Act created the same offence for girls between 13 and 15 years old.
Sections 5 and 6 of the 1885 Act originally included a defence of reasonable belief that the girl was 16 or older.
The defence of reasonable belief was abolished by the 1923 Act and the 1950 Act.
Section 5 of the 1885 Act now refers to girls under 17 years old with no defence of reasonable belief.
No defence of reasonable belief has ever been explicitly provided in any version of section 4.
The constitutional principle of requiring mens rea for criminal liability is strong and not easily displaced.
The Supreme Court emphasized that mens rea is presumed unless clearly excluded by statute.
The Court noted that grave offences with heavy penalties require a strong case for implying the absence of mens rea.
The Court emphasized the importance of examining legislative intention before considering modifications.
The original intention of section 4 was to impose liability for carnal knowledge of a girl under 14 without proof of knowledge of her age.
The decision in R v Prince (1875) confirmed that proof of knowledge or belief in the victim's age was not required under the 1861 Act.
The removal of the defence from sections 5 and 6 does not imply its inclusion in section 4.
uksc-2015-0238: The issue in the appeal involves the role of the Court of Protection in disputes between health/social care providers and family members regarding care for a person lacking decision-making capacity.
N is a profoundly disabled man in his twenties who requires constant care throughout the day and night.
N's parents were unable to cooperate with authorities in meeting his needs, leading to a care order when he was eight.
The care order ended when N turned eighteen.
Before N turned eighteen, the local authority sought Court of Protection orders to place him in a care home and regulate contact with his parents.
Responsibility for N's care transferred to the National Health Service when he reached eighteen.
It was not disputed that N lacked the capacity to make decisions about his residence or contact with his family.
The care home was considered a safe and settled environment for N at the time of the hearing.
The dispute between N's parents and the clinical commissioning group focused on whether N could visit the family home and whether his mother could assist with his intimate care.
The respondent argued that neither option was in N's best interests due to funding constraints and staff concerns.
The judge concluded that the contact plan proposed by the respondent was in N's best interests.
The Court of Appeal upheld the judge's decision.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed N's parents' appeal.
The Court of Protection could not order the respondent to fund the parents' proposed plan.
The Court of Protection could not order care providers to perform actions they were unwilling or unable to do.
The judge was entitled to conclude that continuing the hearing served no useful purpose.
Lady Hale provided the only judgment in the Supreme Court.
The Court of Protection's jurisdiction is limited to decisions a person could make if they had capacity.
The Court of Protection is not equivalent to the family court in children's cases.
The Mental Capacity Act focuses on capacity in relation to specific decisions or matters.
The court prefers making orders under section 16 of the MCA over declaratory relief under section 15.
The court can make decisions on behalf of a person or appoint a deputy under section 16 of the MCA.
The court's powers under section 17 include deciding where a person should live and what contact they should have.
The court cannot compel third parties to provide services or treatments for a person.
The court cannot pressure a local authority to make decisions in the exercise of its statutory duties.
Such decisions can be challenged on judicial review principles.
The issue was mischaracterized as one of jurisdiction, as the Court of Protection has jurisdiction to make declarations and orders under the MCA.
The court has wide case management powers, including identifying issues that need investigation.
The court was entitled to conclude that no useful purpose would be served by continuing the hearing.
The appeal was dismissed because the court lacked the power to order the respondent to fund the parents' proposals.
uksc-2017-0160: The appeal concerns the effect of the GLA Roads and Side Roads (Transfer of Property etc) Order 2000 and the GLA Roads Designation Order 2000.
Responsibility for GLA roads was transferred from individual London borough councils to TfL under these Orders.
Article 2(1)(a) of the Transfer Order provides for the transfer of the highway in so far as it is vested in the former highway authority.
TfL and the Councils convened a statutory arbitration to determine what property and liabilities transferred to TfL.
The dispute is whether the transfer under article 2(1)(a) included only the zone of ordinary use or the entire vertical plane.
The Councils argued the transfer was limited to the zone of ordinary use.
TfL argued the transfer included the entire vertical plane to the extent the relevant council owned it prior to the transfer date.
The arbitrator broadly agreed with TfL's case.
The arbitrator noted that particular layers of subsoil or airspace could not be treated as parts of the highway.
The High Court agreed with the arbitrator but noted a concession by TfL that its claim related to land acquired for highway purposes.
The Court of Appeal adopted a narrower position, limiting the transfer to the zone of ordinary use.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
Lord Briggs delivered the sole judgment of the Supreme Court.
The word "highway" has no single meaning in the law.
The default land law position is that conveyance of freehold land involves transfer of the entire vertical plane.
The Baird principle limits transfers to the road surface, subsoil immediately beneath, and airspace for public use and maintenance.
The Baird principle reflects concerns about expropriation of private property without compensation.
The Baird principle applies to section 263 of the 1980 Act, replicating section 226 of the 1959 Act.
Section 265 of the 1980 Act provides for transfer of property and liabilities between highway authorities for designated trunk roads.
Section 7 of the Trunk Roads Act 1936 was the first major property transfer scheme for trunk roads.
Section 228 of the 1956 Act and section 265 of the 1980 Act are materially the same as section 7 of the 1936 Act.
Local highway authorities may acquire property rights through means other than automatic vesting, such as compulsory purchase.
Ownership of airspace and subsoil may have substantial commercial or development value in urban areas.
The Supreme Court decided the Baird principle does not apply to article 2 of the Transfer Order or section 265 of the 1980 Act.
The phrase "in so far as" in article 2 and section 265(1)(a) imports an ownership capacity limitation.
The Courts' approach avoids irrational multi-layering of ownership on the vertical plane.
Expropriation concerns are not well founded as transfers are quid pro quo for relief from responsibility.
There is no presumption or burden of proof as to the extent of highway rights transferred.
The decision does not resolve issues regarding the ownership of the lateral plane of a highway.
uksc-2018-0099: A retail store in Streatham was granted planning permission in 1985.
The 1985 planning permission restricted the store to the sale of DIY goods and other specified categories, excluding food.
The permitted categories were extended through later consents under section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.
The most recent consent was granted in 2014 and is the subject of this appeal.
The 2014 permission did not include a restriction on the sale of food goods.
The 2014 permission did not reference the conditions from the previous 2010 permission.
Aberdeen Asset Management sought a certificate from the appellant Council to determine that the store's lawful use included sales of unlimited categories of goods, including food.
The Council initially refused the certificate but it was granted by a planning inspector on appeal.
The planning inspector's decision was upheld by the lower courts.
The Council appeals the decision to this court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal.
The certificate should be amended to exclude uses within the scope of the proposed wording in the decision notice.
Lord Carnwath gives the lead judgment in the case.
Section 73 of the 1990 Act allows for the grant of a new permission unconditionally or subject to revised conditions.
Section 73 does not specify what happens if some conditions are changed but others are left in place.
Government guidance suggests that planning decisions under section 73 should repeat relevant conditions from the original permission for clarity.
The guidance was given as advice, not as a legal statement.
The interpretation of the document should be based on the natural and ordinary meaning of the words used.
The document should be interpreted in the context of common sense and the perspective of a reasonable reader.
The wording of the 2014 permission is clear and unambiguous.
The Council approved a variation of a condition as set out in the application.
The application included precise descriptions of the development, the condition to be varied, and the permission under which it was imposed.
The original wording of the condition restricted the store to the sale of non-food goods only.
The proposed wording in the 2014 permission also restricted the store to the sale of non-food goods only.
The reasonable interpretation of the document is that the Council approved the variation of the condition.
There is no indication that the Council intended to discharge the condition or remove the restriction on the sale of food goods.
If section 73 did not grant the power to vary the condition, the grant would be invalid.
All parties agree that the 2014 permission was valid.
The document must be taken as it is, without assuming any invalidity.
It has been common practice to describe section 73 as conferring the power to vary or amend a condition.
uksc-2009-0073: The appellants were convicted of serious criminal offences after trials in which the victims did not give evidence.
In one case, the victim had since died, and in the other case, the victim had run away in fear when the trial was about to commence.
A statement from the victim was admitted pursuant to s 116 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003.
The statement was placed before the jury in both cases.
The appellants complained that their convictions were based solely or to a decisive extent on the statement of a witness whom they had no chance to cross-examine.
The appellants argued that this infringed their right to a fair trial under articles 6(1) and 6(3) of the European Convention on Human Rights.
Article 6(1) guarantees the right to a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal.

Article 6(3)(d) guarantees the right to examine or have examined witnesses against him and to obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his behalf under the same conditions as witnesses against him.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the appellants' appeals against conviction.
The Court of Appeal held that the test of fairness from the European Court of Human Rights in Al Khawaja and Tahery v United Kingdom was not determinative of the results in these appeals.
The United Kingdom requested that the decision be referred to the Grand Chamber of the Strasbourg Court.
On 5 June 2009, the Grand Chamber adjourned consideration of the request pending the judgment of the Supreme Court in this case.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The judgment of the court was given by Lord Phillips, President.
The questions before the court were whether the regime for admitting evidence of an absent witness at a criminal trial would result in an unfair trial.
The court also considered whether the European Court of Human Rights case law required the court to apply the regime in a manner contrary to Parliament's intention.
Section 2 of the Human Rights Act 1998 requires the Supreme Court to take into account any judgment of the European Court of Human Rights.
The Supreme Court may decline to follow a Strasbourg decision if there are concerns about whether it sufficiently appreciates or accommodates aspects of the UK trial process.
The Supreme Court may give reasons for declining to follow a Strasbourg decision, allowing the Strasbourg Court to reconsider the issue.
The conclusions of the Court of Appeal were correct.
The Supreme Court's judgment should be read as complementary to the Court of Appeal's judgment.
The Supreme Court held that the appellants' trials were fair despite the decision in Al Khawaja.
The common law hearsay rule addressed the aspect of a fair trial covered by article 6(3)(d).
Parliament had enacted exceptions to the hearsay rule with safeguards that rendered the sole or decisive rule unnecessary.
The Strasbourg Court had recognized the need for exceptions to article 6(3)(d) but lacked clarity in its jurisprudence.
The Strasbourg Court introduced a sole or decisive rule without discussing the underlying principle or fully considering its justification.
The sole or decisive rule would create severe practical difficulties if applied to English criminal procedure.
In almost all cases, English law would reach the same result without the rule.
Al Khawaja did not establish that it was necessary to apply the rule in this jurisdiction.
The Supreme Court's judgment was complementary to the Court of Appeal's.
uksc-2015-0082: The case concerns the scope of the duty of confidentiality owed by HMRC to taxpayers.
Section 18(1) of the 2005 Act prohibits HMRC officials from disclosing taxpayer information.
Section 18(2) of the 2005 Act outlines situations where the duty of confidentiality may be overridden.
One such situation is when a disclosure is made for the purpose of a function of HMRC.
The function of HMRC is defined broadly in various sections of the 2005 Act.
Specific situations for overriding confidentiality include disclosures for civil or criminal proceedings.
Mr Patrick McKenna is the Founder and Chief Executive Officer of Ingenious Media Holdings plc.
Ingenious Media promotes film and investment schemes involving film production partnerships.
These schemes utilised certain tax relief previously available.
On 14 June 2012, Mr David Hartnett gave an off-the-record interview to The Times journalists.
The Times published articles on film schemes and tax avoidance on 21 June 2012.
The articles identified Mr McKenna as one of the main providers of film investment schemes.
The articles informed readers that such schemes enabled investors to avoid at least £5 million in tax.
The articles included a direct quote from Mr Hartnett attributed to a senior Revenue official.
Mr McKenna and Ingenious Media brought a claim for judicial review against HMRC.
The court at first instance found the disclosures were not irrational and were proportional.
The Court of Appeal upheld the first instance court's decision.
Ingenious Media appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Ingenious Media's appeal.
Lord Toulson delivered the lead judgment in the Supreme Court.
Judicial review is not the only course of action available to challenge public body conduct.
Public bodies are subject to the common law, including the law of confidentiality.
The law of confidentiality requires a duty to the person from whom information was received.
Tax affairs of individual taxpayers are matters between HMRC and the taxpayer.
Confidentiality is essential to the functioning of the tax system.
Statutory provisions may override the principle of confidentiality.
The interpretation of s.18(2)(a)(i) must not render other provisions in s.18(2)(b) to (j) superfluous.
The principle of legality prevents overriding fundamental rights with ambiguous language.
Parliament did not intend for HMRC to have wide discretion to disclose taxpayer information.
The correct interpretation of s.18(2)(a)(i) is that it permits disclosure reasonably necessary for HMRC's functions.
uksc-2013-0036: Med marketed hotel accommodation in the Mediterranean and the Caribbean through a website.
Hoteliers had to enter into a written agreement with Med to have their hotels marketed.
Potential customers booked holidays through a form on Med's website, which included standard booking conditions.
Customers paid the full amount for their holiday (the gross sum) before arriving at the hotel.
Med only paid the hotel a lower amount (the net sum) after the holiday ended.
VAT is an EU tax levied on the supply of goods or services.
Article 2.1(c) of Directive 2006/112/EC imposes VAT on the supply of services for consideration within a Member State.
Article 45 of the Principal VAT Directive states that the place of supply of services connected with immovable property is where the property is located.
Article 306 of the Principal VAT Directive differentiates between travel agents who deal with customers in their own name and those who act solely as intermediaries.
Article 306.1(a) applies to travel agents who deal with customers in their own name and use supplies from other taxable persons.
HMRC assessed Med for VAT based on the assumption that Med was a travel agent under article 306.1(a).
Med challenged the assessment, arguing it was a travel agent acting solely as an intermediary under article 306.1(b).
The First Tier Tribunal upheld HMRC's analysis that Med was a travel agent under article 306.1(a).
Morgan J allowed Med's appeal, but HMRC's subsequent appeal to the Court of Appeal was successful.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Med's appeal.
Lord Neuberger provided the only judgment, with which the rest of the court agreed.
Med was acting as an intermediary, not in its own name, and thus falls under article 306.1(b).
The Supreme Court discharged the Court of Appeal's order and restored Morgan J's order.
The outcome of the appeal depends on whether Med's activities fell under article 306.1(a) or 306.1(b).
The interpretation of article 306 is a matter of EU law, binding on national courts.
The nature and character of the contractual relationship between parties must be determined by the proper law of the contract.
The Accommodation Agreement and website terms govern the relationship between Med, the hotelier, and the customer.
The contractual documentation indicates that the hotelier provides the hotel room to the customer through Med's agency.
The customer pays the gross sum to Med, with the difference being Med's commission as an agent.
None of the contractual provisions suggest that the Accommodation Agreement or website terms are a sham or require rectification.
The contractual documentation supports the conclusion that Med acted as an agent for the hotelier.
The economic reality of the situation does not contradict the conclusion that Med was an intermediary.
The CJEU guidance indicates that the concepts of an intermediary and an agent are similar.
The CJEU's approach to determining whether a person is an intermediary is similar to English law's approach to determining agency.
Med's role as an agent under English law implies it was an intermediary under article 306.1.
uksc-2009-0118: Farstad Supply AS owned an oil rig supply vessel that was damaged by fire while berthed in harbour on 7 July 2002.
At the time of the fire, Asco UK Limited had engaged Enviroco Limited to clean out tanks on board the vessel.
Following the fire, Farstad sued Enviroco for damages, alleging that the fire was caused by the negligence of Enviroco's employees.
Enviroco alleged contributory negligence against Farstad's employees and sought a contribution from Asco under section 3(2) of the 1940 Act.
Section 3(2) of the 1940 Act allows a defender who has been held liable to recover contribution from any other person who, if sued, might also have been held liable.
Clause 33(5) of the charterparty required Farstad to defend, indemnify, and hold harmless Asco from all liabilities resulting from damage to the vessel.
Enviroco argued that Asco would be entitled to an indemnity from Farstad under clause 33(5) if it was entitled to a contribution from Asco.
The Outer House held that Enviroco was not entitled to a contribution from Asco under section 3(2) of the 1940 Act.
An Extra Division of the Inner House allowed Enviroco's reclaiming motion by a majority of 2:1.
Farstad appealed to the Supreme Court to restore the decision of the Lord Ordinary.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
The Court held that Enviroco is not entitled to a contribution from Asco under section 3(2) of the 1940 Act.
The Court determined that Enviroco could not establish that if sued, Asco might have been liable to Farstad in respect of losses caused by the fire.
The Court considered the meaning and effect of section 3(2) of the 1940 Act.
The Court considered whether a pre-existing contract, such as the charterparty, can be taken into account in determining if a person might have been liable under section 3(2).
The Court considered whether clause 33(5) of the charterparty excluded Asco's liability to Farstad for damage caused by Asco's own negligence.
The Court found that clause 33(5) of the charterparty does exclude Asco's liability to Farstad in respect of damage caused by Asco's own negligence.
The Court concluded that even if clause 33(5) were an indemnity clause, Farstad would not be entitled to a joint and several decree against both Asco and Enviroco.
The charterparty is governed by English law, and such a claim by Farstad would be met by the defence of circuity of action.
Scots law applies a principle similar to circuity of action, making any action by Farstad against Asco clearly fail.
Lord Rodger confirmed that the Court's construction of section 3(2) aligns with the case law of New Zealand and Canada.
The policy underlying the decisions of New Zealand and Canadian courts is equally applicable to Scots law.
The appeal was allowed, and the decision of the Lord Ordinary was restored.
The Supreme Court's decision clarified that Enviroco cannot establish Asco's potential liability under section 3(2) of the 1940 Act.
The Court emphasized that the outcome depends on the true construction of the charterparty.
The Court held that the charterparty's clause 33(5) excludes Asco's liability to Farstad for damage caused by Asco's own negligence.
The Court determined that the claim for contribution under section 3(2) requires proof that Asco might have been liable if sued.
The Court concluded that Asco would not have been liable if sued by Farstad due to the terms of the charterparty.
The Court rejected the argument that an indemnity clause would have allowed Farstad to obtain a joint and several decree against Asco and Enviroco.
The Court's decision reaffirmed that any action by Farstad against Asco would fail under the principles of circuity of action.
uksc-2010-0128: K is an unmarried father who cohabited with JR and had a child, L, born in May 2002.
K and JR registered the birth of their child, L, together.
K and JR's relationship broke down after the birth of L.
K continued to have contact with L and was involved in her hospital appointments until at least September 2003.
In May 2004, K raised proceedings in the sheriff court seeking full parental responsibilities and parental rights and a contact order.
An interim order for weekly overnight stays was made in K's proceedings.
In December 2005, JR alleged that K had abused L.
In March 2006, the local authority's social work services department referred the case to the Principal Reporter on the ground that L was in need of compulsory measures of supervision.
Children's hearings were held in June and July 2006.
In August 2006, the sheriff deemed the grounds of referral proved and remitted the case to the children's hearing.
K was not entitled to attend any of the children's hearings as he was not a relevant person under section 93(2)(b) of the 1995 Act.
On 27 October 2006, the sheriff made an order granting K parental rights and responsibilities to the extent that he becomes a relevant person in the children's referral.
After the sheriff's order, K attended the children's hearings.
In August 2007, the children's hearing imposed a condition of no contact between K and L.
In January 2009, K appealed against the continuation of the no contact condition.
The Principal Reporter challenged the sheriff's order in the Court of Session on the ground that it was incompetent.
On 27 March 2009, the Lord Ordinary suspended the sheriff's order of 27 October 2006.
On 21 January 2010, the First Division refused K's appeal and his application for a declaration of incompatibility with the European Convention on Human Rights.
Section 11(1) of the 1995 Act provides that the sheriff court may make an order in relation to parental responsibilities and parental rights.

Section 93(2)(b) defines a relevant person as a person (including a parent) with parental responsibilities or parental rights or who appears to be a person who ordinarily has charge of, or control over, the child.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed K's appeal.
Lord Hope and Lady Hale gave the judgment of the Court.
The Court held that the sheriff's order of 27 October 2006 was not incompetent.
The Court recalled the First Division's interlocutor and dismissed the petition.

The Court declared that section 93(2)(b)(c) of the 1995 Act should be read to include the words "or who appears to have established family life with the child with which the decision of a children's hearing may interfere."
The Court found that K is a relevant person under the amended section 93(2)(b)(c).
The Court noted that the case raises a fundamental issue about fairness.
K did not have the opportunity to refute the allegations in the grounds of referral in July or August 2006.
The Court stated that this is contrary to the right to be heard, a fundamental rule of natural justice.
The Court concluded that the children's hearing system violated the Article 8 rights of K and L, and risks violating the rights of others in similar situations.
uksc-2017-0115: On 26 May 2013, Ms Bianca Cameron was injured in a car collision with a Nissan Micra.
The incident was caused by the negligence of the driver of the Nissan Micra.
The driver of the Nissan Micra made off without stopping or reporting the accident to the police.
The registration number of the Nissan Micra was recorded.
Mr Naveed Hussain, the registered keeper of the Nissan Micra, was not the driver.
Mr Naveed Hussain has declined to identify the driver of the Nissan Micra.
Mr Naveed Hussain was convicted of failing to disclose the identity of the driver.
The Nissan Micra was insured under a policy issued by Liverpool Victoria Insurance Co Ltd.
The policy was issued to a Mr Nissar Bahadur, whom the insurer believes to be a fictitious person.
Neither Mr Naveed Hussain nor the driver was insured under the policy to drive the car.
Ms Cameron initially sued Mr Naveed Hussain for damages.
The proceedings were amended to add a claim against Liverpool Victoria Insurance for a declaration of liability.
The insurer denied liability, arguing there was no evidence that Mr Naveed Hussain was the driver.
Ms Cameron applied to amend her claim form to substitute Mr Naveed Hussain with the unknown driver.
District Judge Wright dismissed Ms Cameron's application to amend the claim form.
District Judge Wright entered summary judgment for the insurer.
HHJ Parker dismissed Ms Cameron's appeal against the summary judgment.
The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal by a majority, with Sir Ross Cranston dissenting.
The majority held that the court has discretion to sue an unknown person if justice requires it.
The majority considered the alternative right of claim against the Motor Insurance Bureau (MIB) to be irrelevant.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, setting aside the Court of Appeal's order.
The Supreme Court reinstated the summary judgment of District Judge Wright.
Lord Sumption delivered the lead judgment, with which all justices agreed.
Part VI of the Road Traffic Act 1988 applies to this appeal.
Section 145 of the Road Traffic Act 1988 requires an insurance policy against third-party risks for the driver.
Section 151(5) of the Road Traffic Act 1988 requires the insurer to satisfy a judgment against the driver.
Section 151(2)(b) of the Road Traffic Act 1988 makes the insurer liable on a judgment even if it was obtained against an uninsured driver.
The Motor Insurance Bureau (MIB) compensates victims of road accidents involving uninsured vehicles or untraceable drivers.
Clause 4(d) of the 2003 Untraced Drivers Agreement applies to Ms Cameron's case.
The statutory scheme of compulsory insurance in the UK does not confer a direct right of recovery against an insurer for the underlying liability of the driver.
uksc-2011-0196: In 2005, the Assets Recovery Agency (ARA) obtained an interim receiving order over properties acquired by Mrs Szepietowski's husband with money allegedly obtained through drug trafficking, mortgage fraud, and concealment from the Revenue.
In November 2006, the ARA initiated civil proceedings against Mr and Mrs Szepietowski to confiscate 20 properties under section 266 of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002.
The properties targeted included Ashford House, two properties at Thames Street, two properties at Church Street, and two properties at Claygate.
All of the properties were registered in the name of Mrs Szepietowski and had been charged to RBS for a debt of about £3.225 million.
On 16 January 2008, the Szepietowskis and the ARA settled the proceedings under a consent order that included a Settlement Deed.
Pursuant to the Settlement Deed, Thames Street and Church Street were sold to partially satisfy the RBS debt.
In September 2009, Mrs Szepietowski granted a charge over Claygate to the Serious Organised Crime Agency (SOCA).
The 2009 Charge was a second charge over Claygate, which was already subject to the RBS debt.
The 2009 Charge included a provision stating that Mrs Szepietowski had no personal liability to pay SOCA.
In late 2009, Mrs Szepietowski sold Claygate for £2.44 million.
After paying off the RBS debt, £1,324.16 remained to satisfy SOCA's rights under the 2009 Charge.
SOCA sought to invoke the right to marshal against Ashford House.
The right to marshal applies when there are two or more creditors with security over different properties.
SOCA argued it was entitled to marshal against Ashford House after using proceeds from Claygate to pay RBS.
Mrs Szepietowski argued that SOCA should not be allowed to marshal due to the terms of the Settlement Deed and the 2009 Charge.
Henderson J ruled in favor of SOCA's marshalling claim, as did the Court of Appeal.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed Mrs Szepietowski's appeal.
Lord Neuberger held that the 2009 Charge did not create or acknowledge any debt from Mrs Szepietowski to SOCA.
The 2009 Charge only bound Mrs Szepietowski to pay up to £1.24 million from the proceeds of Claygate after RBS was paid.
Marshalling is not available to a second mortgagee if the common property does not secure a debt from the mortgagor.
The Supreme Court emphasized that marshalling is an equitable remedy and depends on the circumstances.
The Court held that, in the absence of an express right to marshal, it is hard to conceive how marshalling would be available.
The Court considered whether the parties intended for SOCA to have the right to marshal.
The statutory background, Settlement Deed, and surrounding circumstances showed the parties did not intend for SOCA to have the right to marshal.
The fact that Ashford House was Mrs Szepietowski's home was a relevant background fact but not sufficient to prevent marshalling.
The Court noted that the right to marshal may be lost if the first mortgagee enforces against the common property in priority to the other property.
Lord Carnwath and Lord Hughes would have allowed the appeal on the narrower basis that the 2009 Charge excluded the right to marshal.
The 2009 Charge excluded any personal liability on the part of Mrs Szepietowski.
The 2009 Charge was read against the statutory background of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002.
The Supreme Court concluded that the parties did not intend for SOCA to have the right to marshal.
uksc-2015-0057: Investment trust companies (ITCs) sought refunds of VAT they had paid on investment management services.
The supplies in question were found to be exempt from VAT under EU law.
Investment managers (Managers) believed they could deduct input tax from output tax when accounting for VAT.
The Managers accounted for only 75 out of a notional 100 received from the ITCs after deducting 25 in input tax.
The Managers claimed refunds under s.80 of the VAT Act 1994 for the VAT they had actually paid.
The Managers could not claim refunds for accounting periods excluded by the three-year statutory limitation period.
The ITCs did not receive the full amount of VAT they had been charged and brought proceedings against the Commissioners.
The ITCs sought remedies in unjust enrichment and EU law for the notional 25 and the dead periods.
The judge found the Commissioners were enriched by the full amount of VAT paid by the ITCs.
The ITCs' common law claim was excluded by the statutory scheme under s.80.
EU law required the exclusion to be disapplied to permit a claim, but subject to the limitation period.
The claim for the dead periods was dismissed, but payment of the notional 25 outside those periods was ordered.
The Court of Appeal allowed both appeals.
The statutory scheme did not exclude a common law claim.
The Commissioners were enriched only to the extent of the notional 75 received from the Managers.
The notional 25 retained by the Managers was not an amount owed to them by the Commissioners.
There was uncertainty about whether the Commissioners were enriched at the expense of the ITCs.
A direct transfer of value from the ITCs to the Commissioners is required for enrichment at the expense of the ITCs.
The ITCs' payment to the Managers became part of the Managers' general assets.
The Managers' VAT liability to the Commissioners was independent of the ITCs' payments.
The two transactions (ITCs to Managers and Managers to Commissioners) are separate and cannot be collapsed.
Even if a claim in unjust enrichment was possible, it would have been excluded by s.80.
The statutory scheme creates an exhaustive code of remedies for suppliers and consumers.
The statutory scheme allows suppliers to reimburse consumers, subject to a limitation period.
The statutory scheme is compatible with EU law.
The European Court of Justice accepts a system where only suppliers can seek VAT reimbursement from tax authorities.
Consumers can seek restitution from suppliers, unless reimbursement is impossible or excessively difficult.
In this case, reimbursement by the supplier was possible, so a direct claim against the tax authorities was not appropriate.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the Commissioners' appeal and dismissed the ITCs' cross appeal.
Lord Reed gave the judgment, with which the rest of the Court agreed.
uksc-2016-0213: Mr Ivey sued a casino, Crockfords, to recover his winnings at Punto Banco.
Crockfords refused to pay out because it believed Mr Ivey cheated.
The appeal raises questions about the meaning of cheating at gambling.
The appeal also raises questions about the relevance of dishonesty to the concept of cheating.
Punto Banco is a variant of Baccarat and is not normally a game of skill.
The casino enjoys a small advantage in Punto Banco, taken over all the play.
In Punto Banco at Crockfords, the casino had a 1.24% advantage if the player wins.
In Punto Banco at Crockfords, the casino had a 1.06% advantage if the banker wins.
Edge sorting is possible due to tiny differences on the edges of playing cards.
A sharp-eyed person can see which long edge of a card is facing the table.
Edge sorting can be useful if cards are presented with specific edges facing the table.
Edge sorting can help identify high-value cards in Punto Banco.
Using edge sorting in Punto Banco can give the player a 6.5% edge over the house.
Mr Ivey and his associate, Ms Sun, played Punto Banco at Crockfords on 20 and 21 August 2012.
Mr Ivey openly admitted to using edge sorting during the game.
Mr Ivey asked the senior croupier to reuse the same shoe of cards if he indicated a win.
Ms Sun asked the croupier to turn the cards in a particular manner based on superstition.
The croupier was unaware of the significance of Ms Sun's request.
The procedure of turning cards was followed until the shoe was finished.
Mr Ivey indicated he had won, and the cards were reshuffled.
A machine shuffler was used to shuffle the cards without rotating them.
Mr Ivey could identify high-value cards after the reshuffle.
Mr Ivey's betting accuracy increased sharply after identifying high-value cards.
Mr Ivey's total winnings over the two days were 7.7 million.
Nine days after play, Crockfords refused to pay Mr Ivey's winnings.
The High Court held that Mr Ivey's use of edge sorting was cheating.
The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's finding that Mr Ivey cheated.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Mr Ivey's appeal.
Lord Hughes gave the judgment, with which other justices agreed.
The parties' contract implied that neither would cheat.
uksc-2017-0031: An EU citizen with a permanent right of residence in a host member state may have that right removed in the case of abuse of rights or fraud, such as marriages of convenience.
Ms Sadovska is a citizen of Lithuania.
Ms Sadovska moved to the United Kingdom in 2007 and has lived and worked there lawfully since.
Ms Sadovska acquired a right of permanent residence in the UK as an EU citizen pursuant to Directive 2004/38/EC.
Mr Malik is a citizen of Pakistan who entered the UK with a student visa in May 2011.
Mr Malik remained in the UK unlawfully after his visa expired in April 2013, in breach of section 10(1)(a) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999.
Ms Sadovska and Mr Malik maintained that they have been in a relationship since February 2013.
Ms Sadovska and Mr Malik decided to marry in January 2014.
On 11 April 2014, the appellants' solicitors notified the Home Office in Glasgow that they intended to marry on 17 April 2014.
Immigration officers interviewed the appellants separately before the wedding and then detained them.
Both appellants were served with notice that they were persons liable to removal from the UK.
Mr Malik was liable to removal as an overstayer.
Ms Sadovska was liable to removal for giving the Secretary of State reasonable grounds to suspect abuse of her EU right of residence.
The appellants appealed to the First tier Tribunal.
The judge held that the burden of proof was on the appellants to establish that their proposed marriage was not a marriage of convenience.
The appellants appealed unsuccessfully to the Upper Tribunal and to the First Division of the Inner House.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal and remitted the case for a full re-hearing by the First tier Tribunal.
Lady Hale gave the only substantive judgment in the case.
The European Commission's 2014 Communication explained that a marriage of convenience is one contracted with the predominant purpose of enjoying the right of free movement.
The Directive requires member states to facilitate the entry and residence of the partner of an EU citizen if it is a durable relationship, duly attested.
Both appellants enjoyed rights under articles 8 and 12 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
The 2006 Regulations permitted the Secretary of State to take steps to remove Ms Sadovska on the basis of reasonable grounds to suspect a marriage of convenience.
The tribunal had to form its own view of the facts from the evidence presented.
The burden of proof was on the Secretary of State to establish that the proposed marriage was one of convenience.
The Supreme Court concluded that the tribunal had not properly analyzed Ms Sadovska's rights.
The appeal was allowed and the case was remitted for a full rehearing by the First tier Tribunal.
The inconsistencies in the appellants' interviews will be considered along with evidence supporting a genuine relationship.
The circumstances in which the interviews took place will also be taken into account in the rehearing.
The appellants' ECHR rights did not add anything further to their claims.
ECHR rights would not prevent a state from taking steps to prevent sham marriages if it could show the marriage was indeed a sham.
uksc-2017-0075: Ms Rhuppiah entered the UK in 1997 with leave to reside as a student for three months.
The Home Secretary granted Ms Rhuppiah further leave to reside in the UK as a student on 12 occasions.
Some of Ms Rhuppiahs applications for leave to reside in the UK were made after the previous leave had expired.
Ms Rhuppiah met Ms Charles, who suffers from ulcerative colitis, while they were studying at the same college.
Ulcerative colitis is a gravely debilitating condition.
Ms Rhuppiah and Ms Charles have resided together since 2001.
Ms Rhuppiah cooks food suitable for Ms Charles' medical condition.
Ms Rhuppiah accompanies Ms Charles to Bristol, to hospital and in effect everywhere.
Instead of paying Ms Rhuppiah for her care, Ms Charles provides her with largely free board and lodging.
Ms Rhuppiah is a Seventh Day Adventist.
Ms Rhuppiah cares for Ms Charles out of friendship, faith and habit.
If Ms Rhuppiah were to leave the UK, Ms Charles' health would be compromised.
If Ms Rhuppiah were to leave the UK, Ms Charles' life would be turned upside down.
If Ms Rhuppiah were to leave the UK, Ms Charles would have to turn to the state for care.
Ms Rhuppiahs final grant of leave expired in November 2009.
After her final grant of leave expired, Ms Rhuppiah twice failed to secure indefinite leave to remain in the UK.
Ms Rhuppiah's first failure to secure indefinite leave was due to her residence in the UK not always being lawful.
Ms Rhuppiah's second failure to secure indefinite leave was due to applying on the wrong form.
By the time Ms Rhuppiah reapplied, the Immigration Rules, HC395, had changed, which fatally affected her reapplication.

The Home Secretary was obliged to determine whether Ms Rhuppiahs reapplication could succeed outside the rules on the basis of her right to respect for private life under Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights.
