The Home Secretary's determination on this basis was negative.
Ms Rhuppiah challenged the Home Secretary's decision at the First tier Tribunal (FTT).

Section 117B(5) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 requires little weight to be given to an applicant's private life if it was established in the UK at a time when their immigration status was precarious.
The FTT dismissed Ms Rhuppiahs challenge, stating that section 117B(5) applied to her.
The FTT also stated that Ms Rhuppiah was not financially independent.
Section 117B(3) requires the Home Secretary to weigh against an applicant's right to respect for private life the consideration of financial independence.
Ms Rhuppiah depended on support from her father and from Ms Charles.
Ms Rhuppiah appealed unsuccessfully to the Upper Tribunal and the Court of Appeal.
Ms Rhuppiahs appeal has become academic because she has lived continuously in the UK long enough to secure leave to remain by a different route.
The Supreme Court heard the appeal due to the public importance of providing a definitive interpretation of the word "precarious" in section 117B(5).
uksc-2009-0167: The law requires that use of land must not be by force, stealth, or permission of the landowner.
The law considers how the matter would appear to a reasonable landowner.

It was difficult to determine how a reasonable landowner would conclude that residents were not asserting a right to take recreation on the disputed land based solely on their civility towards members of the golf club.
The inspector incorrectly assessed the significance of natural behavior by the residents.
The appeal would be allowed, and the council should register the land.
The Respondent argued that residents would have unqualified use of the land after registration, regardless of the landowner's wishes.
There would be a mismatch between how residents gained rights and what they could do after the green was registered.
Lords Walker and Rodger believed there was little danger of sudden diversification or intensification of use after registration under normal circumstances.
Lords Hope and Kerr found a broad equivalence between the use relied on to establish the right and the use after registration, though there may be some asymmetry in the manner of use.
Lord Brown stated that residents could increase their use of the land only if it did not conflict with the landowner's previous use.
Lord Hope suggested that the Government should review the consequences of village green registration as revealed by case law and the functioning of the registration system.
uksc-2014-0089: Mrs Cox worked as the catering manager at HM Prison Swansea.
Mrs Cox was responsible for all aspects of catering, including kitchen operations.
Mrs Cox supervised prisoners who worked in the kitchen alongside civilian staff.
On 10 September 2007, Mrs Cox instructed prisoners to transport kitchen supplies.
During the task, a prisoner named Mr Inder accidentally dropped a sack of rice on Mrs Cox's back.
Mrs Cox sustained an injury as a result of Mr Inder's negligence.
Mrs Cox filed a claim against the Ministry of Justice in the Swansea County Court.
The County Court judge found Mr Inder negligent but dismissed the claim due to lack of vicarious liability.
The Court of Appeal overturned the County Court's decision, finding vicarious liability applicable.
The case was appealed to the Supreme Court by the Ministry of Justice.
The Supreme Court heard the case alongside Mohamud v WM Morrison Supermarkets plc.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the Ministry of Justice's appeal.
Lord Reed delivered the lead judgment, with which other justices agreed.
Lord Reed provided guidance on the relationship necessary for vicarious liability.
In the Christian Brothers case, five factors were mentioned for imposing vicarious liability.
The five factors from Christian Brothers are not equally significant.
The first factor, the defendant's ability to compensate, is not independently significant.
The fifth factor, control over the tortfeasor, is less significant in modern contexts.
The remaining three factors are interrelated and include the tort being part of the defendant's business.
The tortfeasor's activity must be part of the defendant's business and for its benefit.
The defendant creates a risk of the tort by assigning the activity to the tortfeasor.
Vicarious liability can apply beyond employment relationships if the tortfeasor is integrated into the defendant's operations.
The defendant does not need to be engaged in commercial activities for vicarious liability.
The defendant must derive benefit from the tortfeasor's activities in furtherance of its interests.
The tortfeasor must carry out activities assigned by the defendant as part of its operation.
The defendant must create a risk of the tort by assigning the activity to the tortfeasor.
Prisoners working in kitchens are integrated into the prison's operations.
The activities of prisoners in the kitchen are an integral part of the prison's operations.
The prison service recognizes the risk of negligent acts by prisoners and provides health and safety training.
The prisoners work under the direction of prison staff.
The Supreme Court ruled that the prison service is vicariously liable for Mr Inder's negligence.
The Ministry of Justice's argument about rehabilitation as the sole purpose of prisoner work was rejected.
Penal policy also aims to have prisoners contribute to the cost of their upkeep.
Prisoners working in the kitchen provide direct benefit to the prison service.
The requirement for prisoners to work binds them into a closer relationship with the prison service.
Payment of a wage is not essential for vicarious liability.
The prison does not need an unrestricted workforce pool for vicarious liability.
Prisoners working in the kitchen are selected with consideration for the risks involved.
If the criteria from Christian Brothers are met, re-assessment of fairness is generally unnecessary.
The criteria ensure vicarious liability is imposed where it is fair, just, and reasonable.
uksc-2014-0023: Mr Aaron Hunt was born on 17 April 1991.
Mr Aaron Hunt suffers from ADHD, learning difficulties, and behavioural problems.
North Somerset Council is statutorily required to secure access to educational and recreational leisure time activities for Mr Hunt.
North Somerset Council approved a reduction of 364,793 from its youth services budget for 2012/2013.
Mr Hunt brought judicial review proceedings against the Council's decision.
Mr Hunt argued the Council failed its duty under section 507B of the Education Act 1996.
Mr Hunt argued the Council failed its public sector equality duty under section 149 of the Equality Act 2010.
Mr Hunt sought a declaration that the Council's decision was unlawful and an order to quash it.
Wyn Williams J asked for written submissions on relief if he found in favour of Mr Hunt.
Mr Hunt's barristers sought a quashing order but did not mention a declaration.
Wyn Williams J rejected Mr Hunt's challenges to the legality of the decision.
Mr Hunt was ordered to pay the Council's costs, with a proviso against enforcement.
The Court of Appeal allowed Mr Hunt's appeal on both grounds.
The Court of Appeal refused to make a quashing order.
The Court of Appeal ordered Mr Hunt to pay half of the Council's costs.
Mr Hunt's barristers did not make alternative submissions about declaratory relief.
The Council's barristers prepared a draft order stating the appeal was dismissed.
Mr Hunt's barristers stated the parties were agreed on the order except for costs.
Mr Hunt appealed to the Supreme Court regarding a declaration and costs.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal in relation to costs.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal in relation to declaratory relief.
Lord Toulson delivered the judgment of the Court.
Lord Toulson rejected Mr Hunt's argument for a declaration of his own initiative.
The Court of Appeal's judgment already ruled the Council acted unlawfully.
A court is not required to make declaratory orders if not requested by legal representatives.
The Court of Appeal erred in treating the Council as the successful party.
The Court of Appeal was only successful in a limited sense.
The Court of Appeal judgment provided a lesson for local authorities on equality duty.
The Court of Appeal should have considered Mr Hunt's costs if the Council acted unlawfully.
Mr Hunt should recover two thirds of his costs subject to written submissions.
uksc-2010-0244: The appeal concerns the liability of a local authority to pay the costs of a party to care proceedings.
The proceedings involved two children whose parents were separated.
The local authority applied for a care order under section 31(2) of the Children Act 1989.
The application was in response to allegations of sexual abuse by the children's father and six other men.
The children's grandparents were alleged to have colluded in the abuse.
The six men and the grandparents were joined as interveners in the care proceedings.
The judge conducted a lengthy fact-finding hearing.
The judge exonerated five of the six men and the grandparents of any abuse.
The interveners were entitled to be represented at the hearing.
The six men qualified for legal aid, but the grandparents did not.
The interveners incurred costs of £52,000, which they met by taking out a mortgage on their house.
The interveners applied for an order that the local authority pay their costs.
The application was based on the interveners' success in defending the allegations.
It was accepted that the local authority acted reasonably in bringing the proceedings.
The judge refused the application, stating that costs are not usually ordered in child cases unless conduct was unreasonable or reprehensible.
The Court of Appeal allowed the grandparents' appeal, holding that costs could be awarded in discrete fact-finding hearings.
The Supreme Court granted permission to appeal due to the important point of principle raised.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the appeal.
The Court held that the general practice of not awarding costs in care proceedings should not be an exception in discrete fact-finding hearings.
Lord Phillips delivered the judgment of the court.
Family proceedings depart from the general rule that the unsuccessful party pays the costs of the successful party.
This is because of special considerations, particularly where children's interests are at stake.
It is usual in child proceedings for no order to be made in relation to costs.
Care proceedings often involve allegations of misconduct towards a child by a parent.
The object of the proceedings is to reach a decision in the child's best interests.
The decision to have a split hearing is a matter of case management.
The question of awarding costs against a public authority is distinct from the issue of public funding.
The current arrangements may lead to injustice for interveners like the grandparents.
It does not follow that justice demands compensating local authorities for deficiencies in public funding.
A local authority has a duty to investigate reports of significant harm to a child and instigate care proceedings if there are reasonable grounds.
uksc-2017-0106: Until 1960, Cyprus was a colony of the UK.
In 1960, Cyprus became an independent Republic under the Cyprus Act and a treaty between the UK, Turkey, Greece, and Cyprus.
The territory of the new Republic of Cyprus excluded the areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia, which remained under UK sovereignty as Sovereign Base Areas (SBAs).
Article 40(1) of the 1951 Convention and the 1967 Protocol allows a state to extend the Convention to territories for which it is responsible.
In 1956, the UK notified the UN Secretary General that it would extend the Convention to Cyprus subject to certain reservations.
Cyprus acceded to the Convention in 1963 and to the Protocol in 1968.
The UK has never made a specific notification regarding the extension of the Convention to the SBAs after Cyprus independence.
Six refugees boarded a ship in Lebanon in October 1998, which foundered off the coast of Cyprus.
On 8 October 1998, 75 passengers, including the six refugees, were airlifted to safety by RAF helicopters and brought to Akrotiri in Cyprus.
The refugees were accepted as lawful refugees under the Convention by the SBA Administration.
The SBA Administration sought UK government permission to resettle the refugees in the UK, but this was not accepted by Ministers.
The refugees have lived in disused and unsatisfactory service accommodation in the SBA since 1998.
Further refugee arrivals in 2000 and 2001 led to disputes between the SBAs and Cyprus over responsibility for refugees.
The UK and Cyprus entered into a Memorandum of Understanding in 2003 regarding illegal migrants and asylum seekers.
The 2003 Memorandum provided for the UK to fund governmental services for refugees provided by Cyprus.
The 2003 Memorandum did not apply to refugees who arrived in the SBAs before its conclusion.
The SBA Administrator enacted the Refugee Ordinance 2003 to implement Convention rights within the SBAs.
The Appellants claim that Cyprus and the SBA Administration agreed in 2005 to apply the 2003 Memorandum to all refugees, regardless of arrival date.
This 2005 agreement was never put in writing.
The Respondents refused to accept responsibility for them being transferred to Cyprus without their consent.
The Respondents continued to press for admission to the UK with the support of the UNHCR.
In 2013, the Respondents formally requested admission to the UK.
The Secretary of State refused entry to the Respondents on 25 November 2014.
The Respondents challenged the decision on the grounds that it was inconsistent with the Convention.
The High Court held that the Convention did not extend to the SBAs but quashed the Secretary of State's decision for procedural reasons.
The Court of Appeal declared that the Convention does extend to the SBAs and directed the Secretary of State to make a fresh decision.
The Secretary of State refused to admit the Respondents in 2017, citing Cyprus as an alternative resettlement option.
The Supreme Court ruled that the Convention applies to the SBAs and left further issues for determination.
The Supreme Court invited further submissions on unresolved issues related to the UK's obligations under the Convention.
The Court emphasized that international courts will interpret the Convention in line with its object and purpose.
uksc-2019-0028: The appellant was arrested in the United Kingdom in 2017 and charged with one count of conspiracy to commit torture and seven counts of torture.
The charges relate to events in the early stages of the first Liberian civil war in 1990.
The National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL) took control of parts of Liberia during the early stages of the first Liberian civil war.
Charles Taylor became President of Liberia in 1997.
The point of law raised in the appeal concerns the correct interpretation of the term "person acting in an official capacity" in section 134(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 1988.
The prosecution argued that the NPFL was the de facto military government with effective control of the relevant area at the time of the alleged offences.
The appellant denied involvement in the offences and claimed she did not act in an official capacity for the NPFL.
The appellant made an application to dismiss the charges.
The judge concluded that section 134 applies to individuals who act in a non-private capacity as part of an authority wielding entity during armed conflict.
The judge ruled that there was a case to answer on all counts.
The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, holding that section 134 CJA is not confined to individuals acting on behalf of a State.
The Court of Appeal held that section 134 covers any person who acts otherwise than in a private and individual capacity for or on behalf of an organisation or body exercising governmental functions.
The appellant appealed the decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court allowed the appeal to the limited extent of remitting the matter to the judge for further consideration.
Lord Lloyd Jones gave the majority judgment, with which Lady Hale, Lord Wilson, and Lord Hodge agreed.
Lord Reed delivered a dissenting judgment.
Section 134 CJA implements obligations of the United Kingdom under the United Nations Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment 1984 (UNCAT).
The wording of section 134 CJA must bear the same meaning as in article 1 of UNCAT.
The principles governing the interpretation of treaties are found in articles 31 and 32 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties 1969 (VCLT).
The ordinary meaning of the words in section 134(1) describes a person performing official administrative or governmental functions.
The object of UNCAT was not to outlaw torture but to strengthen the prohibition that already exists in international law.
The drafting history indicates that torture by public officials for purposes connected with their public functions was considered more serious than that inflicted by a private person.
The conduct of rebels exercising governmental functions over the civilian population is the concern of the international community.
The appellants suggested reading gives rise to anomalies concerning issues of recognition of States and governments.
The offence applies without distinction between recognised and unrecognised States.
Resort to State practice in the recognition or non-recognition of governments cannot provide a uniform standard for applying the Convention.

The majority concluded that a person acting in an official capacity in section 134(1) CJA includes someone acting for or on behalf of an organisation exercising governmental functions over the civilian population.
The exercise of a governmental function is a core requirement, which must be distinguished from purely military activity.
The question is whether the entity has established sufficient control, authority, and organisation to become an authority exercising official or quasi-official powers.
The matter was remitted to the judge to reconsider whether there is sufficient evidence to conclude that the appellant was acting in an official capacity.
uksc-2010-0236: The three respondents were part of a vitamins cartel.
The European Commission found the cartel infringed Article 81 of the EC Treaty.
The Commission imposed fines on the cartelists.
The cartelists were given until 31 January 2002 to appeal against the infringement decision and/or the fine.
Only BASF exercised the right of appeal.
BASF appealed only the amount of the fine.
No appeal was made against the Commission's decision that an infringement had occurred.
The Court of First Instance reduced the fine amount on 15 March 2006.
The deadline for further appeal expired on 25 May 2006.
No further appeal was lodged after 25 May 2006.
Section 47A of the Competition Act 1998 allows follow-on claims for damages.
On 12 March 2008, the four appellants sought to bring follow-on claims against the respondents.
The respondents argued the claims were time-barred due to a two-year limitation period.
The respondents claimed the limitation period started on 31 January 2002.
The appellants argued the limitation period started on 25 May 2006.
The UK Competition Appeal Tribunal ruled the appellants' interpretation was correct.
The respondents sought permission to appeal the CAT's decision.
The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal.
The Court of Appeal held that only infringement decisions determine the start of the limitation period.
The Court of Appeal stated the CAT had no power to extend the time for follow-on claims.
The appellants appealed to the Supreme Court on grounds of legal uncertainty.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
The Supreme Court found no failure to comply with EU principles of effectiveness and legal certainty.
The statutory limitation period is sufficiently clear, precise, and foreseeable.
National limitation periods are permissible under EU law.
EU law does not require absolute clarity in statutory limitation periods.
Section 47A of the 1998 Act satisfies the requirement for clarity and foreseeability.
The limitation period commenced following the expiry of the time for appealing the Commission's infringement decision.
The Competition Act 1998 distinguishes between infringement and penalty decisions.
The operation of the statutory time limit does not render it excessively difficult to exercise EU law rights.
uksc-2018-0225: The appeals concern the treatment for rating purposes of ATMs situated in supermarkets or shops owned and operated by the retailers.
The two main issues are whether the sites of the ATMs are separate hereditaments and who was in rateable occupation of those hereditaments.
Appeals relating to some 10,000 other sites have been stayed pending the final decision in these cases.
The appellants in this case are the valuation officers; the respondents are the retailers, banks, and ATM operators.
The ATMs are installed and operated not directly by the retailers but under contractual arrangements with related banking companies.
The ATMs fall into four categories: external, internal, convenience store, and moveable ATMs.
External ATMs are found in the external walls of stores and can be used 24 hours a day.
External ATMs are chained to the floor of the cash room of the stores and are connected to the stores electricity supplies.
The money dispensed by external ATMs is owned by the bank but kept in the cash room of the stores.
Internal ATMs are available only for use within the stores and can only be accessed within the stores opening hours.
For all other practical purposes, the arrangements for internal ATMs are the same as with the external ATMs.
Convenience store ATMs are similar to other external ATMs.
Convenience store ATMs lead to greater interference with the stores workings due to reduced floor space.
Moveable ATMs can be unbolted from the floor and moved without difficulty.
The only example of a moveable ATM on appeal is at Tescos Nottingham store.
A hereditament is defined in s.115(1) of the General Rate Act 1967 as property which is or may become liable to a rate.
The definition of hereditament is adopted into the current statutory scheme by s.64(1) of the Local Government Finance Act 1988.
Rateable occupation is determined by reference to the rules under the 1967 Act, as provided in s.65(2) of the 1988 Act.
The 2000 Regulations assume that an ATM has no effect on the rateable value of the hereditament on which it is sited.
The Valuation Tribunal for England held that all ATMs were situated on hereditaments rateably occupied separately from the host stores.
The Upper Tribunal held that, save for the moveable ATM, all ATMs were situated on hereditaments separate from the host stores.
The Court of Appeal held that none of the ATMs were rateably occupied separately from the host stores.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeals.
Lord Carnwath gave the sole judgment, with which the other Justices agree.
The argument about whether the sites of the ATMs are separate hereditaments has two aspects.
The 2000 Regulations' assumption about rateable value does not apply to the question of whether there is a hereditament that needs to be valued.
Previous case law establishes that a hereditament is a self-contained piece of property.
The Upper Tribunal was entitled to define the boundaries of fixed ATMs to satisfy the geographical test for self-containment.
The moveable ATM was found to have qualities of impermanence and mobility.
The second question is whether the retailers or the banks were in rateable occupation of the ATMs.
uksc-2017-0214: Tadalafil is the generic name for a drug sold under the brand name CIALIS for the treatment of erectile dysfunction.
Sildenafil, sold under the brand name VIAGRA, is a competitor to tadalafil.
The patent in question is EP(UK) 1,173,181, owned by ICOS and licensed to Eli Lilly.
The 181 patent was filed on 26 April 2000 and granted on 15 October 2003.
The 181 patent relates to the use of tadalafil in a dosage form for the treatment of erectile dysfunction.
The case involves section 3 of the Patents Act 1977, which assesses whether an invention involves an inventive step.
Section 2(2) of the 1977 Act defines an invention as involving an inventive step if it is not obvious to a person skilled in the art.
The state of the art includes all matter made available to the public before the priority date of the invention.
The court must assess whether an invention is obvious by considering the state of the art at the priority date.
Lilly claims that the essence of the invention is the discovery that tadalafil is effective in treating ED at a low dose with minimal side effects.
The discovery allows tadalafil to be taken daily for chronic use, unlike sildenafil which is approved for on-demand use.
The respondents initiated proceedings to revoke the 181 patent.
Lilly defended the revocation claim and counterclaimed that the respondents were threatening to infringe its patent.
The High Court found that a 5mg daily dose of tadalafil was not obvious for treating ED.
The High Court concluded that the 181 patent involves an inventive step.
The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal, stating that the 181 patent lacked an inventive step.
Lilly appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
Lord Hodge provided the sole judgment with which the other justices agreed.
The purpose of a patent, since the 1623 Statute of Monopolies, has been to encourage innovation.
The patent bargain involves the inventor obtaining a monopoly in exchange for disclosing the invention to the public.
English courts often use the Windsurfing/Pozzoli structure when assessing obviousness under section 3 of the 1977 Act.
The EPO often uses the problem and solution approach when assessing obviousness.
Courts must not apply either approach in a mechanistic way when assessing obviousness.
The question of obviousness must be considered on the facts of each case.
The Court considers factors such as whether something was obvious to try at the priority date.
The routine nature of research and established practices are relevant considerations in assessing obviousness.
The burden and cost of the research program are relevant to determining obviousness.
The necessity for and nature of value judgments during testing are relevant considerations.
The existence of alternative or multiple paths of research indicates that the invention may not be obvious.
uksc-2012-0007: The appellants were charged with theft in Northern Ireland.
The offence was alleged to have taken place on 6 October 2007.
A stack of building materials was found removed from the owners depot.
The appellants were found nearby in a van but claimed they were waiting innocently.
The appellants were arrested and their fingerprints were taken at the police station using an electronic fingerprint scanner called Livescan.
The Livescan machine has been commonly used by police in the UK, including in Northern Ireland, for a number of years.
A fingerprint matching Elliotts left thumb was found on packaging of the building materials.
Article 61 of the Police and Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order sets out the powers of the police to take fingerprints without consent.
Between 1 March 2007 and 12 January 2010, article 61(8B) required electronic fingerprint devices to be approved by the Secretary of State.
No approval was ever given to any device, including Livescan, until 29 March 2009.
Article 61(8B) was later repealed by the Policing and Crime Act 2009.
At the time the fingerprints were taken from the appellants, there was no approval for the Livescan machine, which was a breach of article 61(8B).
The appellants were convicted at trial and no issue over the fingerprints was raised.
After the lack of approval for the Livescan device was noticed, the appellants appealed to the County Court.
The County Court declared the fingerprint evidence inadmissible and acquitted the appellants.
The Public Prosecution Service appealed to the Court of Appeal, which reinstated the appellants' convictions.
The appellants argued that the lack of approval for the Livescan device made the fingerprints automatically inadmissible.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.
Lord Hughes gave the judgment of the court.
The statute does not specify the consequences of using an unapproved fingerprint device.
The common law rule states that evidence obtained unlawfully does not automatically become inadmissible.
The common law rule extends to evidence created by an unlawful process.
The purpose of article 61(8B) was not to make fingerprints from unapproved devices inadmissible.
A defendant could lawfully refuse to give a fingerprint on an unapproved device.
The requirement for approval of fingerprint devices is not analogous to breath tests or speed guns.
Breath tests and speed guns capture a snapshot of the suspect's activity and are often the offence itself.
Fingerprints can be reproduced at any time and are not unique to the moment of collection.
The ease of verifying fingerprint accuracy shows no need for inadmissibility of unapproved devices.
No challenge was ever made by the appellants to the accuracy of the fingerprints taken by the Livescan device.
The Protection for Freedoms Act 2012 and Criminal Justice (Northern Ireland) Act 2013 support the Supreme Court's interpretation of the legislation.
uksc-2012-0250: Mr George was born in Grenada in 1984.
Mr George came to the UK in 1995 at the age of 11.
Mr George was granted indefinite leave to remain (ILR) in the UK in March 2000.
Mr George has a partner with whom he has a daughter born in 2005.
Mr George and his partner do not live together.
Mr George's daughter sees him reasonably often and sometimes stays with him.
Mr George has been convicted of seven different offences since 2000.
Mr George's offences include supply of cocaine.
Mr George's offences include possession with intent to supply heroin.
Mr George's offences include possession with intent to supply cocaine.
The Secretary of State decided that Mr George's deportation would be conducive to the public good.
Mr George was liable to deportation under section 3(5) of the Immigration Act 1971.
A deportation order was served upon Mr George in January 2007.
Mr George unsuccessfully challenged the deportation decision.
A deportation order was made against Mr George on 24 April 2008.
The deportation order invalidated Mr George's ILR under section 5(1) of the Immigration Act 1971.
Mr George applied to the Secretary of State arguing that his deportation would breach his Article 8 ECHR rights.
The Secretary of State rejected Mr George's application.
An immigration judge allowed Mr George's appeal on 31 March 2009.
The judgment revoked Mr George's deportation order.
The question was whether Mr George's ILR revived after the revocation of the deportation order.
Mr George's solicitors believed his ILR would revive upon revocation of the deportation order.
The Secretary of State granted six months discretionary leave to remain (DLR) to Mr George on 2 August 2013.
The Secretary of State granted a further three years DLR after the initial six months.
Mr George judicially reviewed the decision not to reinstate ILR.
Mr George argued that section 5(1) and (2) of the Immigration Act 1971 required his ILR to be reinstated upon revocation of the deportation order.
The High Court dismissed Mr George's claim.
Mr George's appeal to the Court of Appeal was allowed.
The Secretary of State appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the Secretary of State's appeal.
uksc-2016-0210: Private pension schemes are required to provide some form of indexation to protect pension values against inflation.
Barnardos adopted a pension scheme that increases pensions by the lesser of 5% or the Retail Prices Index (RPI) rise.
The Retail Prices Index is defined as the General Index of Retail Prices published by the Department of Employment or any replacement adopted by the Trustees.
The critical clause in the definition allows the Trustees to adopt a replacement index without prejudicing Approval.
Barnardos argued that the clause empowers the Trustees to use the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) if RPI is no longer suitable.
Members of the scheme argued that the clause does not allow the Trustees to use CPI if RPI is still published.
The Trustees took a neutral stance on the dispute.
The Trustees sought a ruling on the meaning of the Definition.
The High Court ruled that the Definition does not allow the Trustees to adopt an index other than RPI unless RPI is discontinued.
Barnardos appealed the High Court's decision.
The Court of Appeal dismissed Barnardos' appeal by majority.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed Barnardos' appeal.
Lord Hodge delivered the sole judgment for the Supreme Court.
English courts must consider the nature and circumstances of the instrument when interpreting contracts or trusts.
Pension schemes are formal legal documents prepared by skilled legal draftsmen.
Pension schemes are designed to operate long-term, defining rights long after the original circumstances.
Members of pension schemes may not have easy access to legal advice or information about the scheme's history.
Courts should give weight to textual analysis when interpreting pension schemes.
Courts should avoid undue technicality and consider practical consequences of interpretations.
The Court concluded that RPI means the RPI or any replacement index adopted by the Trustees.
The word "replacement" in the definition suggests that RPI must first be replaced before a new index is adopted.
The discretion of the Trustees and the requirement to not prejudice CIR approval do not contradict the interpretation.
Consistency within the scheme's rules suggests the official authority, not the Trustees, replaces the index.
CIR guidance on approval does not influence the interpretation of the Definition.
Superseded rules do not assist in interpreting the Definition.
A provision allowing for the replacement of a cost of living index has a rational purpose.
The Court must interpret the scheme's rules without favoring either the employer or the members.
uksc-2017-0083: Broome Park is a substantial country estate near Canterbury.
Broome Park originally included the Mansion House, Elham House, and surrounding lands.
In 1967, Elham House and adjoining land were conveyed away.
Elham House is the alleged dominant tenement of the disputed easement.
The seller retained the rest of Broome Park, including the Mansion House (jointly the Park).
The Park is the alleged servient tenement.
In or before 1979, the Park was acquired by Gulf Investments Ltd to develop a timeshare and leisure complex.
The development included timeshare apartments in the Mansion House.
The development included a communal club house in the Mansion House with restaurant, TV, billiards, and gymnasium facilities.
The development included sporting and recreational facilities in the surrounding grounds.
The development included a full golf course, outdoor heated swimming pool, tennis and squash courts, and formal gardens.
Individual purchasers of timeshare units formed the Broome Park Owners Club.
The Broome Park Owners Club was indirectly granted free use of communal and leisure facilities in the Mansion House and surrounding grounds by a lease in August 1980.
Elham House was reacquired in November 1980.
Planning permission was obtained for the conversion and construction of 26 timeshare apartments using a freehold structure called Regency Villas.
Gulf Investments transferred Elham House to an associated company on 11 November 1981.
Elham House was then transferred to a trustee for intended timeshare owners on the following day.
Elham House was held for the benefit of the Regency Villas Owners Club members.
The Facilities Grant stated that the Transferee and its successors could use the swimming pool, golf course, squash courts, tennis courts, and other facilities on the adjoining estate.
Most of the relevant sporting and recreational facilities had been constructed by 1981.
The swimming pool fell into disuse and was filled in by 2000.
Other facilities such as the putting green, croquet lawn, jacuzzi, and roller skating rink were closed.
The riding stables were demolished.
The RVOC made voluntary contributions towards the cost of the facilities from about 1983.
Agreement about contributions broke down, leading to denial of RVOC members' rights by new owners of Broome Park.
The First Respondent and other Respondents claimed entitlement to free use of sporting and recreational facilities under an easement.
The Respondents sought an injunction to restrain interference with their use of the facilities.
The Respondents sought the return of sums paid for use of the facilities since 2009 as damages or restitution.
The Respondents succeeded in their claims at trial, except for recovery of payments before 2012.
The Court of Appeal upheld the main issue that the Facilities Grant amounted to an easement.
uksc-2015-0255: The appeal concerns the legality of the Lord Chancellor's attempt to introduce a residence test for civil legal aid under the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012.
Part 1 of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 came into force on 1 April 2013.
Section 9(1) of Part 1 of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 outlines the conditions under which civil legal services are available.
Section 9(2) of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 allows the Lord Chancellor to add to, vary, or omit services in Part 1 of Schedule 1.
In April 2013, the Ministry of Justice stated its intention to introduce a residence test for civil legal aid, with certain exceptions.
The Lord Chancellor decided to proceed with the proposal and issued a draft order for delegated legislation in 2014.
The draft order was laid before Parliament on 31 March 2014.
The Public Law Project applied to the High Court for a declaration that the draft order was unlawful on two grounds: ultra vires and unjustifiably discriminatory.
The Divisional Court held that the draft order was unlawful on both the ultra vires and discriminatory grounds.
The Lord Chancellor withdrew the draft order before any debate in the House of Lords could take place.
The Court of Appeal allowed the Lord Chancellor's appeal, finding the draft order intra vires and justifiable despite its discriminatory effect.
The Public Law Project appealed to the Supreme Court on both the ultra vires and discrimination grounds.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed the Public Law Project's appeal on the ultra vires issue.
Lord Neuberger provided the only judgment, which was agreed upon by the other justices.
The Public Law Project argued that excluding individuals based on personal characteristics unrelated to the legal issue or need is outside the scope of the Lord Chancellor's power.
The Supreme Court accepted the Public Law Project's argument that the draft order was outside the scope of the statutory power.
The Court upheld the supremacy of Parliament over the Executive by declaring the subordinate legislation unlawful.
Section 9(2)(b) of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 grants the power to vary or omit services, not to exclude individuals based on personal characteristics.
The draft order sought to reduce the class of individuals eligible for services based on residency, not to vary or omit services.
The interpretation of section 9(2) is supported by the wider statutory context of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012.
Each service in Schedule 1 is linked to a specific legal issue or claim, not to personal circumstances or characteristics.
Section 9(1) distinguishes between the qualification of services and the qualification of individuals for those services.
Section 11 of the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 identifies characteristics related to the issue, services, or financial need.
The draft order attempted to exclude individuals based on residence, which was not intended by the legislature.
Section 41(2)(b) allows for provisions based on a class of individual, but does not permit excluding a whole class based on residence.
Section 41 is intended to grant ancillary powers, not to extend the scope of section 9(2)(b) to exclude individuals based on residence.
The Supreme Court concluded that the draft order was ultra vires and did not need to address the discrimination issue.
The Supreme Court's decision reaffirmed the limits of the Lord Chancellor's power under section 9(2)(b).
The Court emphasized that the legislature did not intend for the exclusion of individuals based on residence under section 9(2)(b).
The Supreme Court's ruling upheld the principle of parliamentary supremacy over executive action.
uksc-2014-0079: The benefit cap was introduced by the Welfare Reform Act 2012 and implemented through the Benefit Cap (Housing Benefit) Regulations 2012.
The main issue in the appeal is whether the Regulations are unlawful under the Human Rights Act 1998.
The benefit cap is argued to have an unjustifiably discriminatory impact on women, violating their right to the peaceful enjoyment of their possessions under A1P1.

The cap applies when the total entitlement of a single person or couple to specified welfare benefits exceeds the average weekly earnings of a working household in Great Britain, net of tax and national insurance contributions.
The Regulations set the cap at 350 per week for a single claimant without dependent children and 500 for all other claimants.
Benefits included in the cap are housing benefit, child benefit, and child tax credit.
The Government justifies the scheme by stating it sets a reasonable limit on state support for non-working families, provides work incentives, and achieves public expenditure savings.
The cap does not apply to persons or families entitled to working tax credit.
Receipt of working tax credit requires lone parents to work at least 16 hours a week and couples with children to work a total of 24 hours a week, with one working at least 16 hours.
The cap affects a higher number of women than men due to the prevalence of single parent households, which are mostly headed by women.
The appellants are two lone mothers and their youngest children.
The application of the cap reduced the weekly income of SG by 75 and NS by 55.
The courts below ruled that the indirectly discriminatory impact of the scheme on lone parents, and therefore women, could be justified and the scheme was lawful.
The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by a majority of 3 to 2.
Lord Reed gave the lead judgment, with which Lord Hughes agreed.
Lord Carnwath concurred with the result but for different reasons.
Lady Hale and Lord Kerr each gave dissenting judgments.
Lord Reed acknowledged that the Regulations result in differential treatment of men and women in relation to welfare benefits, which constitute possessions under A1P1.
Lord Reed accepted that the aims of the cap are legitimate.

The appellants argued that the aim of setting a reasonable limit to benefits could be achieved by using the average income of working households inclusive of in-work benefits instead of their average earnings exclusive of benefits.
Lord Reed noted that the Act requires the cap to be set by reference to earnings.
The appellants also argued that the savings in public expenditure were marginal.
Lord Reed noted that although the short-term savings are a small proportion of the total welfare budget, they contribute to deficit reduction.
The cap is also intended to change behavior over the longer term.
The cap for households with children is equivalent to a gross annual salary of 35,000, which is higher than the earnings of half of the UK's working households.
Whether the cap should be higher is a political question, not for the courts to determine.
Affected households were given advance notice and assistance to adjust to the cap.
The differential impact of the cap results from including child-related benefits in the cap.
Excluding child-related benefits would reduce savings by 80-90% and compromise the achievement of the cap's legitimate aims.
No credible means were suggested by which the aims of the cap might be achieved without affecting more women than men.
uksc-2009-0129: Steve Allison was convicted on 9 September 2004 of four contraventions of section 4(3)(b) of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971.
The conviction involved being found guilty of being concerned in the supplying of cocaine and three other controlled drugs.
Steve Allison was sentenced to 8 years imprisonment by the trial judge.
Steve Allison appealed against both his conviction and sentence.
The appeal court refused his appeal against conviction on 7 November 2008.
The appeal court left his appeal against sentence to be heard on a date to be fixed.
One of the grounds of appeal related to the record of a police interview of John Stronach.
John Stronach had died before the trial.
The Crown introduced the interview of John Stronach into evidence in accordance with section 259(5) of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995.
The Crown did not disclose to the defence that John Stronach had previous convictions before or during the trial.
The Crown did not disclose that there were outstanding charges against John Stronach before or during the trial.
One of the outstanding charges against John Stronach related to events covered by the trial.
The appellants legal advisers were aware of the outstanding charges against John Stronach.
The Crown disclosed the previous convictions and outstanding charges against John Stronach only during the appeal.
The appellant argued that the Crown's failure to disclose the information violated his article 6 Convention rights.
The appeal court accepted that the failure to disclose Mr. Stronach's previous convictions was incompatible with the appellant's article 6(1) rights.
The appeal court did not find that the Crown's failure resulted in an unfair trial or miscarriage of justice.
The appeal court distinguished between Mr. Stronach's previous convictions and outstanding charges.
The appeal court did not consider outstanding charges important for the preparation of the defence or challenging the witness's credibility.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal, with Lord Rodger delivering the leading judgment.
The Supreme Court disagreed with the appeal court's view regarding the significance of outstanding charges.
The Supreme Court acknowledged that the presumption of innocence does not mean treating a charged individual as if no charge has been brought.
The Privy Council's decision in Holland v HM Advocate 2005 1 SC (PC) 3 supports the disclosure of outstanding charges against Crown witnesses.
The Crown accepts that the failure to disclose the outstanding charges was incompatible with the appellant's article 6(1) rights.
The only live issue in the appeal was the significance of the Crown's failure to disclose the outstanding charges.
The Supreme Court found no real possibility that the jury would have reached a different verdict if aware of the outstanding charges.
The Supreme Court concluded there was no miscarriage of justice.
The Crown does not deny that the outstanding charges against Mr. Stronach might have weakened the Crown's case.
The Crown accepts that the failure to disclose the charges was incompatible with the appellant's article 6(1) rights.
The Supreme Court is satisfied that the disclosure of the outstanding charges would not have made a material difference to the outcome.
uksc-2014-0110: The appeal concerns a repayment of overpaid VAT of approximately 125m received by Shop Direct Group (SDG).
Companies within the Littlewoods corporate group made substantial overpayments of VAT between 1978 and 1996.
The VAT overpayments were made based on an incorrect understanding of the law.
The VAT was wrongly calculated when goods were sold to agents of the supplier with a discount for commission.
VAT was paid to HMRC by the representative member of the Group under section 43 of the Value Added Tax Act 1994.
By 2007, all companies that made relevant supplies had permanently discontinued their trade.
In June 2003, the representative member of the Group claimed repayment of VAT under section 80 of the Value Added Tax Act 1994.
The claim included various payments that led to the VAT Repayment.
HMRC made the VAT Repayment in September 2007.
The VAT Repayment was received by SDG as the beneficial owner at the time of receipt.
The issue before the Supreme Court is whether the VAT Repayment is liable to corporation tax under the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1988.
Sections 103 and 106 of the ICTA imposed a charge to corporation tax on post cessation receipts from a trade.
The provisions were enacted to prevent tax avoidance by businesses choosing when to discontinue a business.
The First tier Tribunal, Upper Tribunal, and Court of Appeal all held that SDG was liable to corporation tax on the VAT Repayment.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed SDG's appeal.
Lord Hodge gave the judgment of the court, with the agreement of other justices.
The court concluded that section 103 does not contain an implicit restriction limiting the charge to tax on post cessation receipts to the former trader.
Section 103(1) requires only that the sums are received after the discontinuance.
Section 103 was designed to catch the fruit of the trade.
The aim of section 103 was to ensure that sums received from a discontinued trade were brought into a charge to tax.
The court rejected the argument that the VAT Repayment was the result of an intra-group arrangement.
The focus of section 103 is on the original source of the receipt.
The arrangements within the Group did not alter the original source of the VAT Repayment.
Section 106 of ICTA supports a wider interpretation of the scope of the section 103 charge.
Section 106(1) quantifies the section 103 charge at the amount of the consideration or the market value of the rights.
Section 106(2) disapplies section 103 if the transferee company is carrying on the continuing business.
The court concluded that the VAT Repayment was received by SDG as beneficial owner.
The VAT Repayment arose from the carrying on of the trade before discontinuance.
The VAT Repayment was not otherwise chargeable to tax.
The VAT Repayment is subject to a charge to corporation tax in the hands of SDG.
uksc-2016-0082: In July 2008, the Appellant was knocked over by a group of men in the centre of Huddersfield.
Two of the men were police officers, DS Willan and PC Dhurmea.
The third man was a suspected drug dealer named Williams.
The officers were attempting to arrest Williams when the incident occurred.
Williams backed into the Appellant, causing her to fall.
The three men fell on top of the Appellant, resulting in her injury.
The officers had foreseen that Williams would attempt to escape.
The officers did not notice that the Appellant was in the immediate vicinity.
The principal question in the appeal was whether the officers owed a duty of care to the Appellant.
The judge held that the officers were negligent but immune from negligence claims.
The Court of Appeal found that most claims against the police in their core functions fail the Caparo test.
The Court of Appeal concluded that Williams caused the harm to the Appellant.
The case concerned an omission by the police, not a positive act.
The Supreme Court considered whether the existence of a duty of care depends on the Caparo test.
The Supreme Court considered whether the police have a general duty of care when performing core functions.
The Supreme Court considered whether the case involved a positive act or an omission.
The Supreme Court considered whether the police owed a duty of care to the Appellant.
The Supreme Court considered whether the Court of Appeal was correct to overturn the judge's finding of negligence.
The Supreme Court considered whether the Appellant's injuries were caused by a breach of duty.
The Appeal was allowed.
Lord Reed gave the lead judgment, with which Lady Hale and Lord Hodge agreed.
Lord Mance and Lord Hughes allowed the appeal but reached a different conclusion on the existence of a duty of care.
The Supreme Court held that the Caparo test is not always applicable in negligence claims.
The Supreme Court stated that the Caparo test is only needed in novel cases where established principles do not apply.
The case involved the application of established principles of negligence, not the Caparo test.
The police, like other public authorities, are subject to liability for causing personal injury under the general law of tort.
The police do not have a private law duty towards individual members of the public in their core functions.
The common law does not normally impose liability for omissions or failure to prevent harm caused by third parties.
The case of Hill v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire does not support a general immunity for the police.
The police may owe a duty of care to protect an individual from danger they themselves create.
uksc-2018-0030: The Attorney General applied to the Supreme Court under paragraph 34 of Schedule 10 to the Northern Ireland Act 1998.
Paragraph 34 allows the Attorney General to refer devolution issues not subject to proceedings to the Supreme Court.
A devolution issue includes a question about the validity of a Department of Northern Ireland's function under section 24 of the 1998 Act.
Section 24(1)(a) of the 1998 Act prohibits Departments from making, confirming, or approving subordinate legislation incompatible with ECHR rights.
The Welfare Reform (Northern Ireland) Order 2015 was commenced by the Secretary of State for universal credit provisions from 27 September 2017.
The commencement of universal credit provisions was for claims in no. 1 relevant districts.
The Secretary of State appoints the dates for commencement of legislation, using a legislative technique requiring action by the Northern Ireland Department for Communities.
The 2017 Order defines no. 1 relevant districts as postcodes specified in the List of no. 1 Relevant Districts.
The Department for Communities is responsible for issuing the list of no. 1 relevant districts.
The Department for Communities also issues lists for no. 3 and no. 2 relevant districts.
The Attorney General claims the universal credit provisions breach several ECHR articles and are therefore invalid under section 24 of the 1998 Act.
The Attorney General argues that the Department for Communities' publication of lists is necessary to implement the Secretary of State's commencement orders.
The Attorney General asserts that the Department's publication of lists constitutes an act incompatible with the ECHR and invalid under section 24.
The Department for Communities denies that its role in issuing lists constitutes an act raising a devolution issue.
The Department for Communities claims its role is administrative support and the legal effect of the lists comes from the Secretary of State's act.
The Supreme Court refused the Attorney General's application to refer the issue under paragraph 34 of Schedule 10.
The Supreme Court judgment was delivered by Lord Kerr, with Lady Hale and Lord Reed agreeing.
The Court noted that acts by the Secretary of State or Westminster departments do not fall under section 24 of the 1998 Act.
A devolution issue requires an act or function by a Northern Ireland minister or department to be invalid under section 24.
Section 24 of the 1998 Act prohibits acts that are incompatible with the ECHR, including subordinate legislation.
Acts ancillary to the enactment of subordinate legislation may be caught by section 24 of the 1998 Act.
The Court considered that the Department's provision of postcode lists could be an ancillary act under section 24.
The Court found that the provision of lists does not raise a devolution issue because it is not incompatible with the ECHR on its own.
The Court cited a previous reference where it declined to accept a devolution issue in parallel proceedings.
A challenge to the universal credit provisions will be heard on appeal from the English Court of Appeal.
The Attorney General may intervene in the appeal of the universal credit provisions.
The Court emphasized that the incompatibility lies with the Secretary of State's introduction of universal credit, not the Department's act of publishing lists.
For a devolution issue to arise, the departmental act must be capable of being incompatible with the ECHR.
The publication of lists is not in itself capable of giving rise to an incompatibility with the ECHR.
The Court concluded that it is not appropriate to accept a reference under paragraph 34 of Schedule 10 for the publication of lists.
uksc-2017-0006: The appellants are defendants indicted for offences of unauthorised use of trademarks under section 92(1) of the Trade Marks Act 1994.
An offence under section 92(1) is committed if a person applies to goods a sign identical to, or likely to be mistaken for, a registered trade mark.
An offence under section 92(1) is also committed if a person sells goods which bear such a sign.
An offence under section 92(1) is also committed if a person possesses in the course of a business any such goods with a view to committing an offence under (b).
The allegations against the appellants are that they are engaged in the bulk import and subsequent sale of goods bearing registered trademarks, manufactured abroad, in countries outside the EU.
A significant portion of the goods said to be sold by the appellants were manufactured with the permission of the trademark proprietor.
The goods in question were then sold without the trademark proprietor's consent.
The appellants describe the goods as grey market goods, distinguishing them from true counterfeits.
At a preparatory hearing in the Crown Court, the appellants argued that the sale of grey goods attracts civil liability, but not criminal liability under section 92(1).
The appellants argued that subsection (1)(b) of section 92 refers back to (1)(a), applying only to goods where the trademark has been applied without the consent of the proprietor.
The trial judge and the Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) rejected the appellants' submission.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeals.
Lord Hughes gave the lead judgment, with which the rest of the Court agreed.
Grey market goods are caught by the criminal offence in section 92(1).
The appellants contended that the construction of section 92(1) must be rejected.
The plain reading of section 92(1)(b) refers back to the sign mentioned in (1)(a), which is a sign identical to, or likely to be mistaken for, a registered trade mark.
Section 92(1)(b) covers the unauthorised sale of any goods bearing a trademark, regardless of whether the trademark was applied with consent.
The reference back to (1)(a) in (1)(b) does not incorporate the requirement that the sign has been applied without the consent of the proprietor.
The offences in (a), (b), and (c) are not cumulative, but separate.
The requirement that the use of the sign is without the consent of the proprietor applies to each type of use specified in section 92(1).
The predecessor of section 92, section 58A of the Trademarks Act 1938, also covered grey market goods.
The appellants' contention that the more stringent test for intention in section 58A confined criminal liability to true counterfeits must be rejected.
There is no ambiguity in the language of section 92(1) to justify investigating the Parliamentary debate at the passing of the 1994 Act.
The appellants did not contend that Parliament considered a difference between true counterfeits and grey market goods.
There is no point at which it can be suggested that Parliament plainly confined itself to criminalising fake goods and abjured the criminalising of grey market goods.
The authorities relied on by the appellants do not assist here, as they were not addressing any difference between fake goods and unauthorised goods on the grey market.
The appellants are correct that section 12 of the 1994 Act limits further objection to the use of the mark to special cases such as changes or impairments to the goods.
The concept of exhaustion means that there is no infringement of the mark as a matter of civil law, and thus no criminal offence.
The distinction between the two categories suggested by the appellant is not cut and dried, but both are clear infringements of the rights of the trademark proprietor.
The plain meaning of the Act is that it is unlawful to put grey goods on the market just as it is to put fake ones on the market.
uksc-2019-0001: The appeal raises two important questions about the interpretation and application of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990.
The case concerns the correct treatment of a pair of early 18th century lead urns resting on limestone pedestals.
The items were originally commissioned for a historic garden at Wrest Park in Bedfordshire.
The items remained at Wrest Park until 1939.
The items have been moved a number of times since 1939.
In 1973, the items were moved by Major Dill (Mr Dill's father) to the garden of Idlicote House.
In June 1986, the items were added to the list of listed buildings under s.54 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1971.
There is no record of notice of the listing having been served.
The items were included in the register of local land charges in due course.
In 1993, Mr Dill (the appellant) acquired the house and the items.
Mr Dill was not aware of the items' presence on the list.
In 2009, Mr Dill sold the items at auction.
On 29 April 2015, the district council informed Mr Dill that listed building consent was required for the items to be removed.
Mr Dill's retrospective application for consent was refused on 11 February 2016.
On 26 April 2016, the council issued a listed building enforcement notice requiring the reinstatement of the items at Idlicote House.
Mr Dill appealed against the refusal of listed building consent and the issuing of the enforcement notice to the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government.
The grounds of appeal included the argument that the items were not buildings for the purposes of the Listed Buildings Act.
The appeals were dismissed by a planning inspector on 19 January 2017.
The planning inspector held that the status of the items as buildings was established by the listing.
The planning inspector stated that he could not reconsider the issue of whether the items were buildings.
Mr Dill's appeal was rejected by the High Court (Singh J) and the Court of Appeal (McCombe and Coulson LJJ).
Both courts held that listing was conclusive of the items being buildings.
The Supreme Court unanimously allows the appeal.
Lord Carnwath gives the sole judgment, with which the other Justices agree.
The Supreme Court considers whether listing is conclusive of the items being buildings for the purposes of the Listed Buildings Act.
The Supreme Court notes that individuals affected by a legal measure should have a fair opportunity to challenge the measure.
The Supreme Court states that the context of the particular statutory scheme is relevant in applying the principle of fair opportunity.
The Supreme Court refers to the parallel context of breach of planning control, where statutory grounds of appeal are wide.
The Supreme Court suggests that the question of whether something is a building may raise difficult factual judgments.
The Supreme Court states that an inspector appointed under the statutory scheme is more appropriately placed to decide such issues than the High Court.
uksc-2013-0158: Olympic Airlines SA was wound up by a court in Athens on 2 October 2009.
The main liquidation proceedings for Olympic Airlines SA are ongoing in Greece.
The company pension scheme has a 16m deficit.
Olympic Airlines SA is liable to make good the deficit by s 75 of the Pensions Act 1995.
It is unlikely that Olympic Airlines SA will be able to make good the deficit.
Members of the pension scheme are eligible for compensation under the Pensions Act 2004 from the UK's Pension Protection Fund.
Compensation is payable from the date when a qualifying insolvency event occurred.
One possible date for the qualifying insolvency event is 20 July 2010.
On 20 July 2010, the trustees of the pension scheme presented a winding up petition in England.
Winding up a company under the Insolvency Act 1986 is a qualifying insolvency event under the Pensions Act 2004, s 121(3)(g).
English courts have jurisdiction to wind up a foreign company under the Insolvency Act 1986.
Under EU Regulation 1346/2000, the English court can only wind up a company if it has an establishment in England.
The second possible date for the qualifying insolvency event is 2 October 2014.
The second possible date is the fifth anniversary of the commencement of the proceedings in Greece.
A change in legislation in 2014 created the possibility of treating 2 October 2014 as a qualifying insolvency event.
The trustees of the pension scheme prefer compensation to be treated as payable from 20 July 2010.
The court's only question is whether Olympic Airlines SA had an establishment in the UK on 20 July 2010.
By 20 July 2010, Olympic Airlines SA had closed all its offices in the UK except for its head office in London.
By 20 July 2010, Olympic Airlines SA had ceased all commercial operations.
By 20 July 2010, Olympic Airlines SA had terminated the contracts of all remaining UK staff except for three individuals.
The three remaining staff were retained on short-term ad hoc contracts to implement instructions from the liquidator in Athens.
The three remaining staff were retained to supervise the disposal of the company’s assets in the UK.
The three remaining staff were retained to pay bills and conduct other administration relating to the head office building.
At first instance, the judge held that the remaining activities constituted non-transitory economic activities.
The judge at first instance concluded that Olympic Airlines SA had an establishment in the UK.
The Court of Appeal disagreed with the first instance judge's conclusion.
The Court of Appeal held that the remaining activity was not enough to give the court jurisdiction.
The trustees of the pension scheme have appealed the Court of Appeal's decision.
The Supreme Court unanimously dismissed the appeal.
Lord Sumption gave the only judgment in the Supreme Court.
uksc-2014-0231: The Public Processions (Northern Ireland) Act 1998 established an independent statutory body called the Parades Commission to manage public parades.
The 1998 Act required organizers of public processions to give advance notice to the police.
Failure to notify the police of a public procession was made a criminal offence under the 1998 Act.
On 3 December 2012, Belfast City Council decided to stop flying the Union flag over Belfast City Hall every day.
The decision to limit the flying of the Union flag sparked protests by loyalists known as the flags protests.
The protesters marched from East Belfast to Belfast City Hall and back, passing through the Short Strand area.
The route of the parades included the Short Strand, which is perceived as a nationalist area.
The parades involved violence, disorder, and sectarian abuse directed at residents in the Short Strand area.
No notification was made under the 1998 Act that the parades were taking place.
Initially, the police decided not to permit the protesters to enter Belfast City Centre.
Between 6 and 8 December 2012, the police changed their decision to allow the protesters to enter Belfast City Centre.
The weekly parades continued until March 2013, during which time the police took no action to stop them.
The police made public announcements stating they had no power to stop unnotified parades.
The police attempted, unsuccessfully, to refer the matter to the Parades Commission.
A resident of Short Strand issued judicial review proceedings challenging the police's failure to act.
The High Court found the police had failed to appreciate their powers to stop unnotified parades.
The Court of Appeal allowed the Chief Constables appeal.
The appellant, DB, appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court unanimously allowed DB's appeal.
The Supreme Court declared the Police Service of Northern Ireland had misconstrued their legal powers.
Lord Kerr delivered the judgment, with which the other justices agreed.
The police had a duty under the general law to prevent the commission of offences, including unnotified parades.
The police mistakenly believed they only had power to prevent general public order offences.
The police failed to recognize the importance of enforcing the notification requirement under the 1998 Act.
The integrity of the 1998 Act depended on the enforcement of the notification requirement.
The police had the responsibility to prevent unnotified parades, not the Parades Commission.
The police mistakenly believed they were obliged by the European Convention on Human Rights to facilitate illegal protests.
The police had a duty to prevent illegal parades and protect rights under the European Convention on Human Rights.
Allowing article 11 considerations to determine how parades were policed was not justified.
The High Court was correct in concluding the police had a misapprehension about their powers.
